page.title: 2009 flu pandemic in the United States by state

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Multiple issues| {{update|date=December 2009}} {{very long|date=January 2010}} }} {{2009 US swine flu outbreak table}} {{Main article|2009 flu pandemic}} The United States experienced the beginnings of a [[pandemic]] of a novel strain of the [[Influenza A virus subtype H1N1#2009 A(H1N1) pandemic|influenza A/H1N1]] virus, commonly referred to as "[[swine flu]]", in the spring of 2009. The earliest reported cases in the US began appearing in late March 2009 in California,{{cite web| title=CDC Press Briefing Transcripts April 23, 2009|url=https://www.cdc.gov/media/transcripts/2009/t090423.htm|publisher=CDC|accessdate=June 11, 2009|date=April 23, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090605145129/http://www.cdc.gov/media/transcripts/2009/t090423.htm| archivedate= June 5, 2009 | deadurl= no}} then spreading to infect people in Texas, New York, and other states by mid-April.{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/topNews/idUKTRE5435R220090504|title=Flu spreads across U.S., officials weigh measures | Top News | Reuters|publisher=Uk.reuters.com|date=February 9, 2009|accessdate=May 5, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090507072145/http://uk.reuters.com/article/topNews/idUKTRE5435R220090504| archivedate= May 7, 2009 | deadurl= no}} Early cases were associated with recent travel to Mexico; many were students who had traveled to Mexico for Spring Break.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/05/04/health/main4988673.shtml |title=Queens School At Flu Epicenter Reopens |publisher=CBS News |date= May 4, 2009|accessdate=May 8, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090507080303/http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/05/04/health/main4988673.shtml| archivedate= May 7, 2009 | deadurl= no}} This spread continued across the country's population and by the end of May there were approximately 0{{Clarify|date=March 2010}} confirmed cases throughout all 50 states.{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/h1n1flu/ |title=H1N1 Flu (Swine Flu) |work=H1N1 Flu |publisher=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] |date=May 6, 2009 |accessdate=May 6, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhOamgHk?url=http://www.cdc.gov/h1n1flu/ |archivedate=September 11, 2009 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} On April 28, 2009, the director of the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) confirmed the first official US death of swine flu, a 23-month-old toddler from Mexico who died on April 27 while visiting Texas.{{cite news|url=http://cnnwire.blogs.cnn.com/2009/04/29/swine-flu-fatality-in-texas-likely-infected-in-mexico-official-says/ |work=CNN |title=Swine flu fatality in Texas likely infected in Mexico, official says |accessdate=December 6, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503220655/http://cnnwire.blogs.cnn.com/2009/04/29/swine-flu-fatality-in-texas-likely-infected-in-mexico-official-says/ |archivedate=May 3, 2009 }} By June 24, 132 deaths had been attributed to the virus. As of January 11, 2010, at least 13,837 deaths were attributed to the virus worldwide, and at least 2290 deaths in the US were confirmed to be due to the virus. The CDC suspects, however, that the total number of deaths in the US is much higher than the official total, as some deaths probably went unconfirmed.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} {{Horizontal TOC|nonum=y|limit=2}} ==Alabama== [[File:AlabamaH1N1.PNG|thumb|left|Alabama
As of July 21, 2009:
{{legend|#cd3412|Case(s) confirmed}}]] On May 2, 2009, the Alabama Department of Public Health confirmed the first case of H1N1 (swine flu) in [[Madison, Alabama|Madison]], Alabama,{{cite web|url=http://adph.org/news/assets/090502.pdf|title=Alabama reports five additional probable cases & first confirmed case of H1N1 (swine) flu|accessdate=May 4, 2009|date=May 2, 2009|format=PDF|publisher=Alabama Department of Public Health}} one of two probable cases previously identified at an elementary school in [[Madison, Alabama|Madison]].{{cite web|url=http://www.waff.com/Global/story.asp?S=10275514&nav=0hBEZy5S |title=2 probable, 10 possible cases of swine flu in Madison County – WAFF.com: North Alabama News, Radar, Weather, Sports and Jobs |publisher=WAFF.com |accessdate=April 30, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503150814/http://www.waff.com/Global/story.asp?S=10275514&nav=0hBEZy5S |archivedate=May 3, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} As a result, all public schools and most private schools and daycare centers in Madison County, Alabama, including the cities of [[Huntsville, Alabama|Huntsville]] and [[Madison, Alabama|Madison]], closed for two days.{{cite web|url=http://www.waff.com/Global/story.asp?S=10275703|title=School and day-care closures due to probable swine flu outbreak – WAFF.com: North Alabama News, Radar, Weather, Sports and Jobs|publisher=WAFF.com|accessdate=April 30, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090601202349/http://www.waff.com/Global/story.asp?S=10275703| archivedate=June 1, 2009| deadurl= no}} After meeting with the state public health officer on May 3, 2009, all Madison city elementary schools were to be closed through May 13, 2009,{{cite web |url=http://www.madisoncity.k12.al.us/news/letter4.htm |title=Letter from Dr. Fowler concerning Madison Elementary Schools CLOSED 14 Days from April 30 |author= Dee O. Fowler |date=May 2, 2009 |publisher= Madison City Schools |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090505040334/http://www.madisoncity.k12.al.us/news/letter4.htm |archivedate=May 5, 2009 |accessdate=May 4, 2009}} but were reopened after the CDC updated its guidance to schools. As of December 5, 2009, the Alabama Department of Public Health reports 2453 confirmed and 36 deaths from swine flu. As of January 9, 2010, Alabama was the only US state reporting widespread A/H1N1 flu activity. ==Alaska== On May 10, 2009, the Alaska state Division of Public Health reported the state's first probable case of swine flu in a crew member of a Royal Caribbean cruise ship traveling in Alaska waters.{{cite web|author=Mary Pemberton |publisher=The Associated Press |url=http://www.adn.com/life/health/story/790532.html |title=Swine flu suspected on Alaska cruise ship: Health |work=adn.com |accessdate=May 19, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090513022026/http://www.adn.com/life/health/story/790532.html |archivedate=May 13, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} On May 12, they confirmed that the woman had been infected with swine flu but they do not consider it to be Alaska's first case because she became ill before entering state waters. As of December 5, 460 cases of swine flu and 11 deaths were confirmed in Alaska.[http://www.hss.state.ak.us/press/2009/H1N1_pr_061209.pdf Alaska health department report on the new swine flu cases] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090617184948/http://www.hss.state.ak.us/press/2009/H1N1_pr_061209.pdf |date=June 17, 2009 }} On July 27, Alaska health officials confirmed the first H1N1-related death. ==Arizona== As of October 31, the Arizona Department of Health Services had reported a total of 6,302 confirmed cases of H1N1 infection since April 2009, with at least one case reported in each of the state's 15 counties. 786 of the cases had resulted in hospitalization of the patient, and 81 deaths were associated with H1N1 infection in that period of time. Of the H1N1 associated deaths reported in the state, 72% suffered an underlying medical condition (asthma, lung or heart conditions, cancer, metabolic disorders, pregnancy, immunosuppressive disorders, neurologic diseases or other chronic diseases) at the time of death.{{cite web|url=http://www.azdhs.gov/phs/oids/epi/flu/pdf/weeklyflureport.pdf |archivedate=November 23, 2009 |format=PDF |publisher=Arizona Department of Health Services |title=Weekly Influenza Summary |date=October 31, 2009 |accessdate=November 12, 2009 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091123202605/http://www.azdhs.gov/phs/oids/epi/flu/pdf/weeklyflureport.pdf |df= }} On April 28, the first cases of H1N1 influenza infection in Arizona were confirmed in four school-aged patients in the [[Phoenix metropolitan area]]. The schools attended by the patients were immediately closed following recommendations from the CDC; after only 3 days, however, local authorities reopened the schools, stating that the H1N1 flu appeared to be no more deadly than the seasonal flu.{{cite news|url=http://www.azcentral.com/news/articles/2009/05/05/20090505arizflu0505.html|title=Teachers scramble as school closings lifted at 3 schools|last=Fehr-Snyder|first=Kerry|date=May 5, 2009|accessdate=May 20, 2009|publisher=[[The Arizona Republic]]}} School closures in the area have since been eliminated in favor of simply sending the infected children home, resulting in slightly elevated absence rates statewide.{{cite news|url=http://www.azcentral.com/news/articles/2009/11/02/20091102schoolflu1102.html|title=Valley students with flu symptoms sent home|date=November 2, 2009|accessdate=November 12, 2009|publisher=The Arizona Republic|first=Emily|last=Gersema}} The first death in the state due to H1N1 swine flu complications was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health on May 14.{{cite news|url=http://www.azcentral.com/12news/news/articles/2009/05/14/20090514ariz-swine0514-ON-CP.html|title=Arizona woman dies of swine flu complications|last=Turner|first=Channing|date=May 15, 2009|accessdate=May 18, 2009|publisher=[[The Arizona Republic]]}} As of January 15, Arizona has reported 142 deaths due to confirmed A/H1N1 influenza, including at least 2 in 2010 alone.[http://www.azdhs.gov Arizona Department of Health Services] ==Arkansas== [[File:ArkansasH1N1.PNG|thumb|left|Arkansas
As of July 21, 2009:
{{legend|#cd3412|Case(s) confirmed}}]] As of July 16, 2009, the Arkansas Department of Health has reported 51 confirmed cases of swine flu.{{cite web|url=http://www.myeyewitnessnews.com/news/local/story/5-Cases-of-Swine-Flu-Confirmed-in-Arkansas/C85aiTjLPUuJSvJUSy2GZQ.cspx |title=5 Cases of Swine Flu Confirmed in Arkansas|myEyewitnessNews.com, Memphis News, Entertainment, Videos, Business Search and Shopping |publisher=Myeyewitnessnews.com |date=April 30, 2009 |accessdate=May 19, 2009}}{{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Four of the cases were from Camp Robinson, a US Army National Guard base located in North Little Rock in Pulaski County. {{clear left}} ==California== Deaths by county: {{colbegin|colwidth=30em}} *Alameda – 33[http://www.acphd.org/H1N1/index.htm Alameda County Public Health – Novel H1N1 (Swine) Flu] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091031012734/http://www.acphd.org/H1N1/index.htm |date=October 31, 2009 }} *Berkeley City – 1[http://www.cdph.ca.gov/data/statistics/Pages/H1N1FluDataTables.aspx H1N1 Flu – Data Tables] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091001121602/http://www.cdph.ca.gov/data/statistics/Pages/H1N1FluDataTables.aspx |date=October 1, 2009 }} *Butte – 3 *Calaveras – 5[http://www.mymotherlode.com/news/local/news_detail.php?ID=533626 Calaveras County Reports Fifth H1N1 Victim – myMotherLode.com] *Contra Costa – 15{{cite web |url=http://cchealth.org/topics/swine_flu/deaths.php |title=Contra Costa Fatalities with H1N1 |website=Contra Costa Health Services |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091030041646/http://cchealth.org/topics/swine_flu/deaths.php |archivedate=October 30, 2009 |accessdate=January 7, 2010}} *El Dorado – 1 *Fresno – 22http://www.co.fresno.ca.us/uploadedFiles/Departments/Public_Health/Divisions/CH/content/CD/content/Diseases/H1N1_Flu_(Swine_Flu)_Updates/content/09351_PanFluStatus121509.pdf *Humboldt – 4[http://www.times-standard.com/ci_13960504 Fourth H1N1 death reported – Times-Standard Online] *Imperial – 2 *Kern – 22 *Kings – 3 *Lake – 1 *Long Beach City – 7 *Los Angeles – 149{{cite web | url=http://www.publichealth.lacounty.gov/acd/docs/Flu/IWcurrent.pdf | title=LA County Department of Public Health}} *Madera – 4 *Marin – 5 *Mendocino – 4 *Merced – 5 *Monterey – 4 *Napa – 1 *Nevada – 1 *Orange – 56 *Placer – 5 *Riverside – 40 *Sacramento – 22 *San Benito – 1 *San Bernardino – 43 *San Diego – 63[http://www.10news.com/news/23141194/detail.html Death Of Man, 22, Linked To H1N1 – San Diego News Story – KGTV San Diego] *San Francisco – 8 *San Joaquin – 13http://www.sjcphs.org/Disease/documents/Influenza%20Report%20Weeks%2046%20and%2047.pdf *San Luis Obispo – 3 *San Mateo – 11 *Santa Barbara – 9[http://www.ksby.com/news/another-central-coast-residents-dies-from-h1n1-virus/ Another Central Coast residents dies from H1N1 virus | KSBY.com | San Luis Obispo, Santa Maria, Santa Barbara, Paso Robles] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927154720/http://www.ksby.com/news/another-central-coast-residents-dies-from-h1n1-virus/ |date=September 27, 2011 }} *Santa Clara – 21 *Santa Cruz – 3 *Shasta – 2[http://www.redding.com/news/2009/nov/09/shasta-county-resident-dies-h1n1-complications/?print=1 Shasta County resident dies from H1N1 complications : Record Searchlight] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091118095459/http://www.redding.com/news/2009/nov/09/shasta-county-resident-dies-h1n1-complications/?print=1 |date=November 18, 2009 }} *Solano – 8[http://www.mercurynews.com/breaking-news/ci_14799895?nclick_check=1 Recent Solano County swine flu death not immediately reported – San Jose Mercury News] *Sonoma – 11[http://www.pressdemocrat.com/article/20100226/news/100229555 11th swine flu death in Sonoma County | PressDemocrat.com] *Stanislaus – 13 *Tehama – 2 *Trinity – 1 *Tulare – 6 *Tuolumne – 1 *Ventura – 14[http://www.vcstar.com/news/2010/jan/12/14th-person-in-county-dies-of-swine-flu/ County reports 14th swine flu death » Ventura County Star] *Yolo – 6 *Yuba – 3 *Total – 657 {{colend}} [[File:H1N1 California Map.svg|thumb|left|As of July 14, 2009:The [http://www.cdph.ca.gov/Pages/default.aspx California Department of Public Health] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090626005321/http://www.cdph.ca.gov/Pages/default.aspx |date=June 26, 2009 }} will update every Thursday at 14:30 PDT. They have a flu map available here {{cite web|url=http://www.cdph.ca.gov/programs/HISP/Pages/SwineFluTracking.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-06-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090618172619/http://www.cdph.ca.gov/programs/HISP/Pages/SwineFluTracking.aspx |archivedate=June 18, 2009 }}.
{{legend|#000000|Death(s) confirmed}}{{legend|#cd3412|Case(s) confirmed}}{{legend|#eaa912|Case(s) unconfirmed (both suspected and probable cases)}}]] [[File:SwineFlu CDC Media Conference 4-25.ogg|thumb|left|CDC conference with the media on the swine flu outbreak on April 25, 2009]] The first two cases detected in the US were two children living in [[San Diego County, California|San Diego County]] and [[Imperial County, California|Imperial County]] (a county in which 18% of the residents are not US citizens),{{cite news|url=http://www.cnsnews.com/public/content/article.aspx?RsrcID=47515 |title=Earliest Confirmed U.S. Swine Flu Case Was in California Border County Where 18% Are Non-Citizens |author=Terence P. Jeffrey |publisher=[[Cybercast News Service]] |date=May 1, 2009 |accessdate=May 1, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090504040601/http://www.cnsnews.com/public/Content/Article.aspx?rsrcid=47515 |archivedate=May 4, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} who became ill on March 28 and 30 respectively.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/04/21/AR2009042103694.html|title=New Strain of Swine Flu Investigated: Two Children in San Diego Area Had No Contact with Pigs|author=David Brown|work=Washington Post|date=April 22, 2009|accessdate=April 24, 2009}} A CDC alert concerning these two isolated cases was reported in the media on April 21.{{cite news|title=Officials alert doctors after 2 California children infected with unusual swine flu |author=Mike Stobbe |agency=Associated Press |date=April 21, 2009 |url=http://www.startribune.com/lifestyle/health/43357097.html |accessdate=April 24, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090430115903/http://www.startribune.com/lifestyle/health/43357097.html |archivedate=April 30, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }} As of April 24 eight human cases were known in the US, including six in Southern California. The patients have recovered.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/8016909.stm|title= Experts probe deadly Mexico flu |date=April 24, 2009|accessdate=April 25, 2009|publisher=BBC| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090425170758/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/8016909.stm| archivedate= April 25, 2009 | deadurl= no}} The acting director of the US [[Centers for Disease Control]] (CDC) said that preliminary tests on seven out of fourteen samples from patients in Mexico had matched the virus found in the US, which experts say is a new strain of swine flu. None of the US patients had any contact with pigs, leading CDC officials to believe that human-to-human transmission has been occurring.{{cite news|first=Rob|last=Stein|title=In California and Texas, 5 New Swine Flu Cases|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/04/23/AR2009042304116.html|work=Washington Post|date=April 24, 2009|accessdate=April 26, 2009}} Gov. [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] and the state of California activated the Joint Emergency Operations Center of the [[California Department of Public Health|Department of Public Health]], and are coordinating with the California Emergency Management Agency, the CDC, and the Mexican government. They have additionally stepped up other preparations to lessen the flu's threat.{{cite web|title=Gov. Schwarzenegger Directs State Swine Flu Response |url=http://gov.ca.gov/press-release/12129/ |date=April 24, 2009 |publisher=State of California |accessdate=April 25, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090427105419/http://gov.ca.gov/press-release/12129 |archivedate=April 27, 2009 }} On April 28, Gov. Schwarzenegger declared a state of emergency which allows the state to deploy additional resources to the Department of Public Health and more quickly and easily purchase equipment and materials.{{cite web|url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/N28344841.htm|title=Reuters AlertNet – Swine flu prompts California 'state of emergency'|publisher=Alertnet.org|accessdate=April 28, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090502011732/http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/N28344841.htm| archivedate= May 2, 2009 | deadurl= no}} St. Mels Catholic School in [[Fair Oaks, California|Fair Oaks]] was closed after [[Sacramento County, California|Sacramento County]] Health Department notified the school that a 7th grade student who reportedly recently returned from a family vacation in Mexico tested positive for an unidentified strain of influenza virus A.{{cite news|first=Hudson |last=Sangree |url=http://www.sacbee.com/content/news/story/1811611.html |title=Sacramento School Closed in Possible Swine Flu Case |publisher=The Sacramento Bee |date=April 26, 2009 |accessdate=April 26, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090430120732/http://www.sacbee.com/content/news/story/1811611.html |archivedate=April 30, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} On April 27, CDC officials confirmed that the student tested positive for swine flu.{{cite news|first=Niesha |last=Lofing |url=http://www.sacbee.com/1310/story/1813776.html |title=CDC confirms swine flu in Fair Oaks student |publisher=[[The Sacramento Bee]] |date=April 27, 2009 |accessdate=April 27, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090430094605/http://sacbee.com/1310/story/1813776.html |archivedate=April 30, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} In [[Marin County, California|Marin County]], a grandmother and her 20-month-old granddaughter have been confirmed to have the flu.{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/Swine_Flu_Makes_it_to_the_Bay_Area_Bay_Area.html|title=Swine Flu Makes it to the Bay Area|publisher=NBC Bay Area|accessdate=April 29, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090502183338/http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/Swine_Flu_Makes_it_to_the_Bay_Area_Bay_Area.html| archivedate= May 2, 2009 | deadurl= no}} By April 28, the CDC had confirmed 10 cases of swine flu in California.{{cite web|title=Swine Influenza (Flu)|url=https://www.cdc.gov/h1n1flu/updates/042809.htm|publisher=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]]|date= April 28, 2009|accessdate=May 1, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090504004825/http://www.cdc.gov/h1n1flu/updates/042809.htm| archivedate= May 4, 2009 | deadurl= no}} [[California State University, Long Beach]] reported on April 29 that a student had returned a "probable positive" test result for swine influenza. The student showed symptoms on Sunday April 26 and went to the campus health services office the following day. The test results were received by the school on April 28 and distributed to all students and faculty. The affected student had not attended any classes since falling ill and has an apparently mild case of the disease that does not appear life-threatening.{{cite web|url=http://emergency.csulb.edu/advisory/|title=CSULB Health Advisory|publisher=California State University, Long Beach|accessdate=April 29, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090502160901/http://emergency.csulb.edu/advisory/| archivedate= May 2, 2009 | deadurl= no}} Three high schools in [[Riverside County]] were closed April 29 after two teenage girls, from [[Corona, California|Corona]] and [[Indio, California|Indio]] respectively, were confirmed to have contracted the virus.{{cite news|url=http://www.thevalleychronicle.com/articles/2009/04/29/news/doc49f8f7ad06144194074911.txt |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503080133/http://www.thevalleychronicle.com/articles/2009/04/29/news/doc49f8f7ad06144194074911.txt |dead-url=yes |archive-date=May 3, 2009 |title=County health officials: Swine flu in Riverside County |last=Helton |first=Kari |date=April 29, 2009 |work=The Valley Chronicle |accessdate=April 30, 2009 |df=mdy-all }} [[Branham High School]] in [[San Jose, California|San Jose]] was closed that day for a week after one teenage girl was confirmed to be a probable case.{{cite news|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/ci_12252778|title=Branham High student tests positive for swine flu; school closed for 1 week|last=Gomez| first=Mark|date=April 29, 2009|work=San Jose Mercury News|accessdate=April 30, 2009}} Rucker Elementary School in [[Gilroy, California|Gilroy]] is set to be closed on Friday, May 1 after at least one student was being tested after exhibiting flu-like symptoms.{{cite news|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/health/ci_12263134?nclick_check=1|title=Four more Santa Clara County schools close because of swine flu fears|last=Mangaliman| first=Jessie|date=April 30, 2009|work=San Jose Mercury News|accessdate=April 30, 2009}} Three students at the Grizzly Youth Academy in San Luis Obispo are confirmed cases of swine influenza. As many as 73 students are exhibiting flu-like symptoms at The Academy and are assumed to have the virus. All are being isolated. The Academy is set to stay open.{{cite news|url=http://www.ksby.com/Global/story.asp?S=10284548 |title=Three probable swine flu cases located in San Luis Obispo |last=Ryan Foran |first=Jessie |date=May 1, 2009 |work=KSBY News |accessdate=May 1, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503165602/http://www.ksby.com/Global/story.asp?S=10284548 |archivedate=May 3, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} On May 3, 2009, parent of students attending King Middle School in Berkeley were notified that their school would be closed down due to a swine flu outbreak involving students at the school. Days later, other schools were closed down because of students or staff exhibiting flu-like symptoms; for example, Sunnyside Elementary School and Woodville Elementary School, both in [[Tulare County]].[https://archive.is/20120907090049/http://www.recorderonline.com/news/swine-41196-closed-union.html Flu closes Sunnyside, Woodville Union elementary schools | swine, closed, union – Local News – Recorderonline.com] On June 1, 2009, the first two deaths were confirmed, one by a middle-aged man in [[San Bernardino County]], and another one by a middle-aged woman in [[Los Angeles County]].{{cite web|url=https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Pages/NR2009-48.aspx |title=California Confirms Two Deaths from Novel H1N1 Flu |website=California Department of Public Health |accessdate=June 26, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090701191102/http://www.cdph.ca.gov/Pages/NR2009-48.aspx |archivedate=July 1, 2009 }} A third death was confirmed on June 4, when a nine-year-old girl from [[Contra Costa County]] died.{{cite web|url=http://www.cdph.ca.gov/HealthInfo/news/Pages/NR2009-49-FirstCaliforniaChildDeathWithH1N1FluVirus.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-06-26 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090617212922/http://www.cdph.ca.gov/HealthInfo/news/Pages/NR2009-49-FirstCaliforniaChildDeathWithH1N1FluVirus.aspx |archivedate=June 17, 2009 |df=mdy }} at the [[Library of Congress]] (June 17, 2009). They were followed by an [[Orange County, California|Orange County]] man's death on June 8 and a middle-aged man's death in [[Alameda County]] on June 9.http://www.mercurynews.com/news/ci_12553750 As of June 9, there were 973 confirmed cases, 266 probable cases, and five deaths caused by the H1N1 flu. On June 10, another middle-aged man died in Alameda County, thus making it the third death in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]].[http://www.mercurynews.com/alamedacounty/ci_12569939 Second swine flu-related death reported in Alameda County – San Jose Mercury News] On July 1, a woman who had been hospitalized in [[Marin County, California|Marin County]] died of swine flu.{{cite news|title=''San Francisco Chronicle'', July 1st, 2009 |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/blogs/inmarin/detail?&entry_id=42896 |work=The San Francisco Chronicle |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhOc4KUz?url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/blogs/inmarin/detail?%26entry_id%3D42896 |archivedate=September 11, 2009 |accessdate=2009-09-02 |first=Pam |last=Gould |date=July 1, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }} As of July 23, 2009, 2,655 cases and 61 deaths in California had been confirmed.{{cite web|title=California Health Department report on swine flu |url=http://www.cdph.ca.gov/HealthInfo/discond/Pages/SwineInfluenza.aspx |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhOuuMa1?url=http://www.cdph.ca.gov/HealthInfo/discond/Pages/SwineInfluenza.aspx |archivedate=September 11, 2009 |accessdate=September 2, 2009 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} A list of hospitalizations and deaths can be viewed at the California Department of Health Website.{{cite web|title=Novel Influenza A (H1N1) Virus (swine flu) |url=http://www.cdph.ca.gov/HealthInfo/discond/Pages/SwineInfluenza.aspx |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhOuuMa1?url=http://www.cdph.ca.gov/HealthInfo/discond/Pages/SwineInfluenza.aspx |archivedate=September 11, 2009 |accessdate=September 2, 2009 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} As of mid-September 2009, California had 2,655 cases and 152 deaths. As of January 15,{{When|date=May 2012}} at least 479 California residents had died from confirmed H1N1 infection.[http://www.cdph.ca.gov California Department of Public Health] ==Colorado== On April 30 two cases of the flu virus were confirmed in the state of [[Colorado]]. The confirmed cases were a woman from [[Arapahoe County, Colorado|Arapahoe County]] who recently returned from a cruise to Mexico and a [[Denver International Airport]] [[baggage handler]].{{cite news|url=http://www.denverpost.com/ci_12268009|title=Swine flu arrives in Colo.|last=Brown|first=Jennifer|author2=Howard Pankratz|page=A-01|date=May 1, 2009|work=The Denver Post|accessdate=May 1, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090503125326/http://www.denverpost.com/ci_12268009| archivedate= May 3, 2009 | deadurl= no}} Two more H1N1 influenza cases were confirmed on May 2, both in [[Jefferson County, Colorado|Jefferson County]], Colorado. One case is a middle school student, which has caused the school he attends to close for a week.{{cite web|url=http://cbs4denver.com/health/flu.swine.cases.2.1000245.html|title=Colorado Swine Flu Cases Rise To 4, School Closed|publisher=CBS4denver.com|accessdate=May 3, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090505153511/http://cbs4denver.com/health/flu.swine.cases.2.1000245.html| archivedate= May 5, 2009 | deadurl= yes}} The tally increased to seven on May 4 when The [[University of Colorado at Boulder]] (CU) confirmed three of its students contracted the virus.{{cite web|url=http://www.thedenverchannel.com/health/19364241/detail.html|title=CU Says 3 Students May Have H1N1 Flu|publisher=thedenverchannel.com|accessdate=May 4, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090507061929/http://www.thedenverchannel.com/health/19364241/detail.html| archivedate= May 7, 2009 | deadurl= no}} There were 171 cases reported in Colorado as of July 18. On July 29, 2009 Colorado reported its first A(H1N1) swine flu death in El Paso County of a woman in her forties. ==Connecticut== On April 28, it was announced that there were suspected cases of swine flu in three [[Connecticut]] towns. Schools were closed due to suspected cases in [[East Haddam, Connecticut|East Haddam]]{{cite web|title=Four suspected cases of swine flu in CT|date=April 28, 2009|publisher=[[WTNH]]|accessdate=April 28, 2009|url=http://www.wtnh.com/dpp/news/news_wtnh_easthaddam_swineflu_200904291335| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090501113806/http://www.wtnh.com/dpp/news/news_wtnh_easthaddam_swineflu_200904291335| archivedate= May 1, 2009 | deadurl= no}} and [[Wethersfield, Connecticut|Wethersfield]],{{cite web|title=Swine flu claims 1st victim in US|date=April 29, 2009|publisher=[[WTNH]]|accessdate=April 29, 2009|url=http://www.wtnh.com/dpp/news/news_ap_swinefludeath_200904290915| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090502183009/http://www.wtnh.com/dpp/news/news_ap_swinefludeath_200904290915| archivedate= May 2, 2009 | deadurl= no}} though tests on these patients later came back negative.[http://www.wtnh.com/dpp/news/news_wtnh_ehaddam_students_negative_for_swine_flu_200904301032 H1N1 cases negative in two towns] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090603023131/http://www.wtnh.com/dpp/news/news_wtnh_ehaddam_students_negative_for_swine_flu_200904301032 |date=June 3, 2009 }} [[WTNH]]. Retrieved April 30, 2009. On April 30, two students at [[Fairfield University]] were announced as having "probable" swine flu, in addition to another person in [[Glastonbury, Connecticut|Glastonbury]], bringing the total number of likely cases to 6.[http://www.connpost.com/breakingnews/ci_12263196 Ffld U students may have swine flu] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090504020115/http://www.connpost.com/breakingnews/ci_12263196 |date=May 4, 2009 }} [[Connecticut Post]]. 2009-04-30. Retrieved April 30, 2009.[http://www.wtnh.com/dpp/news/news_wtnh_Glastonbury_swine_200904301945 6th probable H1N1 case in Glastonbury] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090604020200/http://www.wtnh.com/dpp/news/news_wtnh_Glastonbury_swine_200904301945 |date=June 4, 2009 }} [[WTNH]]. Retrieved April 30, 2009. On May 1, the first confirmed case of swine flu was reported in Connecticut in [[Stratford, Connecticut|Stratford]]. On May 2, the second confirmed case was reported in a child from Middlefield that had recently returned from a family trip to Mexico.{{cite news |url=http://www.courant.com/news/health/hcu-swine-flu-second-case-0502,0,1554727.story |title=Second Swine Flu Case Confirmed In Connecticut |date=May 2, 2009 |publisher=[[Hartford Courant]] |accessdate=May 2, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090505173221/http://www.courant.com/news/health/hcu-swine-flu-second-case-0502%2C0%2C1554727.story |archivedate=May 5, 2009 |deadurl=no |df=mdy-all }} On May 5, Fairfield University announced that two "probable" cases had tested positive for the H1N1 flu, with five other "probable" cases awaiting test results.{{cite web|url=http://www.stamfordplus.com/stm/information/nws1/publish/health/CDC-confirms-two-more-cases-of-novel-H1N1-flu-in-Connecticut4870.shtml |title=News – CDC confirms two more cases of novel H1N1 flu in Connecticut |publisher=Stamfordplus.com |accessdate=May 19, 2009}} One May 8, Fairfield announced that those five students had also tested positive, although the students by that time were nearly recovered, and there remained one "probable" case remained to be confirmed. On Wednesday, June 3, The first death confirmed to be linked to the H1N1 virus happened in New Haven County. As of Wednesday, June 17 there are 7 confirmed cases of the H1N1 virus at [[Joseph A. Foran High School]] of [[Milford, Connecticut|Milford]]. The school is following a half day schedule until the end of the year, which was reported as being successful for preventing the virus. By July 22, 2009, there were 1,713 confirmed cases of swine flu in Connecticut. New Haven has the most of any town with 175 cases.[http://www.ct.gov/ctfluwatch/cwp/view.asp?a=2533&q=439218 Connecticut government's flu watch site] In January 2010, the Connecticut CDC stated that there were 1,996 confirmed cases of A/H1N1 influenza in the first wave of the A/H1N1 influenza pandemic, and 3,386 confirmed cases of A/H1N1 influenza in the second wave of the A/H1N1 pandemic. 31 deaths from A/H1N1 were confirmed over the course of the pandemic.[http://www.ct.gov/ctfluwatch/cwp/view.asp?a=2533&q=439218 CTFLUWATCH: CT Towns with Confirmed 2009 H1N1 Flu Cases] ==Delaware== The first probable cases of swine flu in Delaware were reported on Monday, April 27. Four probable cases of swine flu were reported on the [[University of Delaware]] campus after the students were experiencing flu like symptoms. Tests were sent to the CDC to see if the students had the swine flu. All four cases were confirmed by the CDC on April 28. The students were reported to be recovering, and the campus set up a temporary Public Health clinic.{{cite news|author=Lauren Wilson |date=May 1, 2009 |url=http://abclocal.go.com/wpvi/story?section=news/health&id=6789057 |title=CDC investigating swine flu at Univ. of Del. |work=6 ABC Action News |location=Philadelphia |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503024721/http://abclocal.go.com/wpvi/story?section=news%2Fhealth&id=6789057 |archivedate=May 3, 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=May 1, 2009 |df=mdy-all }} The Delaware Division of Public Health reported on May 1 a further 17 probable cases, all from the university.{{cite web|url=http://dhss.delaware.gov/dhss/pressreleases/2009/swineflu-050109.html|title=SWINE FLU UPDATE|date=May 1, 2009|publisher=Delaware Health and Social Services|accessdate=May 2, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090503151323/http://dhss.delaware.gov/dhss/pressreleases/2009/swineflu-050109.html| archivedate=May 3, 2009| deadurl= yes}} As of July 24, the CDC had reported 381 cases for Delaware. October 22, a Kent County woman was Delaware's first H1N1-related death. As of January 2010, six deaths in Delaware had been confirmed to be do to H1N1 influenza. ==District of Columbia== As of June 19, 2009, the DC Department of Health reported 43 confirmed and 2 probable cases of swine flu. The department website has since not updated its case counts.{{cite web|url=http://wbal.com/apps/news/templates/story.aspx?articleid=26976&zoneid=3 |title=Graduates Get Diplomas, Hand Sanitizer – WBAL Radio |publisher=wbal.com |accessdate=May 19, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Florida== {{colbegin|colwidth=30em}} *Alachua – 6[http://www.doh.state.fl.us/Disease_ctrl/epi/swineflu/Reports/reports.htm Swine Flu Weekly Surveillance Reports] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090920132355/http://www.doh.state.fl.us/DISEASE_CTRL/EPI/swineflu/Reports/reports.htm |date=September 20, 2009 }} *Baker – 1 *Brevard – 5 *Broward – 12 *Calhoun – 1 *Charlotte – 2 *Citrus – 2 *Clay – 1 *Dade – 38 *DeSoto – 1 *Duval – 13 *Escambia – 1 *Hernando – 2 *Highlands – 2 *Hillsborough – 17 *Indian River – 1 *Lake – 1 *Lee – 5 *Levy – 2 *Manatee – 3 *Marion – 1 *Monroe – 2 *Nassau – 1 *Okaloosa – 2 *Okeechobee – 2 *Orange – 14[http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/local/breakingnews/os-orange-h1n1-death-20100126,0,5882172.story Orange County reports 14th death from H1N1 swine flu – Orlando Sentinel] *Osceola 1 *Palm Beach – 12 *Pasco – 3 *Pinellas – 13 *Polk – 9 *Putnam – 1 *Santa Rosa – 2 *Sarasota – 5 *Seminole – 4 *St. Johns – 2 *St. Lucie – 9 *Sumter – 1 *Taylor 1 *Volusia 6 *Walton 1 *Total 208 {{colend}} On April 28, it was reported that an individual in Florida had tested positive for influenza type A, of which swine flu is a subtype. A culture from that person has been sent to Jacksonville to be tested for swine flu, with results expected within 48 hours.{{cite web|url=http://www.myfoxorlando.com/dpp/news/042809no_swine|title=Florida Hospital: No Swine Flu case|publisher=Myfoxorlando.com|accessdate=April 28, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090501131120/http://www.myfoxorlando.com/dpp/news/042809no_swine| archivedate= May 1, 2009 | deadurl= yes}} [[Charlie Crist|Governor Crist]] announced the first two confirmed cases in Florida on May 1. The cases are both children and in [[Lee County, Florida|Lee]] and [[Broward County|Broward]] counties.{{cite web|url=http://www.doh.state.fl.us/DEMO/php/H1N1MediaReleaseMay-1-09_fivethirty.doc |title=Florida Department of Health: Swine Flu Reports |publisher=Florida Department of Health |accessdate=May 1, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090521045157/http://www.doh.state.fl.us/DEMO/php/H1N1MediaReleaseMay-1-09_fivethirty.doc |archivedate=May 21, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} On May 3, the [[Hillsborough County, Florida|Hillsborough County]] Health Department announced 5 possible cases of H1N1, 4 of the persons are students, and the other is a relative who has recently traveled to Mexico. Three public schools (Wilson Middle School, Freedom High School, and Liberty Middle School) where the students attended have been closed till May 11.{{cite web|url=http://www.933flz.com/cc-common/news/sections/newsarticle.html?feed=124415&article=5408530|title=Five Probable Swine Flu Cases in Hillsborough| publisher=TAMPA, Florida. (970 WFLA)|date=2009-05-03|accessdate=May 3, 2009}} On May 7, [[Alachua County, Florida|Alachua County]] announced its first case of H1N1 (Swine Flu). The person is a [[University of Florida]] student and has since recovered.{{cite web|url=http://www.gainesville.com/article/20090507/ARTICLES/905079943/1002?Title=Swine-flu-case-confirmed-in-Alachua-County|title=Swine flu case confirmed in Alachua County|accessdate=July 1, 2009}} On May 8, a 7-year-old boy tested positive of swine influenza in [[Rockledge, Florida|Rockledge]], [[Brevard County, Florida|Brevard County]], Florida . Two other children tested positive for influenza. It caused Golfview Elementary School in Rockledge to close on May 11.{{cite web|url=http://cfnews13.com/Health/YourHealth/2009/5/9/golfview_elementary_closing_monday_due_to_swine_flu_scare.html |title=Swine Flu Concerns Close Golfview Elementary In Brevard. Retrieved on 2009-5-10 |publisher=Cfnews13.com |date=May 10, 2009 |accessdate=May 19, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090511201520/http://www.cfnews13.com/Health/YourHealth/2009/5/9/golfview_elementary_closing_monday_due_to_swine_flu_scare.html |archivedate=May 11, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} On June 9, a 9-year-old boy died of Swine Flu in Miami Dade{{cite news |title=Florida confirms state's 1st swine flu death |url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1A1-D98RSO501.html |work=AP online |date=June 16, 2009 |accessdate=April 27, 2016 |via=[[HighBeam Research]] |subscription=yes}} On July 10, a woman died of H1n1 in [[Palm Beach County]].{{cite web|title=Palm Beach County's first swine flu victim was new mom; pandemic expected to worsen |url=http://www.palmbeachpost.com/business/content/business/epaper/2009/07/10/0710swineflu.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhOdOBSl?url=http://www.palmbeachpost.com/business/content/business/epaper/2009/07/10/0710swineflu.html |archivedate=September 11, 2009 |accessdate=September 2, 2009 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} As of July 30, Florida has reported 3,221 cases of swine flu and there is at least one in each of Florida's 67 counties.{{cite web|url=http://www.doh.state.fl.us/DISEASE_CTRL/epi/swineflu/index.html |title=Bureau of Epiemiology – Swine Flu Information |last=Health |first=Florida Department of |date=July 30, 2009 |publisher=Florida Department of Health |accessdate=August 4, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090719011301/http://www.doh.state.fl.us/disease_ctrl/epi/swineflu/index.html |archivedate=July 19, 2009 }} ==Georgia== The first case of laboratory confirmed swine flu was reported on April 30. A Kentucky woman was hospitalized in [[LaGrange, Georgia|LaGrange]] while visiting family in Georgia; she had recently returned from a trip to Mexico.{{cite web|url=http://dhr.georgia.gov/portal/site/DHR/menuitem.3d43c0fad7b3111b50c8798dd03036a0/?vgnextoid=3994c0d1492f0210VgnVCM100000bf01010aRCRD |title=1 Georgia Health Officials confirm state's first human swine flu case |publisher=Georgia Department of Human Resources |accessdate=April 30, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503150904/http://dhr.georgia.gov/portal/site/DHR/menuitem.3d43c0fad7b3111b50c8798dd03036a0/?vgnextoid=3994c0d1492f0210VgnVCM100000bf01010aRCRD |archivedate=May 3, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} While Georgia health officials reported this as a confirmed case for the state, the CDC and the Kentucky health department reported it as a case in Kentucky.{{cite web|url=http://chfs.ky.gov/news/swineflufirstcase.htm |title=Kentucky: Cabinet for Health and Family Services – swineflufirstcase |publisher=Chfs.ky.gov |date=April 30, 2009 |accessdate=May 5, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090510020100/http://chfs.ky.gov/news/swineflufirstcase.htm |archivedate=May 10, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} In relation to this case, state officials said they had no plans to close schools or other public institutions.{{cite web|url=http://www.ajc.com/news/content/health/stories/2009/04/30/swine_flu_georgia.html?cxntlid=homepage_tab_newstab|title=1 Georgia has its first confirmed case of swine flu|publisher=AJC|accessdate=April 30, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090503070959/http://www.ajc.com/news/content/health/stories/2009/04/30/swine_flu_georgia.html?cxntlid=homepage_tab_newstab| archivedate= May 3, 2009 | deadurl= no}} On May 4, the Georgia Department of Human Resources announced that all classes have been temporarily suspended at [[Eagle's Landing Christian Academy]] in Henry County until the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] confirms the status of a student who became ill. The Georgia Public Health Laboratory sent three probable cases to the CDC over the weekend for confirmation.{{cite web|url=http://dhr.georgia.gov/portal/site/DHR/menuitem.3d43c0fad7b3111b50c8798dd03036a0/?vgnextoid=f9b45dfeb1601210VgnVCM100000bf01010aRCRD |title=Eagle's Landing Christian Academy suspends classes pending H1N1 probable case |accessdate=May 4, 2009 |date=May 4, 2009 |publisher=Georgia Department of Human Resources |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090510073052/http://dhr.georgia.gov/portal/site/DHR/menuitem.3d43c0fad7b3111b50c8798dd03036a0/?vgnextoid=f9b45dfeb1601210VgnVCM100000bf01010aRCRD |archivedate=May 10, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} On May 5, the Georgia Division of Public Health confirmed three cases of H1N1 located in [[Cobb County, Georgia|Cobb]], [[DeKalb County, Georgia|DeKalb]] and [[Henry County, Georgia|Henry]] Counties.{{cite web|url=http://health.state.ga.us/h1n1flu/index.asp |title=Human H1N1 (Swine) Influenza GA confirmed cases table |accessdate=May 5, 2009 |date=May 5, 2009 |publisher=Georgia Department of Human Resources |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090513225523/http://health.state.ga.us/h1n1flu/index.asp |archivedate=May 13, 2009 }} Swine flu has been confirmed on the Georgia Tech and Agnes Scott College campuses. The CDC has reported 222 cases of swine flu for Georgia as of July 24. ==Hawaii== {{Expand section|date=December 2009}} {{Update|inaccurate=yes|section|date=December 2009}} On May 4, 2009, the Hawaii Department of Health announced that there were three suspected cases of swine flu in the state. Governor [[Linda Lingle]] announced that the cases were mild and that the patients were recovering at home.{{cite news |title=3 suspected flu cases on Oahu |url=http://www.starbulletin.com/news/20090505_3_suspected_flu_cases_on_Oahu.html |date=May 4, 2009 |newspaper=[[Honolulu Star-Bulletin]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090508050924/http://www.starbulletin.com/news/20090505_3_suspected_flu_cases_on_Oahu.html |archivedate=May 8, 2009 |accessdate=May 5, 2009}} On May 5, 2009, all three cases were confirmed on the island of [[Oahu]] by the CDC. All three cases involve recent travel to the mainland United States. One case is a school-age child, who recently traveled to California. The two other cases are a military member, and his or her spouse. The military member traveled to Texas, and has exposed their spouse.{{cite news |title=CDC confirms three cases of flu in Islands |url=http://www.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/20090505/BREAKING01/90505063/1352 |date=May 5, 2009 |newspaper=[[Honolulu Advertiser]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090509201252/http://www.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/20090505/BREAKING01/90505063/1352 |archivedate=May 9, 2009 |accessdate=May 5, 2009}} Two more cases were confirmed on May 6.{{cite news|url=http://kgmb9.com/main/content/view/17095/251/ |title=2 More Hawaii Cases of Swine Flu Confirmed |date=May 6, 2009 |publisher=[[KGMB]] |accessdate=May 14, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090511003028/http://kgmb9.com/main/content/view/17095/251 |archivedate=May 11, 2009 }} Another four were confirmed on May 13, with two identified at Anuenue School, a [[Hawaiian language]] [[Language immersion|immersion]] school. In response to the outbreak, the [[University of Hawaii at Manoa]] announced that it will not be shaking graduates' hands at its [[Graduation|commencement]].{{cite news|url=http://kgmb9.com/main/content/view/17343/251/ |title=4 New Confirmed Cases of Swine Flu; 2 in Anuenue School |date=May 13, 2009 |publisher=[[KGMB]] |accessdate=May 14, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} On June 19, 2009, Hawaii confirmed its first swine flu-related death, a 60-year-old woman who had complications from the swine flu who later died at Tripler Army Medical Center. As of July 24, the CDC has reported 1,424 cases for Hawaii. As of January 20, 2010, Hawaii has reported 13 confirmed deaths due to A/H1N1 influenza.[http://www.khon2.com/news/local/story/Hawaii-H1N1-Death-Toll-Rises-to-13/E1Z7wBc-dki6fNoWVU4BxA.cspx Hawaii H1N1 Death Toll Rises to 13 | KHON2 Hawaii's News Leader] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110616211842/http://www.khon2.com/news/local/story/Hawaii-H1N1-Death-Toll-Rises-to-13/E1Z7wBc-dki6fNoWVU4BxA.cspx |date=June 16, 2011 }} ==Idaho== [[File:BoiseH1N1VaccinationClinic5578.JPG|thumb|widthpx| High-risk groups line up on October 24, 2009 at a defunct [[Kmart]] for the first H1N1 vaccines publicly available in Boise, Idaho.]] On May 3, 2009, the CDC confirmed the state's first H1N1 infection, that of a [[Kootenai County]] woman in her 60s. On September 29, 2009, The Idaho Department of Health and Welfare confirmed that a [[Canyon County]] man in his 50s, with an already existing medical condition, died from the H1N1 virus, by which time 488 cases had been confirmed. By late October the H1N1 vaccine was available for high-risk groups for whom H&W set up clinics and distribution centers in, among other places, defunct big box stores.[http://www.ktvb.com/community/blogs/maggie-omara/H1N1-vaccine-shortage.html H1N1 vaccine shortage | Idaho News from KTVB.COM | Boise news, Idaho weather, sports, traffic & events | Maggie O'Mara: Behind the Scenes] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606161429/http://www.ktvb.com/community/blogs/maggie-omara/H1N1-vaccine-shortage.html |date=June 6, 2011 }}[https://web.archive.org/web/20110719120224/http://www.mtexpress.com/index2.php?ID=2005128179 Idaho Mountain Express: First H1N1 vaccine arrives in Idaho – October 7, 2009][http://www.healthandwelfare.idaho.gov/AboutUs/Newsroom/tabid/130/ctl/ArticleView/mid/3061/articleId/1502/font-size2Idaho-2009-H1N1-Weekly-Update-October-28.aspx Idaho 2009 H1N1 Weekly Update: October 28 > Idaho Department of Health and Welfare > Newsroom] By December 10, 2009, there had been 812 laboratory-confirmed cases, 381 influenza-related hospitalizations (most of them of children under ten), and 18 deaths. Furthermore, the vaccine became readily available to the general public under 65.[http://www.idahostatesman.com/1453/story/1004834.html Idaho's H1N1 death toll rises to 18 | Health & Fitness | Idaho Statesman] By December 30, 2009 the state had 824 laboratory-confirmed cases since September 1, and the virus had contributed to the deaths of 20 people.{{cite web | url=https://archive.is/20140830013954/http://www.idahostatesman.com/531/story/1025288.html | title=Boise, Meridian, Nampa, Caldwell news by Idaho Statesman}} By January 23, 2010 despite at least 23 Idaho deaths and 385 hospitalizations and the widespread availability of the H1N1 vaccine, only 10% to 15% of the populace of [[Ada County]] had been inoculated, prompting concern amongst public health officials.[http://www.idahostatesman.com/newsupdates/story/1052570.html H1N1 vaccines plentiful, but takers few | Your Health | Idaho Statesman] ==Illinois== {{Update|section|date=January 2010}} The state's first probable case of swine flu was reported on Wednesday, April 29. An elementary school in Chicago's Rogers Park neighborhood, on the city's Far North Side, was closed because a 12-year-old student was presumed to have the disease. The student reportedly was recovering at home.{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/30471324 |title=1 Probable Case of Swine Flu Closes Rogers Park School |publisher=MSNBC |accessdate=April 29, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090502091452/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/30471324 |archivedate=May 2, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} By April 30, over 40 probable cases had been identified by state and local health officials. In addition to 16 cases in the city of Chicago, and 11 in surrounding [[Cook County, Illinois|Cook County]], cases were reported in [[Kane County, Illinois|Kane]], [[Lake County, Illinois|Lake]], [[DuPage County, Illinois|DuPage]], [[McHenry County, Illinois|McHenry]], and [[Will County, Illinois|Will]] counties. Several schools in the affected areas were temporarily closed. Many other flu cases happened during or even before the launch of the alert were then confirmed, principally in the urban area of Chicago.{{cite news|url=http://www.suntimes.com/lifestyles/health/1552344,swine-flu-illinois-update-cps-chicago-043009.article |title=More than 40 probable swine flu cases reported in Illinois |work=Chicago Sun-Times |date=April 30, 2009 |accessdate=May 1, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090502235844/http://www.suntimes.com/lifestyles/health/1552344%2Cswine-flu-illinois-update-cps-chicago-043009.article |archivedate=May 2, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }} By May 20, the following 17 counties had confirmed cases: [[Boone County, Illinois|Boone]], [[Cook County, Illinois|Cook]], [[DeKalb County, Illinois|DeKalb]], [[DuPage County, Illinois|DuPage]], [[Franklin County, Illinois|Franklin]], [[Kane County, Illinois|Kane]], [[Kankakee County, Illinois|Kankakee]], [[Kendall County, Illinois|Kendall]], [[Knox County, Illinois|Knox]], [[Lake County, Illinois|Lake]], [[McDonough County, Illinois|McDonough]], [[McHenry County, Illinois|McHenry]], [[Ogle County, Illinois|Ogle]], [[Sangamon County, Illinois|Sangamon]], [[Will County, Illinois|Will]], [[Williamson County, Illinois|Williamson]], and [[Winnebago County, Illinois|Winnebago]]. Total confirmed cases in Illinois were 794, up from 707 the previous day.{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/chi-ap-il-swineflu-illinois,0,3135647.story |accessdate=May 20, 2009 |work=Chicago Tribune |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090429093731/http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/chi-ap-il-swineflu-illinois%2C0%2C3135647.story |archivedate=April 29, 2009 |deadurl=no |title=Topic Galleries |df=mdy-all }} Cases in Illinois throughout May 2009 continued to climb and by May 31, 2009 the published CDC numbers had reached 1002 confirmed cases with 2 deaths. A third confirmed death – the first outside of the Chicago metropolitan area – was reported by state health authorities on May 28, 2009 but this was not reflected in the CDC official numbers by the end of the month.{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagobreakingnews.com/2009/05/3rd-illinois-death-from-swine-flu.html|title=3rd Swine Flu Death in Illinois|publisher=ChicagoBreakingNews.com|date=May 31, 2009| accessdate=February 5, 2010 }} A total of 3,366 cases and 17 deaths have been confirmed in Illinois as of July 24. As of January 2010, a total of 2931 hospitalizations due to confirmed A/H1N1 infection and a total of 97 confirmed deaths due to H1N1 have been reported in Illinois.[http://www.idph.state.il.us/h1n1_flu/sf_statistics.htm H1N1 Flu – Statistics] ==Indiana== On April 28, an unidentified [[University of Notre Dame|Notre Dame]] student was confirmed as the first case of swine flu in this state. The patient had not recently traveled to Mexico or been in contact with anyone who has traveled to Mexico. The student was in voluntarily quarantine, and was doing well, according to Judy Monroe, Indiana's state health commissioner.{{cite web|url=http://www.fox59.com/pages/landing_news/?1-Sample-in-Indiana-for-Swine-Flu-Confir=1&blockID=277690&feedID=2319 |title=1 Sample in Indiana Confirmed for Swine Flu |publisher=Fox59.com |accessdate=April 28, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Two other cases in the state which occurred in two Indianapolis elementary schools were confirmed by the CDC shortly thereafter.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetimesonline.com/articles/2009/05/01/updates/breaking_news/doc49fb17febfa4a578231256.txt|title=Two Indianapolis schools closed over flu cases|work=The Times |location=UK|accessdate=May 2, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090504140637/http://www.thetimesonline.com/articles/2009/05/01/updates/breaking_news/doc49fb17febfa4a578231256.txt| archivedate= May 4, 2009 | deadurl= no}} Additional cases later surfaced in the counties of Hendricks, Lake, Marion, Putnam, St. Joseph, and Tippecanoe. On July 10, 2009, a young teenager died of Swine Flu, this was the first death in Indiana because of this disease.{{cite web|url=http://www.in.gov/portal/news_events/38748.htm|title=State Confirms 12 Additional cases of Novel H1N1 flu|publisher=dhs.in.gov|accessdate=May 12, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090517173542/http://www.in.gov/portal/news_events/38748.htm| archivedate= May 17, 2009 | deadurl= no}} As of July 24, the CDC has reported 291 cases of swine flu. As of February 2010, there have been at least 38 confirmed deaths due to A/H1N1 infection. Also, since September 1, there have been at least 468 confirmed cases of H1N1 in Indiana.http://www.in.gov/flu/files/FluReportWeek5.pdf ==Iowa== On April 29, two probable case of swine flu were reported in [[Des Moines County]] and [[Clinton County, Iowa|Clinton County]]. One was a woman from California, the other one was a man from [[Mexico]]. On May 3, another case was found in [[Marshall County, Iowa|Marshall County]] causing schools to close. On the week of February 28, 2009, a three-year-old caught the swine flu due to close contact with ill pigs, but not the same dangerous strain that came from Mexico. In early May, cases climbed up to 43. A few were in [[Polk County, Iowa|Polk County]], where [[Des Moines]] is.{{cite web|last=Winn |first=Pete |title=CDC: Iowa Boy Caught Swine Flu from Pigs in February—But Not Same Dangerous Strain That's Come from Mexico |publisher=[[Cybercast News Service]] |date=April 30, 2009 |url=http://www.cnsnews.com/public/content/article.aspx?RsrcID=47394 |accessdate=May 3, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090502024101/http://www.cnsnews.com/public/Content/Article.aspx?rsrcid=47394 |archivedate=May 2, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} As of July 24, 165 cases have been reported by the CDC. In Iowa City's [[Iowa City High School]], there were over 400 students absent on Oct. 7 with suspected H1N1. The recent homecoming dance is credited with causing this. The school's 9-day absence limit is also believed to have influenced this, restricting sick students from going home if they have already been absent 9 days. The school has refused to close despite protests from parents, teachers and students alike. On October 9, 32% of all students were absent out of over 1,600. The school has continued to stay open despite advisement by the Johnson County Health Department even as more and more of the student population falls ill. There are serious concerns of students passing along the virus to the community, creating a large local outbreak. As of October 15 the school is still open.[http://www.press-citizen.com/article/20091007/NEWS01/91007005/1079] ==Kansas== Health officials in Kansas announced April 25 that two new cases of swine flu had been confirmed in [[Dickinson County, Kansas|Dickinson County]], after both were isolated. The week prior, one patient had traveled to Mexico by plane to attend a professional conference; both he and his wife experienced minor influenza symptoms.{{cite web|url=http://www.kansas.com/localnews/story/787413.html |title=Two swine flu cases confirmed in Dickinson County |publisher=[[The Wichita Eagle]] |date=April 25, 2009 |accessdate=April 25, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503195215/http://www.kansas.com/localnews/story/787413.html |archivedate=May 3, 2009 |deadurl=yes }}{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jDrS0zyM9U2lh372d7r1FMjLVHrAD97POK800 |title=2 swine flus in Kan., US total 11; 8 likely in NY |agency=Associated Press |author=Dobnik, Verena |date=April 25, 2009 |accessdate=April 25, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090520071905/https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jDrS0zyM9U2lh372d7r1FMjLVHrAD97POK800 |archivedate=May 20, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} As of July 24, 2009 there were 213 confirmed cases of swine flu in Kansas, 101 in adults and 112 in children. However, in [[Wyandotte County, Kansas|Wyandotte]] and [[Johnson County, Kansas|Johnson]] counties the state had instructed that only hospitalized patients needed to be tested so the numbers were quite possibly higher.[https://www.webcitation.org/5kkob397t?url=http://www.kdheks.gov/H1N1/ Kansas Health Department website, accessed June 16, 2009] By June 30, 2009 there were 129 confirmed swine flu cases in Kansas.[https://www.webcitation.org/5kkob397t?url=http://www.kdheks.gov/H1N1/ Kansas Health Department website, accessed June 30, 2009] As of January 9,26 people have died of infection with H1N1, including a healthy 52-year-old man with no underlying health problems that would place him at higher risk for A/H1N1 infection.also, a 6-year-old Kansas boy and 27-year-old Kansas woman, have also died from infection with H1N1, reinforcing the fact that young, healthy people can die from infection with A/H1N1, and that vaccination is recommended even for those without preexisting medical problems. ==Kentucky== A [[Warren County, Kentucky|Warren County]] woman who had recently visited Mexico tested positive for the virus April 30. After returning to Kentucky from Mexico, she traveled to Georgia where she was hospitalized. Health officials from both states announced this as the first confirmed case in their states, however the CDC listed the case in Kentucky. In Jefferson County, Meyzeek Middle school has three cases of H1N1 influenza. This initially started from a staff member, but spread to students. ==Louisiana== As of July 21, there are a total of 232 swine flu cases confirmed by The Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals.{{cite web|url=http://www.dhh.louisiana.gov/offices/default-145.asp?ID=145 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jpHH98UM?url=http://www.dhh.louisiana.gov/offices/default-145.asp?ID=145 |archivedate=September 16, 2009 |title=H1N1 Flu (Swine Flu) |publisher=The Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals |date=May 27, 2009 |accessdate=May 28, 2009 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} Up from 114 reported on May 28. As of January 2010, 1,973 confirmed cases of H1N1 have been reported, and 43 H1N1 deaths have been confirmed, in Louisiana.[http://www.flula.com Fight The Flu LA] ==Maine== On April 29, three cases of H1N1 (swine flu) were confirmed in [[Maine]], according to the Maine Center for Disease Control.{{cite press release|title=H1N1 (Swine Flu) Probable Cases Confirmed in Maine |url=http://www.maine.gov/tools/whatsnew/index.php?topic=DHS+Press+Releases&id=71798&v=cdc_article |archivedate=January 28, 2016 |publisher=Maine CDC |date=April 29, 2009 |accessdate=April 30, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160128114616/http://www.maine.gov/tools/whatsnew/index.php?topic=DHS%2BPress%2BReleases&id=71798&v=cdc_article |df= }} {{cbignore|bot=medic|reason=plussign|date=May 2017}} The three adults, two from [[Kennebec County, Maine|Kennebec County]] and one from [[York County, Maine|York County]], were reported to be recovering at home. Dr. Dora Anne Mills, former director of Maine CDC, said on April 28 that at least 12 suspected cases were being tested.{{cite news|url=http://www.fosters.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20090428/GJNEWS_01/904289833 |title=N.H., Maine residents under quarantine, being tested for swine flu |last=Cook |first=Robert |date=April 28, 2009 |publisher=Geo. J. Foster Company |accessdate=April 28, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090504020809/http://www.fosters.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20090428%2FGJNEWS_01%2F904289833 |archivedate=May 4, 2009 |deadurl=no |df=mdy-all }} Late on April 29, Maine Governor [[John Baldacci]] declared a "civil emergency" and ordered a school and daycare facility in York County to close for seven days.{{cite web|url=http://pressherald.mainetoday.com/newsupdate.php?updates/flu-threat-closes-two-york-county-schools |title=Maine Daily News – Portland Maine News | Portland Press Herald / Maine Sunday Telegram |publisher=Pressherald.mainetoday.com |date=April 23, 2009 |accessdate=April 30, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090501054310/http://pressherald.mainetoday.com/newsupdate.php?updates%2Fflu-threat-closes-two-york-county-schools |archivedate=May 1, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }} As of July 22, there have been 282 cases confirmed throughout Maine. As of November 26, 1562 confirmed cases, 97 hospitalized cases, and 9 deaths have been reported in Maine. Also, 172 schools have reported outbreaks of [[H1N1]] since May, according to Dr. Dora Anne Mills and the Maine CDC. On December 2, 2009, it was announced that H1N1 has killed 2 more Mainers, bringing the death toll to 11. As of December 17, 2009, the Maine CDC states that although 203 Mainers have now been hospitalized and the death toll has risen to 17 in Maine, H1N1 flu activity is decreasing in Maine, and vaccine availability is increasing rapidly, so all Mainers can now get the vaccine. Dr. Dora Anne Mills reminded Mainers that 150 Mainers die every year from regular [[influenza]]. As of December 24, 2009, Maine was one of the only 7 states reporting widespread influenza activity, though Maine's influenza activity was declining as well. As of January 7, 2010, H1N1 activity has decreased from widespread to regional for the first time since October 17, 2009. Although H1N1 activity in Maine has declined for the time being, H1N1 continues to circulate in Maine. H1N1 could return later this year, so it is still very important to get vaccinated against A/H1N1 influenza, Dr. Dora Anne Mills says. So far, 18 deaths, 225 hospitalizations, and 2220 cases have been confirmed. As of January 14, the CDC states just 3 more patients required hospital care due to H1N1 disease, no new deaths occurred, and only 6 new cases were confirmed. However, one outbreak in a long term care facility was confirmed. As of January 28, H1N1 activity has decreased significantly, with the CDC classifying current influenza activity as sporadic. No new cases of A/H1N1 influenza were confirmed between January 21 and January 28.[http://www.maine.gov/dhhs/boh/maineflu/ Influenza: Maine CDC – Maine DHHS] However, as of February 4, the Maine CDC reports that influenza activity has increased enough for the state to be again classified as having regional influenza activity, and that one person had died of confirmed A/H1N1 infection over the previous week, bringing the number of confirmed deaths from A/H1N1 to 19 in the state.http://www.maine.gov/tools/whatsnew/attach.php?id=91047&an=1 ==Maryland== By May 1, 2009, eleven probable cases had been identified in Maryland, in [[Anne Arundel County, Maryland|Anne Arundel]], [[Baltimore County, Maryland|Baltimore]], [[Charles County, Maryland|Charles]], [[Prince George's County, Maryland|Prince George's]], and [[Montgomery County, Maryland|Montgomery]] Counties.{{cite web|url=http://www.governor.maryland.gov/pressreleases/090501b.asp |title=Governor Martin O'Malley Declares Public Health Emergency |date=May 1, 2009 |publisher=Office of Governor Martin O'Malley |accessdate=May 1, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503014800/http://www.governor.maryland.gov/pressreleases/090501b.asp |archivedate=May 3, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} One of these cases, that of a high school student in [[Rockville, Maryland|Rockville]], resulted in the closing of [[Rockville High School (Maryland)|Rockville High School]], the first Maryland school closing due to the outbreak. On May 1, three other schools in the state were closed.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/05/01/AR2009050100981.html|title=Probable Case of Swine Flu Closes Rockville High School|work=The Washington Post|date=May 1, 2009|accessdate=May 1, 2009 | first1=Daniel | last1=de Vise | first2=David A. | last2=Fahrenthold}} As of May 5, Rockville High School has reopened. Takoma Park Middle School also began to take action due to a student catching swine flu. Four of Maryland's probable cases were confirmed on May 4, including two adults and one child in [[Baltimore County, Maryland|Baltimore County]] as well as one young child in [[Anne Arundel County, Maryland|Anne Arundel county]].{{cite news |title=CDC confirms four cases of swine flu in Md. |url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/health/bal-swine-flu-maryland-0504,0,3562022.story |newspaper=Baltimore Sun |date=May 4, 2009 |accessdate=May 4, 2009}} There are 4 cases of swine flu in Worcester County Public Schools in Maryland. In Washington County in Northeast Maryland there were many cases of the Swine Flu almost causing the closing of four Schools. As of Fall 2009, there have been 954 confirmed cases in Maryland. In late September 2009 a 13-year-old Baltimore resident became the first minor to die from swine flu in Maryland. As of December 2, [[oseltamivir]]-resistant [[H1N1]] was confirmed in Maryland. As of January 12, 2010, 43 confirmed deaths from H1N1 have been reported, and at least 969 patients have been hospitalized with A/H1N1 virus infection in Maryland.[http://www.dhmh.state.md.us/swineflu/ Department of Health and Mental Hygiene Seasonal Influenza Preparedness Guide] ==Massachusetts== [[File:Massachusetts H1N1 Flu Map By County.PNG|thumb|right|As of 11:00 [[Eastern Time Zone|EDT]], June 6, 2009:
{{legend|#000000|Death(s) confirmed}}{{legend|#cd3412|Case(s) confirmed}}{{legend|#eaa912|Case(s) unconfirmed (both suspected and probable cases)}}]] There are 1,398 confirmed cases in [[Massachusetts]], 172 of which have led to hospitalizations. The first death from swine flu in Massachusetts occurred on June 14, 2009 when a 30-year-old Boston woman died.{{cite news | url = http://www.boston.com/news/local/breaking_news/2009/06/state_reports_f.html | work=The Boston Globe | title=State reports first swine flu death | date=June 15, 2009| accessdate=February 5, 2010 }} Eleven deaths have been confirmed as being caused by the H1N1 virus in total. ===By county=== *'''Barnstable County''' **A member of the [[United States Coast Guard|US Coast Guard]] stationed on [[Cape Cod]], acquired the virus while training in California, but reportedly recovered.{{cite web|url=http://www.wbz.com/Six-confirmed-cases-of-swine-flu-in-Massachusetts/4316823 |title=Six confirmed cases of swine flu in Massachusetts |publisher=WBZ Newsradio 1030 |date=May 2, 2009 |accessdate=May 2, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090505053030/http://www.wbz.com/Six-confirmed-cases-of-swine-flu-in-Massachusetts/4316823 |archivedate=May 5, 2009 |deadurl=yes }}{{cite web|url=http://www.thebostonchannel.com/news/19352149/detail.html |title=2 More Students 'Probable' Cases Of H1N1 |publisher=WCVB TV/DT Boston 5 |date=May 2, 2009 |accessdate=May 2, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090506045821/http://www.thebostonchannel.com/news/19352149/detail.html |archivedate=May 6, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} *'''Bristol County''' **The Health Agent for the town of [[Easton, Massachusetts|Easton]] stated that there are "a couple of suspected cases in town."{{cite web |url=http://www.wickedlocal.com/easton/news/x1393561254/As-swine-flu-spreads-in-Mass-Easton-officials-watchful |title=As swine flu spreads in Mass., Easton officials watchful|publisher=Wicked Local Easton |date= May 5, 2009 |accessdate=May 6, 2009}} **The Mass. Dept. of Public Health announced that they had 1 confirmed case of the virus in the city of Fall River in southeastern Massachusetts.{{cite news|url=http://www.turnto10.com/jar/news/local/article/confrimed_case_of_swine_flu_in_fall_river/13142/ |title=Health officials confirm swine flu case in Fall River |publisher=turnto10.com – NBC 10 News |date=May 4, 2009 |accessdate=May 5, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090507192315/http://www.turnto10.com/jar/news/local/article/confrimed_case_of_swine_flu_in_fall_river/13142/ |archivedate=May 7, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} *'''Dukes County''' **Martha's Vineyard Hospital treated five confirmed cases of H1N1, two of which required hospitalization.{{cite web|url=http://www.mvtimes.com/marthas-vineyard/news/2009/06/25/news-briefs.php?page=4 |title=Hospital confirms swine flu cases now total five |accessdate=July 6, 2009 |date=June 25, 2009 |publisher=The Martha's Vineyard Times |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927121315/http://www.mvtimes.com/marthas-vineyard/news/2009/06/25/news-briefs.php?page=4 |archivedate=September 27, 2011 }} *'''Franklin County''' **There is at least 1 confirmed case reported in the county.{{cite web|url=http://www.thebostonchannel.com/mostpopular/19384080/detail.html |title=11 More H1N1 Cases Confirmed In Mass |publisher=WCVB 5 |date=May 6, 2009 |accessdate=May 6, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222052414/http://www.thebostonchannel.com/mostpopular/19384080/detail.html |archivedate=February 22, 2012 }} *'''Hampshire County''' **Two students at [[Amherst College]] in Amherst had confirmed cases of the virus and 13 other students are 'suspected' cases. All 15 students are being isolated on campus. A third student at the school contracted the H1N1 virus.{{cite news |title=Swine flu 3rd case in Amherst |publisher=The Republican |url=http://www.masslive.com/hampfrank/republican/index.ssf?/base/news-19/1241594163142390.xml&coll=1 |date=May 6, 2009 |accessdate=May 6, 2009}} Also, there has been 1 'suspected' case each at [[Mount Holyoke College]] (in [[South Hadley, Massachusetts|South Hadley]]) and [[Smith College]] (in [[Northampton, Massachusetts|Northampton]]).{{cite news|title=CDC confirms first two western Mass. swine flu cases at Amherst College |publisher=Daily Collegian |url=http://www.dailycollegian.com/news/cdc-confirms-first-two-western-mass-swine-flu-cases-at-amherst-college-1.1744217 |date=May 5, 2009 |accessdate=May 5, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} *'''Middlesex County''' **The Massachusetts Department of Public Health informed the [[Ashland, Massachusetts|Ashland]] school superintendent that two Ashland High School students have "probable" cases of H1N1 flu.{{cite web|url=http://www.wickedlocal.com/ashland/news/lifestyle/health/x342377586/2-Ashland-students-could-have-swine-flu-high-school-closed-for-weekend |title=2 Ashland students could have swine flu; high school closed for weekend |publisher=Wicked Local Ashland |date=May 2, 2009 |accessdate=May 2, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090504010931/http://www.wickedlocal.com/ashland/news/lifestyle/health/x342377586/2-Ashland-students-could-have-swine-flu-high-school-closed-for-weekend |archivedate=May 4, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} **The CDC confirmed that an elementary school student in Chelmsford tested positive for acquiring the virus.{{cite web |url=http://www.wickedlocal.com/chelmsford/news/x1194156689/Swine-flu-case-confirmed-in-Chelmsford |title=Updated: Swine flu case confirmed in Chelmsford |publisher=Wicked Local Chelmsford |date= May 5, 2009 |accessdate=May 7, 2009}} **In [[Cambridge, Massachusetts|Cambridge]], there are 2 students (at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]) that are "probable" cases of having acquired the virus.{{cite web |url=http://tech.mit.edu/V129/N24/swineflu.html |title=MIT student spread swine flu to dental school at Harvard U |publisher=The Tech |date= May 5, 2009 |accessdate=May 5, 2009}} **Eight residents of [[Framingham, Massachusetts|Framingham]] are being tested for being "probable" cases. **The Lincoln Public Schools Superintendent had confirmed a Lincoln middle school student been diagnosed with the H1N1 virus.{{cite news|url=http://www.wickedlocal.com/lincoln/news/x342377591/Swine-flu-case-reported-in-Lincoln |title=Swine flu case reported in Lincoln |publisher=Wicked Local Lincoln |date=May 2, 2009 |accessdate=May 2, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090505133151/http://www.wickedlocal.com/lincoln/news/x342377591/Swine-flu-case-reported-in-Lincoln |archivedate=May 5, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} **Two middle school students in Lowell have tested positive for swine flu as of April 29, 2009. The two had gone on a family trip to Mexico, and became mildly sick on returning home. The local health department said that the boys had not returned to school since coming back from Mexico, and there were no concerns that the illness had been spread.{{cite news|title=Lowell brothers recovering from swine flu |publisher=NBC WHDH |url=http://www1.whdh.com/news/articles/local/BO111825/ |date=April 29, 2009 |accessdate=April 30, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503160652/http://www3.whdh.com/news/articles/local/BO111825/ |archivedate=May 3, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} **In [[Tyngsborough, Massachusetts|Tyngsboro]], there
