|publisher=WBZ |url=http://wbztv.com/local/swine.flu.massachusetts.2.1001423.html |date=May 5, 2009 |accessdate=May 5, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Later, it was reported that 3 of the 9 reported cases of influenza at the school, resulted positive for the H1N1 virus.{{cite news |title=Three cases confirmed as swine flu |publisher=The Harvard Crimson |url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article.aspx?ref=528130 |date=May 5, 2009 |accessdate=May 6, 2009}} **On May 1, 2009, a [[United Airlines]] Flight 903 from [[Munich, Germany|Munich]] to Washington D.C., was diverted to [[Logan International Airport]] in Boston. A 53-year-old passenger complained of flu-like symptoms, that led him to be admitted to [[Massachusetts General Hospital]].{{cite news |url=http://www.myfoxboston.com/dpp/health/swine_flu/Second_passenger_sick_on_Logan_flight_050209 |title=Second passenger sick on Logan flight |publisher=my Fox Boston – Fox 25 News|date= May 2, 2009 |accessdate=May 2, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090503204351/http://www.myfoxboston.com/dpp/health/swine_flu/Second_passenger_sick_on_Logan_flight_050209| archivedate= May 3, 2009 | deadurl= yes}} **A male passenger in his 40's complained of flu-like symptoms upon landing at Logan International Airport in Boston May 2, 2009. He was flying aboard [[American Airlines]] Flight 155, from London to Boston, that had originated from [[Malaysia]]. He, too, was admitted to Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. **The [[Boston University]] [[Goldman School of Dental Medicine]] reported a single resident that has a confirmed case of the virus. They claim that he has had no contact with anybody on the school's main campus, and those he has been in contact with have been notified.{{cite web|url=http://www.bu.edu/today/2009/05/05/flu-numbers-climb-bit-fear-lessens-lot |title=Flu numbers climb a bit, fear lessens a lot |publisher=BU Today |date=May 6, 2009 |accessdate=May 6, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} **Both [[Boston Latin School|Boston Latin]], where 250 called in sick, and [[the Winsor School]], where 34 called in sick, and were closed. *'''Worcester County''' **There is at least 1 confirmed case reported in the county. *'' '''Other''' '' **In [[Spencer, Massachusetts|Spencer]], two students who also had recently returned from Mexico were tested for possible swine flu infection. The results of those tests were both negative.{{cite news|title=Sick Spencer students don't have swine flu |publisher=WBZ CBS |url=http://wbztv.com/local/swine.flu.spencer.2.997589.html |date=April 29, 2009 |accessdate=April 30, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503162907/http://wbztv.com/local/swine.flu.spencer.2.997589.html |archivedate=May 3, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} ==Michigan== [[File:Michigan H1N1 Flu Map By County.svg|thumb|right|As of 17:00 [[Eastern Time Zone|EDT]], June 24, 2009:
{{legend|#000000|Death(s) confirmed}}{{legend|#cd3412|Case(s) confirmed}}]] On April 29, a 34-year-old woman from [[Livingston County, Michigan|Livingston County]] was Michigan's first reported case of swine flu.{{cite web|url=http://www.clickondetroit.com/news/19328554/detail.html |title=Local Schools Close Amid Virus Fears |date=May 1, 2009 |publisher=ClickOnDetroit |accessdate=May 1, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090501232813/http://www.clickondetroit.com/news/19328554/detail.html |archivedate=May 1, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} On April 30, another 34-year-old woman from [[Ottawa County, Michigan|Ottawa County]] was confirmed as Michigan's second case. As of June 13, Michigan reports 655 confirmed flu cases, and as of July 23, nine deaths. The health department has since stopped reporting cases but continues to update deaths.{{cite web|url=http://www.michigan.gov/mdch/0,1607,7-132-2940_2955_22779_53388-213600--,00.html |title=MDCH – Influenza A (H1N1) |date=July 20, 2009 |accessdate=July 20, 2009 |publisher=State of Michigan |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090722184554/http://www.michigan.gov/mdch/0%2C1607%2C7-132-2940_2955_22779_53388-213600--%2C00.html |archivedate=July 22, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }} The first death in Michigan was of a 53-year-old woman who lived in [[Warren, Michigan|Warren]] and had other under-lying health problems.''Detroit News'', June 4, 2009, p. 4A The second Michigan death occurred in [[Roscommon County, Michigan|Roscommon County]]. As of August 10, 2009, ten deaths have been reported in Michigan due to the H1N1 virus. Michigan has stopped keeping a running tally of confirmed cases. On October 28, 2009 157 schools in Michigan were closed due to the swine flu.''Detroit News'', October 29, 2009, p. 4A ==Minnesota== On April 30, 2009, the Minnesota Department of Health announced that the first case of "H1N1 novel influenza virus" in the state was confirmed by the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]]. The infected individual is an unidentified resident of [[Cold Spring, Minnesota|Cold Spring]], Minnesota. Two schools in the affected city will remain closed until May 6, 2009.{{cite web |last=Lerner |first1=Mara |last2=Marcotty |first2=Josephine |last3=von Sternberg |first3=Bob |date=April 30, 2009 |title=Test confirms state's 1st case of swine flu |url=http://www.startribune.com/local/44046077.html |newspaper=[[Star Tribune]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503192816/http://www.startribune.com/local/44046077.html |archivedate=May 3, 2009 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=April 30, 2009}} On May 4, 2009 the second case of H1N1 was confirmed in Minnesota by the Minnesota Department of Health.{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}} The case was reported in a teen boy attending a Minneapolis Public School. A Minneapolis five-year-old girl had succumbed to the flu during the week of June 8.[http://www.startribune.com/lifestyle/health/48080847.html?elr=KArksc8P:Pc:U0ckkD:aEyKUiD3aPc:_Yyc:aUU Minneapolis girl with swine flu dies | StarTribune.com] As of July 23, 684 cases and three deaths have been reported. As of January 13,2 more people died of confirmed A/H1N1 influenza, increasing the number of confirmed deathsfrom H1N1 to 55 in the state.However, H1N1 influenza activity is currently low in Minnesota, with only one school outbreak reported in the first week of 2010.[http://www.startribune.com StarTribune.com: News, weather, sports from Minneapolis, St. Paul and Minnesota] ==Missouri== [[File:H1N1 Missouri map by county.svg|thumb|({{cite web |url=http://www.dhss.mo.gov/BT_Response/_SwineFlu09.html |title=Latest H1N1 Influenza Information |author= |date=January 22, 2010 |publisher=Missouri Department of Health and Senior Services |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100122074343/http://www.dhss.mo.gov/BT_Response/_SwineFlu09.html |archivedate=January 22, 2010 |accessdate=March 7, 2013 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.dhss.mo.gov/Influenza/Reports.html |title=Data & Statistical Reports |author= |date=June 8, 2010 |publisher=Missouri Department of Health and Senior Services |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100608233826/http://www.dhss.mo.gov/Influenza/Reports.html |archivedate=June 8, 2010 |accessdate=March 7, 2013 }})
{{legend|#000000|Death(s) confirmed}} {{legend|#ff0000|Case(s) confirmed}} {{legend|#ff8800|Unconfirmed cases from other sources}}]] In [[Missouri]], [[Jay Nixon|Gov. Jay Nixon]] announced in a written statement that a probable case had been discovered in a [[Platte County, Missouri|Platte County]] man, and that a sample had been sent to the CDC for confirmation.{{cite web |url=http://www.kshb.com/dpp/news/local_news/Probable-Swine-Flu-Case-in-Platte-County |title=Probable Swine Flu Case in Platte County |date=April 29, 2009 |accessdate=April 29, 2009 |publisher=NBC Action News |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503015905/http://www.nbcactionnews.com/news/local/story/Probable-Swine-Flu-Case-in-Platte-County/VQpJBQWsdUC36GfeXgiz3Q.cspx |archivedate=May 3, 2009 |deadurl=yes }}{{cite news |url=http://www.chicagobreakingnews.com/2009/04/could-swine-flu-cause-a-n-side-school-to-close.html|title=Probable swine flu closes Rogers Park school|date=April 29, 2009|publisher=Chicago BreakingNews Center|accessdate=April 29, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090502100856/http://www.chicagobreakingnews.com/2009/04/could-swine-flu-cause-a-n-side-school-to-close.html| archivedate= May 2, 2009 | deadurl= yes}} As of May 8, 2009, the Missouri Department of Health and Senior Services (DHSS) reported 10 confirmed and 4 probable cases of swine flu.{{cite web|url=http://www.dhss.mo.gov/BT_Response/_SwineFlu09.html |title=Latest Swine Influenza Information |publisher=Dhss.mo.gov |accessdate=May 19, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090520040303/http://www.dhss.mo.gov/BT_Response/_SwineFlu09.html |archivedate=May 20, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} On May 19, 2009, a St. Louis County man became the first death in Missouri due to the Swine Flu.{{cite web|url=http://www.fox2now.com/ktvi-st-louis-swine-flu-death-051909,0,209223.story |title=St. Louis Man With Swine Flu Dies |publisher=KTVI-TV |date=May 19, 2009 |accessdate=May 19, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090521194021/http://www.fox2now.com/ktvi-st-louis-swine-flu-death-051909%2C0%2C209223.story |archivedate=May 21, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }} On May 21, 2009, St. Louis Public School District announced one of its students had the Swine Flu but has not been in class since May 15.{{cite web|url=http://www.ksdk.com/news/local/story.aspx?storyid=175948&catid=3 |title=St. Louis Public School District reports first swine flu case | publisher=KSDK-TV |date=May 21, 2009 |accessdate=May 21, 2009}} In St. Charles Missouri it was also found that a student from St. Charles High School who traveled to Mexico City was found infected with swine flu. The student who just came back from Mexico City was in school for a week than kicked out and brought back.{{Citation needed|date=June 2009}} On June 11, 2009, a teenager from New Bloomfield (11 miles north of the [[Jefferson City, Missouri|Jefferson City]]) in [[Callaway County, Missouri|Callaway County]] became the 50th confirmed case of H1N1 in Missouri.{{cite news |title=New Bloomfield has 1 confirmed, 3 suspected cases of H1N1 |url=http://www.connectmidmissouri.com/news/news_story.aspx?id=312080 |publisher=KRGC-TV |date=June 12, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090623041527/http://www.connectmidmissouri.com/news/news_story.aspx?id=312080 |archivedate= June 23, 2009 |accessdate=June 13, 2009}} On June 20, 2009, about 20 to 30 campers at a [[Lake of the Ozarks]] summer camp in [[Morgan County, Missouri|Morgan County]] reported having mild flu-like symptoms, of which two cases were confirmed to be H1N1. The camp was closed down for a week.{{cite web|url=http://www.stltoday.com/stltoday/news/stories.nsf/sciencemedicine/story/EAF1BA44C5AE29FD862575DE005909C9?OpenDocument |title=Campers, staff heading home after swine flu threat |publisher=St. Louis Post-Dispatch |date=June 23, 2009 |accessdate=June 25, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090626001845/http://www.stltoday.com/stltoday/news/stories.nsf/sciencemedicine/story/EAF1BA44C5AE29FD862575DE005909C9?OpenDocument |archivedate=June 26, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} Another summer camp in [[Stone County, Missouri|Stone County]] near [[Branson, Missouri|Branson]] reported at least 15 campers who have tested positive for the flu in preliminary tests on June 24.{{cite web|url=http://www.stltoday.com/stltoday/news/stories.nsf/sciencemedicine/story/2B5A7631B557B4E7862575DF005D3163?OpenDocument |title=Flu outbreak hits second Missouri summer camp |publisher=St. Louis Post-Dispatch |date=June 24, 2009 |accessdate=June 25, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090627074332/http://www.stltoday.com/stltoday/news/stories.nsf/sciencemedicine/story/2B5A7631B557B4E7862575DF005D3163?OpenDocument |archivedate=June 27, 2009 |deadurl=yes }}{{cite web|url=http://www.kansascity.com/115/story/1276062.html |title=Flu hits second summer camp in Missouri |publisher=Kansas City Star |date=June 24, 2009 |accessdate=June 25, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090629040343/http://www.kansascity.com/115/story/1276062.html |archivedate=June 29, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} The preliminary results were possibly sent to a lab in neighboring [[Taney County, Missouri|Taney County]] as local reporters attempted to dispute or deny that ''any'' flu cases were reported in Taney County by going as far as to cite that the Taney County Health Department found zero cases of the flu.{{cite web|url=http://www.ozarksentinel.com/news/2009/06/branson-area-camp-reports-flu-outbreak/ |title=No Swine flu outbreak at Kanakuk Kamp |publisher=The Ozarks Sentinel |date=2009-06-24 |accessdate=June 25, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090701040735/http://www.ozarksentinel.com/news/2009/06/branson-area-camp-reports-flu-outbreak/ |archivedate=July 1, 2009 }} Official results from the DHSS confirm the camp had five campers with H1N1, but that all the campers were from out of state.{{cite news |title=Five Swine Flu cases confirmed at Kanakuk Kamp |url=http://www.kspr.com/news/local/49231077.html |work=KSPR-TV |date=June 26, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090628173506/http://www.kspr.com/news/local/49231077.html |archivedate=June 28, 2009 |accessdate=June 26, 2009}} Reports from Adair, Buchanan, and Jefferson County were added on June 25 to DHSS's list of confirmed cases, bringing the count to 58 cases. These reports may be based on where people with H1N1 are from rather than where it was located in relation to the H1N1 cases reported at summer camps. The youngest case of H1N1 was confirmed by DHSS in [[Cole County, Missouri|Cole County]] on June 25, 2009. An infant was reported with having Flu-like symptoms which was confirmed by DHSS.{{cite web|url=http://www.connectmidmissouri.com/news/news_story.aspx?id=317547 |title=Health Dept. confirms H1N1 case in Cole Co. |publisher=KRCG-TV |date=June 25, 2009 |accessdate=July 3, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhOchE99?url=http://www.connectmidmissouri.com/news/news_story.aspx?id=317547 |archivedate=September 11, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} As of July 23, there have been 80 cases in Missouri. Adding to the latest cases are two children from [[Springfield, Missouri|Springfield]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ksmu.org/content/view/4835/66/ |title=First Cases of H1N1 Flu Found in Greene County |publisher=KSMU |date=July 17, 2009 |accessdate=July 17, 2009 |author=Kristian Kriner |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhOu8Fjp?url=http://www.ksmu.org/content/view/4835/66/ |archivedate=September 11, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} As of July 31, there have been 86 cases. [[Clay County, Missouri|Clay]] and [[Moniteau County, Missouri|Moniteau]] Counties were added to the list of counties with confirmed cases. As of August 8, there have been 158 confirmed cases in Missouri.{{cite web|url=http://www.dhss.mo.gov/Influenza/Week310910p.pdf |title=Week 31 (ending 8 August 2009) Pre-Season |publisher=DHSS |date=August 8, 2009 |accessdate=August 19, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091029151649/http://www.dhss.mo.gov/Influenza/Week310910p.pdf |archivedate=October 29, 2009 }} On August 15, a 5-year-old boy from [[St. Francois County, Missouri|St. Francis County]] checked into the hospital with H1N1{{cite web |url=http://www.dailyjournalonline.com/articles/2009/08/15/news/doc4a859dad5ed5a411233907.txt | title=County has confirmed first case of swine flu |author=Chris Cline |publisher=Daily Journal (Park Hills, MO) | date=August 15, 2009 | accessdate=August 19, 2009}} it is 11 cases in sharkey county and 20 cases in warren county As of September 5, there have been 37 suspected cases of H1N1 at Saint Louis University in St. Louis, MO.{{cite web|url=http://www.slu.edu/flu/H1N1-updates.html |title=H1N1 Influenza Updates |publisher=Saint Louis University |accessdate=February 5, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100125090130/http://www.slu.edu/flu/H1N1-updates.html |archivedate=January 25, 2010 |deadurl=yes }} ==Mississippi== The Mississippi State Department of Health continues to monitor and investigate human cases of a new type of influenza, H1N1 swine influenza (also known as "novel H1N1 influenza") now present in Mississippi. Symptoms of swine flu in humans are similar to those of seasonal flu, causing fever, respiratory symptoms and body aches. H1N1 swine flu has contributed to a number of deaths nationwide, principally in those with pre-existing health conditions. 898 Mississippi cases of H1N1 swine flu have been identified and 7 deaths since May 15. Mississippians are advised to continue to exercise protective hygiene to avoid illness.As January 25,14 Mississippians have died of the H1N1 flu, and more than 635 cases have been confirmed. ==Montana== On May 11, 2009, the Montana Department of Public Health and Human Services (DPHHH) reported the state's first confirmed case of swine flu. As of July 26, there have been 122 reported cases.{{cite web|url=http://www.dphhs.mt.gov/newsevents/newsreleases2009/april/firstcaseswineflu.shtml |title=Department of Public Health and Human Services – template |publisher=Dphhs.mt.gov |accessdate=May 19, 2009 |archiveurl=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20090527223345/http://www.dphhs.mt.gov/newsevents/newsreleases2009/april/firstcaseswineflu.shtml |archivedate=May 27, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }} As of January 21, there have been 801 confirmed cases of A/H1N1, and 18 confirmed deaths due to H1N1 flu.[http://www.dphhs.mt.gov/influenza/reports.shtml Montana Department of Public Health & Human Services – INFLUENZA: Reported Activity in Montana & the U.S] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100128040913/http://www.dphhs.mt.gov/influenza/reports.shtml |date=January 28, 2010 }} ==Nebraska== As of July 26, 2009, there are 313 confirmed cases of swine flu in Nebraska. Nebraska has recorded sixteen hospitalizations and three deaths.{{cite web |url=http://www.hhs.state.ne.us/H1N1flu/cases.htm |title=Nebraska DHHS: H1N1 Influenza: Human Cases in Nebraska |website=Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services |date=May 11, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503162613/http://www.hhs.state.ne.us/H1N1flu/cases.htm |archivedate=May 3, 2009 |accessdate=May 11, 2009}} as of December 11,13 deaths from A/H1N1 influenza have been reported. ==Nevada== [[File:NevadaH1N1.PNG|thumb|left|As of July 23, 2009:
{{legend|#cd3412|Case(s) confirmed}}{{legend|#000000|Death(s) confirmed}}]] The first confirmed case of the virus was reported in Nevada on April 29. A two-year-old girl from [[Reno, Nevada|Reno]] contracted the virus, but it is unclear how as the case did not appear to be linked to any previously affected areas.{{cite web|title=Nevada officials: No new swine flu cases |date=April 30, 2009 |publisher=San Jose Mercury News |accessdate=April 30, 2009 |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/news/ci_12264347 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} As of recent the virus has spread to Clark County, where the city of Las Vegas lies. It has also resulted in the closing of Mendive Middle School in Sparks, Reno's neighboring city, where ten students were confirmed to have contracted the virus. Through October 14, 2009 there had been 229 confirmed cases and 12 deaths in [[Clark County, Nevada|Clark County]], Nevada, 964 confirmed cases and 2 deaths in [[Washoe County, Nevada|Washoe County]], Nevada, 265 confirmed cases and 0 deaths in [[Carson City, Nevada|Carson City]], Nevada, and 431 confirmed cases and 1 death in the state's remaining 14 counties, totaling in 1871 cases and 15 deaths.{{cite web|url=http://flu.nv.gov/Swine_Flu/Reports/2009-10-23_PHP_HealthInfoReport.pdf |title=Nevada State Health Division Weekly Influenza Report |publisher=Nevada – State Health Division |date=October 23, 2009 |author=Dmilazzo |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhOtVcD2?url=http://health.nv.gov/PDFs/Flu/Swine_Flu/Reports/2009-07-17_InfluenzaWeeklyReport.pdf |archivedate=September 11, 2009 |accessdate=September 2, 2009 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} ==New Hampshire== {{Expand section|date=December 2009}} {{Update|inaccurate=yes|date=December 2009}} The New Hampshire Department of Health and Human Services announced the state's first confirmed case of the H1N1 flu May 2, 2009.{{cite web|url=http://wbztv.com/local/swine.flu.new.2.999793.html |title=NH Gets First Confirmed Swine Flu Case |publisher=WBZ |date=May 2, 2009 |accessdate=May 2, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503162902/http://wbztv.com/local/swine.flu.new.2.999793.html |archivedate=May 3, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} The confirmed case involved an employee of [[Concord Hospital (New Hampshire)|Concord Hospital]] in [[Concord, New Hampshire|Concord]], New Hampshire.{{cite web|url=http://wbztv.com/local/swine.flu.massachusetts.2.999791.html |title=CDC: 8 Confirmed Swine Flu Cases In Mass. |publisher=WBZ |date=May 2, 2009 |accessdate=May 2, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503162857/http://wbztv.com/local/swine.flu.massachusetts.2.999791.html |archivedate=May 3, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} As of July 6, there had been 232 confirmed cases. As of December 12, at least 9 people had died of [[H1N1]] influenza in New Hampshire. ==New Jersey== As of July 22, 2009, the New Jersey Government has confirmed 936 cases of swine flu and 480 probable cases, most of them within a range of 30 minutes of New York or Philadelphia. More swine flu cases are being reported daily, which has caused a widespread in the state. Counties currently confirmed with swine flu: Atlantic (20), Bergen (63), Burlington (64), Camden (35), Cape May (3), Cumberland (17), Essex (105), Gloucester (12), Hudson (85), Hunterdon(17), Mercer (47), Middlesex (115), Monmouth (60), Morris (45), Ocean (48), Passaic (63), Salem (3), Somerset (37), Sussex (13), Union (62), Warren (22), which indicates that currently 21 counties have confirmed cases of swine flu.{{cite web|url=http://www.nj.gov/health/er/h1n1/ |title=NJDHSS News Releases |publisher=State.nj.us |date=June 10, 2009 |accessdate=June 10, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090513231100/http://www.nj.gov/health/er/h1n1/ |archivedate=May 13, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} The first swine flu death in New Jersey occurred on June 13, 2009. The man who died was a 49-year-old resident of [[Essex County, New Jersey|Essex County]].[http://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2009/06/new_jersey_reports_first_swine.html article from New Jersey Real Times] As of January 13, 2010,14 confirmed deaths from H1N1 have been reported, since september1 in New Jersey.[http://njtoday.net/2010/01/13/two-new-h1n1-related-deaths-reported/ Two New H1N1-Related Deaths Reported | njtoday.net – Everything New Jersey] ==New Mexico== [[File:NewMexicoH1N1.PNG|thumb|right|New Mexico
As of July 20, 2009:
{{legend|#cd3412|Case(s) confirmed}}]] On April 29, 2009, Gov. [[Bill Richardson]] announced that there are two very probable cases in [[New Mexico]]. The suspected cases were a 1-year-old boy from [[Santa Fe County]] and an 18-year-old man from [[Valencia County]]. The 1-year-old tested negative for H1N1, but the 18-year-old man tested positive. More cases were raised in the intervening days, and by May 1 the probable case number was increased to nine. As of May 30, 2009, the New Mexico Department of Health has confirmed 156 total cases of the H1N1 virus in various counties with the CDC reporting 232 cases. New Mexico has since stopped reporting cases. ==New York== * New York City – 105{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/02/nyregion/02swine.html | work=The New York Times | title=This Time, City Says It's Ready for Swine Flu | first1=Sewell | last1=Chan | first2=Lisa W. | last2=Foderaro | date=September 2, 2009 | accessdate=April 23, 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://www.nyc.gov/html/doh/flu/html/data/mortality.shtml |title=NYC Influenze Information |website=The City of New York |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091006024748/http://www.nyc.gov/html/doh/flu/html/data/mortality.shtml |archivedate=October 6, 2009 |accessdate=October 17, 2009}} * New York State – 101{{cite web|url=http://www.health.state.ny.us/diseases/communicable/influenza/surveillance/2009-2010/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-10-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090924051206/http://www.health.state.ny.us/diseases/communicable/influenza/surveillance/2009-2010/ |archivedate=September 24, 2009 }} * Total – 206 ===Introduction=== On April 24, [[New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene]] dispatched a team of investigators to the private [[St. Francis Preparatory School]] in [[Queens]] after 150 students complained of symptoms consistent with the disease.{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/queens/2009/04/25/2009-04-25_150_kids_sick_at_queens_school.html|title=150 kids sick at St. Francis Preparatory School in Queens|work=Daily News |location=New York |date=April 25, 2009|accessdate=April 25, 2009 | first=Clare | last=Trapasso| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090429005732/http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/queens/2009/04/25/2009-04-25_150_kids_sick_at_queens_school.html| archivedate= April 29, 2009 | deadurl= no}}. Note: The Daily News a/local/suffolk/ny-liamit2212677813apr21, 0,4090908.story this April 21 Newsday article, which reports the illness at the other school was identified as a common form, not a new form, of influenza. Several of the students had recently traveled to [[Mexico City]].{{cite news|author=Anahad O'Connor|title=Swine Flu Fears at a Private School in Queens|date=April 24, 2009|work=The New York Times|accessdate=April 26, 2009|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/25/nyregion/25sick.html| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130522045122/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/25/nyregion/25sick.html| archivedate=May 22, 2013| deadurl= no}} New York City Health Commissioner Dr. Thomas Frieden reported on April 25 that eight of the New York school cases were "probable" swine flu. On April 26 the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) confirmed that the Queens cases are indeed associated with the H1N1 virus.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/27/world/27flu.html|author=Donald G. McNeil Jr.|title=U.S. Declares Public Health Emergency Over Swine Flu|date=April 26, 2009|work=New York Times|accessdate=April 30, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090610071515/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/27/world/27flu.html| archivedate=June 10, 2009| deadurl= no}} The students suffered only mild symptoms, and some have since recovered.{{cite news|author=Staff Writer|title=CDC: 8 New York students have swine flu|date=April 26, 2009|publisher=CNN|accessdate=April 26, 2009|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/HEALTH/04/26/swine.flu.ny/| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090429170936/http://www.cnn.com/2009/HEALTH/04/26/swine.flu.ny/| archivedate= April 29, 2009 | deadurl= no}} On April 27 federal officials confirmed 20 new US cases at the same school in New York in which eight cases were confirmed earlier.{{cite news|title=73 cases of swine flu confirmed; hundreds more feared|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/HEALTH/04/27/swine.flu/index.html|publisher=CNN|date= April 27, 2009|accessdate=April 27, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090429183620/http://www.cnn.com/2009/HEALTH/04/27/swine.flu/index.html| archivedate= April 29, 2009 | deadurl= no}} As of April 29, one undergraduate commuter student on the Queens Campus of St. John's University had contracted the Swine Flu (A/H1N1) virus. The student was treated and recovered.{{cite web|url=http://www.stjohns.edu/services/studentwellness/healthservices/flu |title=Update on A/H1N1 (Swine Flu) |publisher=Stjohns.edu |accessdate=May 5, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503193548/http://www.stjohns.edu/services/studentwellness/healthservices/flu |archivedate=May 3, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} On May 14, three New York City public schools were closed due to the flu symptoms of hundreds of students.{{cite news|url=http://www.nypost.com/seven/05142009/news/regionalnews/nyc_closing_schools_to_deal_with_big_flu_169289.htm |title=NYC Closing Schools to Deal With Big Flu Outbreak |work=New York Post |date=May 14, 2009 |accessdate=May 19, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090518100320/http://www.nypost.com/seven/05142009/news/regionalnews/nyc_closing_schools_to_deal_with_big_flu_169289.htm |archivedate=May 18, 2009 }} On May 17, Mitchell Wiener, the assistant principal at a Queens school was confirmed as New York State's first death due to the disease.{{cite web|url=http://www.newsday.com/news/local/ny-liflu1812778459may17,0,7938919.story |title=Swine flu claims Queens assistant principal |work=Newsday |location=New York |accessdate=May 19, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090521115720/http://www.newsday.com/news/local/ny-liflu1812778459may17%2C0%2C7938919.story |archivedate=May 21, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }} On May 24, a woman in her 50s died because of the disease and had other health problems. She is New York State's second death and the 11th in the country.{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090525/ap_on_he_me/med_swine_flu |title=NY woman in 50s becomes US' 11th swine flu death |accessdate=February 5, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090531194048/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090525/ap_on_he_me/med_swine_flu |archivedate=May 31, 2009 |df=mdy }} On June 1 a child from [[the Bronx]] became the first minor in New York City to die of swine flu.[http://www.newsday.com/news/local/newyork/ny-nyswin0604,0,3925385.story June 3 News Day report] On Wednesday, June 4, a man died in [[Onondaga County]], which marked the first fatality from swine flu in New York outside of New York City.[http://www.syracuse.com/business/index.ssf?/base/business-15/124410574696200.xml&coll=1 ''The Post-Standard'', June 4, 2009] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607102244/http://www.syracuse.com/business/index.ssf?%2Fbase%2Fbusiness-15%2F124410574696200.xml&coll=1 |date=June 7, 2011 }} A city health department poll suggested that more than half a million citizens of New York may be infected as of June 11.[https://archive.is/20110905193539/http://www.fox44.net/Global/story.asp?S=10516260 1/2 Million infected in NYC according to poll] By June 17, 2009 there had been 30 Swine flu deaths in New York.[http://www.ny1.com/content/special_reports/h1n1__swine_flu/101051/city-s-h1n1-death-toll-rises-to-30/Default.aspx City's H1N1 Death Toll Rises To 30 – NY1.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090725001642/http://www.ny1.com/content/special_reports/h1n1__swine_flu/101051/city-s-h1n1-death-toll-rises-to-30/Default.aspx |date=July 25, 2009 }} As of July 24, the CDC has reported 2,738 confirmed cases of the H1N1 flu. ==North Carolina== The state health director, Dr. Jeffrey Engel, announced that there had been two probable cases of swine flu in the state. The first case was a man traveling through [[Wake County]], where the capital is located, on business. The other case was an [[Onslow County]] resident who had recently traveled to Texas. On a related note, North Carolina is one of 29 states that have deemed to have not stockpiled enough flu medicines by federal guidelines. However, Dr. Engel dismissed these concerns, saying, "I think the commercial supply will keep up at the present time."{{cite news| title=N.C. stock of flu meds below guidelines| date=May 1, 2009| publisher=[[Capitol Broadcasting Company]]| url =http://www.wral.com/news/local/story/5062588/| work =WRAL.com| accessdate =May 2, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090503075809/http://www.wral.com/news/local/story/5062588/| archivedate= May 3, 2009 | deadurl= no}} North Carolina has 483 confirmed cases as of July 22. There have been six deaths confirmed in the state. The most famous victim of swine flu was Elliott Wilson, a student at North Carolina State University. He contracted the virus on September 10, 2009, and was responsible for infecting 13% of the student population. ==North Dakota== {{Expand section|date=January 2010}} {{Update|inaccurate=yes|date=January 2010}} As of July 23, North Dakota has 63 confirmed cases of swine flu. ==Ohio== On April 26, the Ohio Department of Health reported that a nine-year-old boy attending [[Elyria City School District|Elyria City Schools]] in [[Elyria, Ohio|Elyria]], [[Lorain County, Ohio|Lorain County]], had been diagnosed with a mild case of the new strain of swine influenza and that his immediate family was undergoing testing.{{cite web|url=http://www.chroniclet.com/2009/04/26/breaking-news-swine-flu-reported-in-elyria-school/ |title=UPDATED: Ely School student has swine flu |work=Chronicle-Telegram |date=April 26, 2009 |accessdate=April 26, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090429084206/http://www.chroniclet.com/2009/04/26/breaking-news-swine-flu-reported-in-elyria-school |archivedate=April 29, 2009 }} After the confirmed case in Ohio and eight in New York occurred Federal officials declared a public health emergency.{{cite news|title=Confirmed case in Ohio |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-sci-swine-flu27-2009apr27,0,3534516.story?page=2 | work=The Los Angeles Times | first1=Jim | last1=Tankersley | date=April 27, 2009| accessdate=February 5, 2010 }} The [[Cleveland]] health department received numerous calls from concerned residents the first week of the outbreak, although it has been difficult to tell whether or not the cases are swine flu, since it is regular flu season.{{cite web|title=Will swine flu hit Northeast Ohio? Health officials say it's too soon to say |date=April 26, 2009 |publisher=Cleveland.com |accessdate=April 26, 2009 |url=http://www.cleveland.com/news/plaindealer/index.ssf?/base/news/124073480622091.xml&coll=2 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20090427201028/http://www.cleveland.com/news/plaindealer/index.ssf?/base/news/124073480622091.xml&coll=2 |archivedate=April 27, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }} On April 29, a probable case was reported in [[Columbus, Ohio|Columbus]],Columbus investigating probable swine flu case as threat level rises http://www.dispatch.com/live/content/local_news/stories/2009/04/29/flucase.html?sid=101{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} and two new cases were confirmed in Columbus on May 2, one of them being an employee of [[The Ohio State University]] Medical Center.{{cite news|title=CDC Confirms 2 Columbus H1N1 Cases |url=http://www.10tv.com/live/content/local/stories/2009/05/02/story_h1n1_confirmed.html?sid=102 |accessdate=February 5, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110615113121/http://www.10tv.com/live/content/local/stories/2009/05/02/story_h1n1_confirmed.html?sid=102 |archivedate=June 15, 2011 }} As of July 24, 2009 there were 186 confirmed cases of swine flu in Ohio.[http://www.odh.ohio.gov/landing/phs_emergency/swineflu.aspx Ohio health department report] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090624210954/http://www.odh.ohio.gov/landing/phs_emergency/swineflu.aspx |date=June 24, 2009 }} In September 2009, a 20-year-old Columbus woman died from H1N1 a week after having a c-section to give birth to her child at 32 weeks gestation. As of October 9, 2009 a 14-year-old boy was reported as Ohio's first pediatric death. ==Oklahoma== In [[Muskogee, Oklahoma|Muskogee]], Oklahoma a man who recently visited [[Mexico]] had been admitted into a hospital after having H1N1 flu symptoms,{{cite news |title=Patient reports flu after Mexico visit |url=http://www.fox23.com/news/state/story/Patient-reports-flu-after-Mexico-visit/JD7Nq-gr9U6YQxh-TfAf-w.cspx |date=April 28, 2009 |work=KOTV-TV |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503162628/http://www.fox23.com/news/state/story/Patient-reports-flu-after-Mexico-visit/JD7Nq-gr9U6YQxh-TfAf-w.cspx |archivedate=May 3, 2009 |accessdate=April 28, 2009}} but test results on May 1 returned negative.{{cite web|url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/news/article.aspx?subjectid=17&articleid=20090430_298_0_Aveter884084|title=Muskogee man tests negative for swine flu| accessdate=February 5, 2010 }} On May 5, a woman from [[Pontotoc County, Oklahoma|Pontotoc County]] was confirmed to have H1N1 flu,Oklahoma health officials confirm first H1N1 flu case in state (5-5-09) http://www.tulsaworld.com/news/article.aspx?subjectid=12&articleid=20090505_298_0_OKLAHO523217 On May 7, Oklahoma State Department of Health confirmed three new cases of the H1N1 virus: a child from [[Oklahoma County]], and one adult and a teenage female in [[Cleveland County, Oklahoma|Cleveland County]]. All have recovered but, there has been one death in the state so far.3 New Oklahoma H1N1 flu Cases confirmed (5-7-09)http://www.news9.com/global/story.asp?s=10323829 On July 20 it was confirmed that a teenager in Tulsa had the swine flu. As of July 22, there have been 203 cases reported. ==Oregon== [[File:2009 Swine Flu Outbreak in Oregon.png|thumb|right|Confirmed as of July 24, 2009:ODHS updates every Friday, except on July 31, 2009 when the update was [http://www.oregon.gov/DHS/ph/acd/swineflu_investigation.shtml reported delayed] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090502213026/http://www.oregon.gov/DHS/ph/acd/swineflu_investigation.shtml |date=May 2, 2009 }} until August 3, 2009.
{{legend|#000000|6 Death(s)}}{{legend|#cd3412|530 Case(s)}}]] The first probable case of H1N1 flu in [[Oregon]] was announced on April 30 by the [[Oregon Department of Human Services]] (ODHS).{{cite web |url=http://www.oregon.gov/DHS/news/2009news/2009-0430.pdf |title=First probable swine flu case reported in Oregon |date=April 30, 2009 |publisher=[[Oregon Department of Human Services]] |accessdate=June 3, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090603192428/http://www.oregon.gov/DHS/news/2009news/2009-0430.pdf| archivedate= June 3, 2009 | deadurl= no}} By May 3, three people had been tested positive for swine flu.{{cite news |url=http://www.oregonlive.com/news/index.ssf/2009/05/oregons_swine_flu_numbers_grow.html |title=Oregon's swine flu numbers growing |work=[[The Oregonian]] |author=Colburn, Don |date=May 3, 2009 |accessdate=June 3, 2009| archiveurl= https://archive.is/20090507072845/http://www.oregonlive.com/news/index.ssf/2009/05/oregons_swine_flu_numbers_grow.html| archivedate= May 7, 2009 | deadurl= no}} On May 22, the ODHS announced that 46% of patients who tested positive for flu since March 4 were indeed infected with H1N1 flu, with the rest having just a seasonal flu.{{cite web |url=http://www.oregon.gov/DHS/news/2009news/2009-0522.pdf |title=120 cases of H1N1 swine flu reported in Oregon; twice-weekly reporting to begin Tuesday |publisher=[[Oregon Department of Human Services]] |date=May 22, 2009 |accessdate=June 3, 2009 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090603192454/http://www.oregon.gov/DHS/news/2009news/2009-0522.pdf| archivedate= June 3, 2009 | deadurl= no}} H1N1 has been detected in 530 residents of Oregon as of July 24, 2009. Confirmed cases have been found in 21 out of 36 counties, including [[Benton County, Oregon|Benton County]], [[Clackamas County, Oregon|Clackamas County]], [[Clatsop County, Oregon|Clatsop County]], [[Columbia County, Oregon|Columbia County]], [[Crook County, Oregon|Crook County]], [[Deschutes County, Oregon|Deschutes County]], [[Douglas County, Oregon|Douglas County]], [[Hood River County, Oregon|Hood River County]], [[Jackson County, Oregon|Jackson County]], [[Klamath County, Oregon|Klamath County]], [[Lane County, Oregon|Lane County]], [[Lincoln County, Oregon|Lincoln County]], [[Linn County, Oregon|Linn County]], [[Marion County, Oregon|Marion County]], [[Multnomah County, Oregon|Multnomah County]], [[Polk County, Oregon|Polk County]], [[Tillamook County, Oregon|Tillamook County]], [[Umatilla County, Oregon|Umatilla County]], [[Wasco County, Oregon|Wasco County]], [[Washington County, Oregon|Washington County]], and [[Yamhill County, Oregon|Yamhill County]].{{cite web|url=http://www.oregon.gov/DHS/ph/acd/swineflu_investigation.shtml |title=H1N1 Influenza Update |publisher=[[Oregon Department of Human Services]] |accessdate=May 2, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090502213026/http://www.oregon.gov/DHS/ph/acd/swineflu_investigation.shtml |archivedate=May 2, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} On June 8, 2009, Oregon's first H1N1-related death in Marion County was reported by the ODHS.{{cite web | url=http://www.oregon.gov/DHS/news/2009news/2009-0608.pdf | title=State of Oregon: Oregon Department of Human Services -  }} Since then, five other deaths have been reported; another two in Marion County (June 15, 2009 and July 24, 2009) and three in Multnomah County (June 26, 2009, July 3, 2009, and July 17, 2009).[http://www.flu.oregon.gov/ flu.oregon.gov – Home] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090624210952/http://www.flu.oregon.gov/ |date=June 24, 2009 }} ==Pennsylvania== [[File:Pennsylvania swine flu map.svg|thumb|As of June 16, 2009:{{cite web|url=http://www.health.state.pa.us/H1N1Map/ |title=Novel 2009 Influenza A/H1N1: Confirmed and Probable Case Counts In Pennsylvania |publisher=Pennsylvania Department of Health |accessdate=February 5, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100404023733/http://www.health.state.pa.us/H1N1Map/ |archivedate=April 4, 2010 }}
{{legend|#000000|Death(s) confirmed}}{{legend|#cd3412|Case(s) confirmed}}]] On May 3, The Pennsylvania Department of Health said that a 31-year-old male in Montgomery County had the H1N1 flu.{{cite web|author=Myfoxphilly.com|url=http://www.myfoxphilly.com/dpp/news/Pennsylvania_Swine_Flu_05_02_09|title=Pennsylvania Swine Flu|publisher=Myfoxphilly.com|accessdate=May 6, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090504154106/http://www.myfoxphilly.com/dpp/news/Pennsylvania_Swine_Flu_05_02_09| archivedate= May 4, 2009 | deadurl= no}} By May 5 probable cases were under investigation in [[Philadelphia County, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]] (10), [[Bucks County, Pennsylvania|Bucks]] (2), [[Chester County, Pennsylvania|Chester]] (2), [[Allegheny County, Pennsylvania|Allegheny]] (1), [[Cambria County, Pennsylvania|Cambria]] (1), [[Franklin County, Pennsylvania|Franklin]] (1), [[Lehigh County, Pennsylvania|Lehigh]] (1), [[Luzerne County, Pennsylvania|Luzerne]] (1), [[Lycoming County, Pennsylvania|Lycoming]] (1), [[Montgomery County, Pennsylvania|Montgomery]] (1), and [[York County, Pennsylvania|York]] (1) counties.{{cite web|author=PA Department of Health|url=http://www.dsf.health.state.pa.us/health/cwp/view.asp?q=252990|title=Health: 2009 Novel Influenza A H1N1(previously referred to as Swine Flu)|publisher=Dsf.health.state.pa.us|accessdate=May 5, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090502084049/http://www.dsf.health.state.pa.us/health/cwp/view.asp?q=252990| archivedate= May 2, 2009 | deadurl= no}} On June 4, a 55-year-old woman in Berks County was confirmed as the first death in Pennsylvania due to swine flu.{{cite web |url=http://www.dsf.health.state.pa.us/health/cwp/view.asp?Q=253375&A=190 |title=HEALTH DEPARTMENT REPORTS PENNSYLVANIA'S FIRST DEATH DUE TO 2009 NOVEL INFLUENZA A/H1N1 VIRUS |date=June 4, 2009 |accessdate=June 5, 2009 |publisher=Pennsylvania Department of Health}} This was followed by the deaths of a 26-year-old Philadelphia woman with no known underlying conditions on June 7,{{cite web|url=http://www.kyw1060.com/Philadelphia-Sees-1st-Swine-Flu-Death/4560934 |accessdate=June 26, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} and a 48-year-old woman in [[Pike County, Pennsylvania|Pike County]] on June 13.[http://www.poconorecord.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20090616/NEWS/90616020 Pike County woman dead from swine flu | PoconoRecord.com] Confirmed and probable case counts and deaths are updated daily at the Pennsylvania Department of Health. As January 19, 2010,2997 people have either had confirmed or probable cases of A/H1N1 influenza in Pennsylvania, and at least 14 have died.[http://www.health.state.pa.us/H1N1map/ Department of Health Home] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100404023733/http://www.health.state.pa.us/H1N1Map/ |date=April 4, 2010 }} ==Rhode Island== {{Expand section|date=January 2010}} On May 2, 2009, Rhode Island confirmed its first case of H1N1 Flu in a Westerly woman. Rhode Island reported its first death from swine flu on June 18. As of August 26, 2009, the Rhode Island Department of Health has reported 203 confirmed cases of H1N1 flu and two deaths. Three swines from a farm just north of Barrington contracted the flu which gave farmer Jimmy Bo-Brown many headaches. Sick swine have stunted growth and require increased attention from the farmer often leading to headaches. Two of the swines Elliott and Wilson died from dehydration and the last one recovered after about a week and was promptly slaughtered for bacon.{{cite web|url=http://www.health.ri.gov/pandemicflu/swineflu/swineflu.php |title=H1N1 Flu Rhode Island Update |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhOvK0vS?url=http://www.health.ri.gov/pandemicflu/swineflu/swineflu.php |archivedate=September 11, 2009 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=September 2, 2009 |df=mdy }} ==South Carolina== On August 28, 2009 the [[South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control]] (SCDHEC) announced it will begin the first full week of reporting all laboratory confirmed influenza hospitalizations and deaths to the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] on September 8, 2009.South Carolina Health Alert Network, Public Health Notifications, [http://www.scdhec.gov/health/disease/han/docs/10181-DAD-08-28-09-H1N1.pdf August 28, 2009 Advisory]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100211185119/http://www.scdhec.gov/health/disease/han/docs/10181-DAD-08-28-09-H1N1.pdf |date=February 11, 2010 }} The South Carolina Department of Health has reported 313 cases as of July 24 throughout the state.{{cite web|url=http://www.scdhec.gov/flu/CR-009491.gif |title=Influenza A H1N1 (Swine)-S.C. Flu Numbers |publisher=South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control |date=May 8, 2009 |accessdate=May 8, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090507092927/http://www.scdhec.gov/flu/CR-009491.gif |archivedate=May 7, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} Thirteen cases of the flu virus were confirmed in South Carolina on April 30. All 13 were students and/or parents from the private Newberry Academy in [[Newberry, South Carolina|Newberry]], South Carolina; many had traveled to Mexico earlier in the month. All nearby public schools were closed for May 1. On August 31, South Carolina recorded its first death from influenza A H1N1.{{cite web|title=S.C. DHEC: News – South Carolina records first Novel H1N1 flu-associated death |url=http://www.scdhec.gov/administration/news/2009/nr20090831-01.htm |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhOvi0Zm?url=http://www.scdhec.gov/administration/news/2009/nr20090831-01.htm |archivedate=September 11, 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=September 2, 2009 |df=mdy }} The Byrnes Schools High School in Florence, SC closed because of the H1N1 flu from September 23 to September 25. ==South Dakota== As of July 24, South Dakota has confirmed 48 cases of swine flu and hospitalized two patients.{{cite web|url=http://doh.sd.gov/H1N1CaseCounts.aspx |title=South Dakota H1N1 Case Counts |publisher=South Dakota – Department of Health |date=May 28, 2009 |accessdate=June 5, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhOuXnaI?url=http://doh.sd.gov/H1N1CaseCounts.aspx |archivedate=September 11, 2009 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} ==Tennessee== As of July 22, there have been 282 confirmed cases of swine flu.{{cite web |url=http://health.state.tn.us/H1N1.htm |title=H1N1/Swine Flu Information for Tennessee Residents |date=July 25, 2009 |accessdate=July 25, 2009 |publisher=Tennessee – Department of Health| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090722184601/http://health.state.tn.us/H1N1.htm| archivedate= July 22, 2009 | deadurl= yes}} On July 15, the
