[[File:H1N1 Texas map.svg|thumb|As of [[Central Time Zone (Americas)#Central Daylight Time|CDT]] 23:30, July 16, 2009: ([http://www.dshs.state.tx.us/news/updates.shtm source])
{{legend|#000000|Death(s) confirmed}}{{legend|#cd3412|Case(s) confirmed}}{{legend|#eaa912|Case(s) probable}}]] Texas has reported 4,998 cases and 27 deaths as of July 24. Of the first 13 deaths confirmed in Texas, one was a Mexican citizen.{{cite web|url=http://www.dshs.state.tx.us/news/updates.shtm|title=Texas Department of State Health Services, News Updates |date= June 24, 2009 |accessdate=June 25, 2009 |publisher=[[Texas Department of State Health Services]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090624211017/http://www.dshs.state.tx.us/news/updates.shtm| archivedate= June 24, 2009 | deadurl= yes}} Two students attending Byron P. Steele II High School in [[Cibolo, Texas|Cibolo]] were confirmed to have the A/H1N1 swine flu; the patients recovered.{{cite news|first=Rob|last=Stein|title=In California and Texas, 5 New Swine Flu Cases|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/04/23/AR2009042304116.html|work=Washington Post|date=April 24, 2009| accessdate=February 5, 2010 }} A third possible case in a student who attends the same high school as the two other cases in Texas has been identified and the school is closed temporarily.{{cite web|url=http://www.scuc.txed.net/Campuses/Steele/pdf/dshs_press_release_0425.pdf|title=School to Close, Other Flu Precautions Recommended|publisher=Schertz-Cibolo-Universal City Independent School District|author=[[Texas Department of State Health Services]]|date=April 25, 2009|accessdate=April 25, 2009}}{{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} On April 25, the Texas Department of State Health Services (DSHS) decided to close Byron P. Steele II High School for the following week. Following the discovery of more possible swine flu illnesses, the DSHS ordered that all schools and district facilities in the [[Schertz-Cibolo-Universal City Independent School District]] be closed for the week.{{cite web|url=http://www.scuc.txed.net/Departments/PublicInfoWeb/features |archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20090506054552/http://www.scuc.txed.net/Departments/PublicInfoWeb/features |dead-url=yes |archive-date=May 6, 2009 |title=Temporary Closure of All SCUCISD Campuses |publisher=[[Schertz-Cibolo-Universal City Independent School District]] |date=April 26, 2009 |accessdate=April 26, 2009 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://seguingazette.com/story.lasso?ewcd=9552b143f7c740f3|title=Swine flu shuts down all of SCUCISD|work=Seguin Gazette-Enterprise|author=Ron Maloney|date=April 26, 2009|accessdate=April 26, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090504011117/http://seguingazette.com/story.lasso?ewcd=9552b143f7c740f3| archivedate= May 4, 2009 | deadurl= yes}} On April 27, a 7-year-old, a 24-year-old, and a 3-month-old in [[Dallas County, Texas|Dallas County]] were confirmed to have swine flu. All recovering and were not hospitalized.{{cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/metropolitan/6395297.html |title=3 additional swine flu cases confirmed in Texas |work=Houston Chronicle |agency=Associated Press |date=April 27, 2009 |accessdate=April 27, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090429211819/http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/metropolitan/6395297.html |archivedate=April 29, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} That same day, the [[Richardson Independent School District]] in the northern [[Dallas]] suburb of [[Richardson, Texas|Richardson]] shut down Canyon Creek Elementary School due to a confirmed and two suspected cases of swine flu.{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/news/localnews/stories/042809dnmetswineflu.117f21302.html|title=Richardson school shuts down; schools put on alert for swine flu|publisher=Dallas Morning News|author1=Sherry Jacobson |author2=Tawnell Hobbs |date=April 27, 2009|accessdate=April 28, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090430125934/http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/news/localnews/stories/042809dnmetswineflu.117f21302.html| archivedate= April 30, 2009 | deadurl= yes}} All schools in [[New Braunfels, Texas|New Braunfels]]—private schools and all campuses of the [[Comal Independent School District|Comal]] and [[New Braunfels Independent School District]]s—announced closures through May 10 on the recommendation of the Medical Authority of [[Comal County, Texas|Comal County]].{{cite web|url=http://www.statesman.com/blogs/content/shared-gen/blogs/austin/education/entries/2009/04/28/new_braunfels_comal_isd_shut_d.html |title=New Braunfels, Comal ISD shut down due to swine flu fears |publisher=Austin American Statesman |author=Patrick George |date=April 28, 2009 |accessdate=April 28, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090429204019/http://www.statesman.com/blogs/content/shared-gen/blogs/austin/education/entries/2009/04/28/new_braunfels_comal_isd_shut_d.html |archivedate=April 29, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} On May 6, the ''New Braunfels Herald-Zeitung'' reported that all schools in Guadalupe and Comal counties would reopen on Thursday, May 7, four days earlier than had previously been announced.{{cite news|last=Cobb |first=Chris |title=Schools open Thursday |url=http://herald-zeitung.com/story.lasso?ewcd=a86552bb0239c41a&-session=HeraldZeitung:430B05FB0c5b11FF63oUs3DA3E51 |work=New Braunfels Herald-Zeitung |date=May 6, 2009 |accessdate=May 23, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Due to the swine flu, the [[University Interscholastic League]] (UIL) suspended all athletic, musical, and academic competitions and games for primary and secondary public education in the state of Texas until May 11.[http://www.uil.utexas.edu/db/press_release_detail.lasso?-Search=Action&-Table=table&-Database=press_releases&-KeyValue=312 UIL Website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090502075159/http://www.uil.utexas.edu/db/press_release_detail.lasso?-Search=Action&-Table=table&-Database=press_releases&-KeyValue=312 |date=May 2, 2009 }} On April 28, the [[Houston|City of Houston]] Health Department and [[Texas Children's Hospital]] sent samples in to the CDC. There are also possible cases at the [[Baylor College of Medicine]] outpatient clinic, [[Memorial Hermann Hospital]], and [[St. Luke's Episcopal Hospital|St. Luke's Hospital]].{{cite web|url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/metropolitan/6397750.html|title=Houston still waiting for word on city swine flu cases|work=Houston Chronicle|date= April 29, 2009|accessdate=April 29, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090502164231/http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/metropolitan/6397750.html| archivedate= May 2, 2009 | deadurl= no}} A 23-month-old Mexican toddler who had been brought to Houston from [[Brownsville, Texas|Brownsville]] died on April 27, making the child the first US death due to the outbreak. The child had traveled with his family from Mexico to Brownsville to visit relatives. The infant was admitted to a Brownsville hospital after becoming ill, then transferred to Texas Children's Hospital the next day.{{cite web|url=http://www.krgv.com/content/news/special/SwineFlu/story/CDC-Toddler-Dies-of-Swine-Flu/SA2i4APFJkml5h9p9DYLkA.cspx |title=CDC: Toddler Dies of Swine Flu – KRGV NEWSCHANNEL 5 – The Rio Grande Valley's News Channel – Breaking News, Breaking Stories, Breaking the Mold – RGV News |publisher=Krgv.com |date=April 29, 2009 |accessdate=May 2, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503164945/http://www.krgv.com/content/news/special/SwineFlu/story/CDC-Toddler-Dies-of-Swine-Flu/SA2i4APFJkml5h9p9DYLkA.cspx |archivedate=May 3, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} The toddler suffered from chronic muscle weakness, a heart defect, a swallowing problem and lack of oxygen.{{cite web|title=US Swine Flu Victims Had Chronic Health Problems |publisher=[[Cybercast News Service]] |date=May 7, 2009 |url=http://www.cnsnews.com/public/content/article.aspx?RsrcID=47822 |accessdate=May 7, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Texas Governor [[Rick Perry]] issued a disaster declaration.{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iEMiQfLoNmwc8Z_poQuZhlOrG-ng|title=AFP: Texas declares swine flu emergency|accessdate=May 1, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090505082841/https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iEMiQfLoNmwc8Z_poQuZhlOrG-ng| archivedate= May 5, 2009 | deadurl= no}} On April 29, it was confirmed by [[Harris County, Texas|Harris County]] that a 17-year-old girl from [[Fort Bend County, Texas|Fort Bend County]] attending [[Episcopal High School (Bellaire, Texas)|Episcopal High School]] in [[Bellaire, Texas|Bellaire]] had contracted and recovered from the A/H1N1 swine flu. In compliance with the directives of the Harris County Public Health and Environmental Services Department, the school has been closed until further notice. Also in Fort Worth, a rising number of possible and confirmed cases in the district made school officials close all schools starting the next day, April 30. Schools in FWISD remained closed until May 8. The district was the biggest in the nation to close resulting in 80,000 students out of school and 11,000 staff members out of their jobs for that time. During the next week 6 school districts in Dallas-Fort Worth shut down. Including Cleburne, Lewisville, Decatur, Denton, Fort Worth, and Ponder. Other schools in Plano, Dallas, and Richardson were also closed, but did not result in a district wide shut down. Other smaller districts also shut down.{{cite web|url=http://www.ehshouston.org/ehs/NewsBot.asp?MODE=VIEW&ID=790&SnID=2034202181 |title=Episcopal High School closes through the weekend |accessdate=February 5, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503150443/http://www.ehshouston.org/ehs/NewsBot.asp?MODE=VIEW&ID=790&SnID=2034202181 |archivedate=May 3, 2009 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/health/6399725.html|title=First Houston swine flu case reported; 4 schools now shut | Health & Medicine | Chron.com – Houston Chronicle|work=Houston Chronicle |accessdate=April 30, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090503014202/http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/health/6399725.html| archivedate= May 3, 2009 | deadurl= no|date=2009-04-29}} Also that day, a probable case caused the closure of Lucy Read Pre-Kindergarten Demonstration School in north [[Austin]].{{cite web|url=http://www.kvue.com/news/top/stories/042909kvue_Lucy_Reed-cb.26f0453.html |title=WATCH: Probable swine flu case prompts AISD to close North Austin campus |accessdate=February 5, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090502214846/http://www.kvue.com/news/top/stories/042909kvue_Lucy_Reed-cb.26f0453.html |archivedate=May 2, 2009 |df=mdy }} [[Denton County, Texas|Denton County]] reported its first confirmed swine flu case April 30, in a child in [[Plano, Texas|Plano]]; the student attended Wilson Middle School in the [[Plano Independent School District]], and the district decided to close the [[Collin County]] school until May 11.{{cite news|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/news/localnews/stories/050109dnmetflumain.4a75516.html|title=Dallas, Fort Worth take different tacks in responding to swine flu outbreak|last=Jacobson|first=Sherry|date=May 1, 2009|work=The Dallas Morning News|accessdate=May 2, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090503131859/http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/news/localnews/stories/050109dnmetflumain.4a75516.html| archivedate= May 3, 2009 | deadurl= yes}} [[Navo Middle School]] and [[Robert E. Lee Elementary School (Dallas, Texas)|Lee Elementary School]], of [[Denton Independent School District]] were also closed after three students at both schools respectively were diagnosed with type A influenza.{{cite news |last1=Tabor |first1=Britney |last2=Carlisle |first2=Candace |date=April 30, 2009 |title=Denton ISD closes two schools |url=http://www.dentonrc.com/sharedcontent/dws/drc/localnews/stories/drc_flu_update_0430.83f939f.html |work=Denton Record-Chronicle |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503045100/http://www.dentonrc.com/sharedcontent/dws/drc/localnews/stories/drc_flu_update_0430.83f939f.html |archivedate= May 3, 2009 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=May 2, 2009}} As of May 2, the rest of Denton ISD officially closed for the following week, but as of May 5, all schools are officially reopening on May 7.{{cite web|url=http://dentonisd.org/51210428115646493/site/default.asp?# |title=Update: H1N1 (Swine) Influenza |date=May 5, 2009 |accessdate=May 6, 2009 |publisher=Schoolwires, Inc. |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090506063041/http://www.dentonisd.org/51210428115646493/site/default.asp |archivedate=May 6, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} The Superintendent of [[Keller Independent School District]] in [[Keller, Texas|Keller]] reported 3 possible cases, one in each of three schools.{{cite web|url=http://www.kellerisd.net/kellerisd/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=683&Itemid=48 |title=schools open; no confirmed Swine Flu |publisher=Keller ISD |accessdate=May 1, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503150427/http://www.kellerisd.net/kellerisd/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=683&Itemid=48 |archivedate=May 3, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} On April 30, 8 suspected cases were recognized in [[El Paso County, Texas|El Paso County]]. Lab samples have been sent to CDC. No further information has been provided at this time until cases are confirmed. At this time, international borders will remain open.{{cite web|url=http://www.kvia.com/global/Story.asp?s=10281383 |title=8 suspected cases of swine flu found in El Paso County – KVIA.com El Paso, Las Cruces – Weather, News, Sports |publisher=Kvia.com |accessdate=May 1, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503093420/http://www.kvia.com/global/Story.asp?s=10281383 |archivedate=May 3, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} The El Paso Dept. of Public Health identified 11 more suspect cases of H1N1 flu in El Paso County on Friday, May 1, to bring the total number of suspect cases to 19. Lamar Consolidated ISD closed Lamar Junior High School due to a suspected (probable) case.{{cite web|url=http://www.myfoxhouston.com/dpp/health/090430_houston_swin_closures|title=Houston Swine Flu Closures & Info|publisher=myfoxhouston.com|accessdate=May 1, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090502160238/http://www.myfoxhouston.com/dpp/health/090430_houston_swin_closures| archivedate= May 2, 2009 | deadurl= yes}} [[Weslaco ISD]] closed all campuses for 7 days after a student was confirmed to have contracted type A influenza.{{cite news|url=http://www.themonitor.com/articles/closures-26027-rgv-school.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20090502172225/http://www.themonitor.com/articles/closures-26027-rgv-school.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=May 2, 2009|title=More school closures in RGV|date=April 30, 2009|work=The Monitor|accessdate=May 2, 2009}} On May 5, Judy Trunnell, a woman in her 30's suffering from "chronic underlying health conditions" died of swine flu in [[Cameron County, Texas|Cameron County]], near the US-Mexico border. She was the first US citizen to die from the disease.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/8034991.stm|title=US resident dies from swine flu|publisher=BBC|date=May 5, 2009|accessdate=May 23, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090509043259/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/8034991.stm| archivedate= May 9, 2009 | deadurl= no}} The woman, a special education teacher, had recently given birth to an eight-month-term healthy baby, delivered by caesarian section.{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/science/judy-dead-at-33-from-suspected-swine-flu-20090506-au9c.html |title=Flu suspected in US teacher's death |work=Sydney Morning Herald |date=April 23, 2009 |accessdate=May 8, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090508025646/http://www.smh.com.au/world/science/judy-dead-at-33-from-suspected-swine-flu-20090506-au9c.html| archivedate= May 8, 2009 | deadurl= no}} She had been in a coma after being admitted to the hospital with breathing problems on April 19. The woman had also suffered from asthma, rheumatoid arthritis and a skin condition. On August 28, a 52-year-old woman with underlying health conditions became the first death in Dallas County. Meanwhile, at TCU in Fort Worth there is an outbreak of swine flu on the campus. On Monday August 24, 10 students had possible cases of swine flu, by Wednesday the number had jumped to 88. Students that are sick are being asked to isolate themselves in their dorm rooms. SMU and UT at Arlington are also each reporting less than 5 cases of swine flu each. This is all occurring as schools in the state of Texas return to school.{{cite web |title=Woman, 52, becomes first Dallas County swine flu fatality |url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/news/localnews/stories/DN-flu_28met.ART0.State.Edition2.4bbfd8f.html|publisher=[[Dallas Morning News]]|date= August 28, 2009|accessdate=August 30, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091003101518/http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/news/localnews/stories/DN-flu_28met.ART0.State.Edition2.4bbfd8f.html| archivedate= October 3, 2009 | deadurl= yes}} On October 14, it was confirmed, that Reality TV star [[Melissa Rycroft]] who lived in [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]], New Jersey over the summer and came back to Dallas has swine flu.As of January 2, 2010,203 Texans have died of H1N1 influenza,474 Texans admitted to the intensive care unit due to A/H1N1, and 2,052 Texans have been hospitalized do to A/H1N1 influenza.{{Citation needed|date=January 2010}} ==Utah== [[File:Updated 2009 Swine Flu outbreak in Utah.png|thumb|right|As of 12:30 [[Mountain Time Zone|MST]], June 17, 2009:
{{legend|#000000|Death(s) confirmed}}{{legend|#cd3412|Case(s) confirmed}} ]] On April 28, 2009, one student in Park City, Utah was suspected to have swine flu. Two more students in the school district began showing similar symptoms making three probable cases. All 8 schools in the Park City School District closed the following day. On May 1 the number of probable cases was increased to 9; 6 in Summit County (Park City), 2 in Salt Lake County and 1 in the Morgan-Weber Health District and about 80 suspected cases.[279] May 2 at around 11 o'clock the first confirmation came back for the original case, 7 more were confirmed by the 6th. On May 6 the probable case count was at 30.{{Citation needed|date=June 2009}} As of June 11, Utah has reported 684 cases of swine flu and has not updated since; however, the CDC has reported 988 cases as of July 24. The first confirmed death from swine flu in Utah, of a 21-year-old man, was reported on May 20, 2009.{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/30795846/|publisher=MSNBC|title=Over 52? You may be protected from swine flu|date=May 20, 2009|accessdate=May 20, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090519222404/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/30795846/| archivedate= May 19, 2009 | deadurl= no}} On June 16, 2009, the number of reported deaths from Swine flu in Utah reached six. All six deaths had occurred in Salt Lake County.[https://archive.is/20130121194419/http://www.deseretnews.com/article/1,5143,705310889,00.html ''Deseret News'', June 16, 2009] The state announced on June 17 two more deaths from swine flu, one of which occurred at an unspecified location outside of Salt Lake County, the other in Salt Lake County.[http://www.deseretnews.com/article/705311092/Two-more-dead-from-H1N1-virus.html ''Deseret News'', June 17, 2009] Utah has reported 21 deaths as of October 15, 2009.[http://www.sltrib.com/news/ci_13561188 ''The Salt Lake Tribune'', October 15, 2009] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091015160136/http://www.sltrib.com/news/ci_13561188 |date=October 15, 2009 }} New reports available from Utah's health department as of October 28, 2009 indicated there had been 30 deaths from H1N1 in Utah, 18 through August 31, 2009 and a further 12 since that time.[http://www.deseretnews.com/article/705340315/3-more-H1N1-deaths-in-Utah.html ''Deseret News'', October 28, 2009] On November 18, 2009 the Utah State Health department reported five more deaths from swine flu.[http://www.deseretnews.com/article/705345626/5-more-Utah-H1N1-deaths-reported.html ''Deseret News'', November 18, 2009] ==Vermont== The Vermont Department of Health announced a probable case of the H1N1 virus in rural Orleans County.{{cite web|url=http://www.burlingtonfreepress.com/article/20090506/NEWS/90506028/Probable+case+of+swine+flu+in+Vermont&referrer=FRONTPAGECAROUSEL|title=Probable case of swine flu in Vermont|author=Joel Banner Baird|date=May 6, 2009|work=burlingtonfreepress.com|accessdate=May 7, 2009}}{{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} A second case of the flu was confirmed involving an adult in Windsor County.{{cite web|url=http://www.burlingtonfreepress.com/article/20090520/NEWS02/90520040/1001/NEWS |title=Second case of Vt. swine flu confirmed |accessdate=February 5, 2010 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} As of July 22, there have been 62 laboratory confirmed cases.{{cite web|url=http://www.burlingtonfreepress.com/article/20090609/NEWS02/90609022/Vt.+Health+Department++Swine+flu+spreading&referrer=FRONTPAGECAROUSEL |title=Vt. Health Department: Swine flu spreading |publisher=The Burlington Free Press |date=June 9, 2009 |accessdate=February 5, 2010 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Virginia== The Virginia Department of Health had confirmed 14 cases in the state by May 7, and a total of 23 by May 21. The VDH reports cases by Health district, often without narrowing down a specific county, citing [[HIPAA]] privacy laws, as well as a desire to avoid creating a "false sense of security".{{cite web|url=http://www.vdh.virginia.gov/news/Alerts/SwineFlu/FAQs.htm |title=VDH Swine flu FAQ |publisher=Vdh.virginia.gov |accessdate=May 19, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090520210841/http://www.vdh.virginia.gov/news/Alerts/SwineFlu/FAQs.htm| archivedate= May 20, 2009 | deadurl= no}} 12 of the cases have been reported for the district containing [[Lexington, Virginia|Lexington]], Virginia, following an early outbreak on the campus of [[Washington and Lee University]]. Additionally, there have been three cases in Fairfax, two each in the Chesterfield, Arlington and Peninsula Health districts, and one each in the Norfolk and Three Rivers Health districts.{{cite web|url=http://www.vdh.virginia.gov/news/Alerts/SwineFlu/ConfirmedCases.htm |title=Virginia Department of Health swine flu update |publisher=Vdh.virginia.gov |date=May 15, 2009 |accessdate=May 19, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090520211021/http://www.vdh.virginia.gov/news/Alerts/SwineFlu/ConfirmedCases.htm| archivedate= May 20, 2009 | deadurl= no}} Currently, at least 35 deaths resulting from confirmed A/H1N1 influenza have been reported in Virginia. ==Washington== As of October 16, 2009, the [[Washington State Department of Health]] (WSDOH) reported 174 hospitalizations and 16 deaths between April 26, 2009 and September 19, 2009, and further reported 7 additional deaths and 163 additional hospitalizations from September 19, 2009 to October 16, 2009.Washington State Department of Health [http://www.doh.wa.gov/h1n1/h1n1_newsroom.htm H1N1 Newsroom.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091014195513/http://www.doh.wa.gov/h1n1/h1n1_newsroom.htm |date=October 14, 2009 }} All the recent fatal cases and the cases resulting in hospitalizations were spread fairly equally across Western and Eastern Washington. As of September 9, 2009, the WSDOH reported 164 hospitalized persons confirmed with 2009 H1N1, and 16 total deaths.Washington State Department of Health, Flu Update, 2009 CDC Week 35 (8/30-9/5), Quick Notes.[http://www.doh.wa.gov/EHSPHL/Epidemiology/CD/fluupdate.htm] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090910182452/http://www.doh.wa.gov/EHSPHL/Epidemiology/CD/fluupdate.htm |date=September 10, 2009 }} In its August 28, 2009 report, the WSDOH reported that it would no longer issue updates of the numbers of probable or confirmed cases, but would instead issue reports of state lab-confirmed H1N1 (swine flu) total hospitalizations and deaths. Accordingly, the WSDOH reports that from April 26, 2009 to August 28, 2009 the total number of hospitalizations was 154, and as of August 28, 2009 the total number of deaths stood at 14.WSDOH, Monitoring H1N1 (swine flu): [http://www.doh.wa.gov/swineflu/default.htm#current Hospitalizations and deaths] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090624211026/http://www.doh.wa.gov/swineflu/Default.htm |date=June 24, 2009 }} ===Deaths=== On June 18, 2009, A King County swine flu-related death was reported, making it the third death from swine flu in Washington State. On June 5, A Pierce County woman in her twenties became Washington's second swine flu-related death. On May 9, it was announced that a man from Snohomish County, in his thirties with a pre-existing heart condition and active viral [[pneumonia]], became the third confirmed US death from swine flu-involved complications. As of January 23, there have been 1383 confirmed cases of H1N1N that required hospital care in the second wave of H1N1 (since September 19, 2009), and 76 deaths.{{cite web|url=http://www.doh.wa.gov/h1n1/h1n1_newsroom.htm |accessdate=October 20, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091014195513/http://www.doh.wa.gov/h1n1/h1n1_newsroom.htm |archivedate=October 14, 2009|title=H1N1 Swine Flu - H1N1 News Room }} ===Cases=== On July 1, 2009, it was reported that the Tri-Cities had its first case of swine flu. On June 18, 2009, [[Grant County, Washington|Grant County]] Health Department reported six cases of swine flu in [[Quincy, Washington|Quincy]]. As of the evening of May 22, 2009, Washington state has reported 574 confirmed cases and one death due to swine flu. The health department has since no longer reported anymore cases; however, it has reported seven deaths as of July 24.{{cite web|url=http://www.king5.com/localnews/stories/NW_050709HEB-wash-swine-flu-thursday-TP.2e8edbf.html |title=10 more confirmed WA swine flu cases |author=King5.com Staff |date=May 7, 2009 |work=King5.com |accessdate=May 8, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090511105033/http://www.king5.com/localnews/stories/NW_050709HEB-wash-swine-flu-thursday-TP.2e8edbf.html |archivedate=May 11, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} So far, confirmed cases have been identified in seventeen Washington state counties, with public facilities closed as a precaution in those counties and several others. On May 3, Seattle-King County officials announced that, due to the virus' widespread presence in the community and low rates of severity, schools would no longer be closing due to suspect or probable cases. A majority of confirmed cases (584) have occurred in [[King County, Washington|King County]]. 115 confirmed cases, one probable case, and one death have been reported in [[Snohomish County, Washington|Snohomish County]]. Thirty-one confirmed cases have also been identified in [[Pierce County, Washington|Pierce County]], while seven cases of swine flu have been confirmed in [[Clark County, Washington|Clark County]], bordering the city of [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]], Oregon. [[Thurston County, Washington|Thurston County]] and [[Yakima County, Washington|Yakima County]] have reported five cases each. [[Spokane County, Washington|Spokane County]] and [[Whatcom County, Washington|Whatcom County]] have reported four cases each. [[Kitsap County, Washington|Kitsap County]] and [[Mason County, Washington|Mason County]] have each reported three cases. Two cases have been reported in [[Island County, Washington|Island County]] and [[Skagit County, Washington|Skagit County]]. One case each has been reported in [[Douglas County, Washington|Douglas County]], [[Grays Harbor County, Washington|Grays Harbor County]], [[Jefferson County, Washington|Jefferson County]], [[Kittitas County, Washington|Kittitas County]] and [[Lewis County, Washington|Lewis County]]. An additional case, that of a cruise ship worker, is counted at the state level only. September 19, 2009, the Washington department of health stopped counting individual cases of A/H1N1 influenza, and only counting hospitalizations and deaths from A/H1N1. ==West Virginia== As of July 22, there have been 276 reported cases.{{cite web|url=http://www.wvidep.org/AZIndexofInfectiousDiseases/Influenza/InfluenzaSeason0809/tabid/1747/Default.aspx |title=Influenza Surveillance Data 2008–2009 |publisher=West Virginia – Department of Health and Human Resources |accessdate=June 23, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090624214059/http://www.wvidep.org/AZIndexofInfectiousDiseases/Influenza/InfluenzaSeason0809/tabid/1747/Default.aspx |archivedate=June 24, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} In November 2009, it was confirmed a West Virginia pediatrician had confirmed A/H1N1 influenza twice, once in July, and again in October. This is very rare, but does occur sporadically, according to the CDC. ==Wisconsin== As of July 22, 2009, Wisconsin has 5,147 confirmed cases, including 3,278 in Milwaukee.[http://pandemic.wisconsin.gov/ H1N1 Flu (Swine Flu) Information]. Wisconsin Department of Health Services Pandemic Influenza Program. May 22, 2009 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090624210950/http://pandemic.wisconsin.gov/ |date=June 24, 2009 }} most of which are in the southern and south-eastern region of the state. So far, cases have been confirmed in 24 counties, however Milwaukee, Dane, Waukesha, and Columbia have the majority of the cases, with 706, 90, 54, and 52 respectively. As of May 24, 2009, Wisconsin currently has the most confirmed cases of swine flu in the United States. On June 1, 2009, it was confirmed that a Milwaukee resident with underlying health issues died from the virus. Two Wisconsin residents have died from the virus. As of Friday June 12, 2009 there were 3,008 confirmed and probable cases and one death in Wisconsin reported by the CDC.[http://www.bizjournals.com/phoenix/stories/2009/06/08/daily67.html ''Phoenix Business Journal'', June 12, 2009] As of Friday June 19, 2009 the CDC reported no change of these numbers. ===Milwaukee=== As of Friday, June 12, 2009, the largest city in Wisconsin, [[Milwaukee]], reported the second death and 1,883 confirmed cases of swine flu.{{cite web|url=http://www.milwaukee.gov/PressReleasesMediaAdvisories3505.htm |title=MHD Press Releases & Media Advisories |publisher=Milwaukee Health Department |accessdate=June 21, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091105043846/http://www.milwaukee.gov/PressReleasesMediaAdvisories3505.htm |archivedate=November 5, 2009 }} As of Tuesday, June 16, 2009, the city of Milwaukee reported the third death related to the novel flu and more than 2,000 confirmed cases in Milwaukee. As of Thursday, June 18, 2009, Milwaukee reported 2,618 confirmed cases.{{cite web|url=http://www.milwaukee.gov/2009SwineFlu |title=City of Milwaukee Case Counts |publisher=Milwaukee Health Department |accessdate=June 21, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090505052112/http://www.milwaukee.gov/2009SwineFlu |archivedate=May 5, 2009 }} The CDC update seems not to reflect the rising of case toll from 1,883 (June 12) to 2,618 (June 18) in the city of Milwaukee. ===Dane County=== [[Dane County]] reported 300 confirmed cases as of Thursday June 18, 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.publichealthmdc.com/disease/swineFlu/ |title=H1N1 outbreak (swine flu) |publisher=Public Health Madison and Dane County |date=June 18, 2009 |accessdate=June 21, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090515162049/http://www.publichealthmdc.com/disease/swineFlu/ |archivedate=May 15, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} ===Columbia County=== [[Columbia County, Wisconsin|Columbia County]] reported 68 confirmed cases as of June 5, 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.co.columbia.wi.us/ColumbiaCounty/Portals/7/Public%20Health/PressreleaseCambriaschoolsJune12009.pdf |title=One Laboratory Confirmed Case of H1N1 (Swine Flu) Cambria –Friesland Elementary School Student (swine flu) |publisher=Health and Human Services |date=June 1, 2009 |accessdate=June 21, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716094423/http://www.co.columbia.wi.us/ColumbiaCounty/Portals/7/Public%20Health/PressreleaseCambriaschoolsJune12009.pdf |archivedate=July 16, 2011 }} ==Wyoming== [[File:2009 Wyoming Swine Flu.png|thumb|right|{{legend|#000000|Death(s) confirmed}}{{legend|#cd3412|Case(s) confirmed}}{{legend|#eaa912|Case(s) unconfirmed (probable)}}]] As of August 27, 2009, the [[Wyoming Department of Health]] reported 171 lab-confirmed cases of H1N1.Wyoming Department of Health [http://wdh.state.wy.us/phsd/epiid/swineflu.html Swine (novel H1N1) Influenza Cases in Wyoming] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090712134057/http://wdh.state.wy.us/phsd/epiid/swineflu.html |date=July 12, 2009 }} On August 19, 2009 the Wyoming Department of Health confirmed Wyoming's first death from H1N1 of a state resident infected with the swine flu (novel H1N1) virus as a victim who was a young adult female resident of [[Fremont County, Wyoming|Fremont County]] with an underlying health condition associated with higher risk of complications from influenza.Wyoming Department of Health, Swine Flu-Related Death Confirmed in Wyoming, August 19, 2009.[http://wdh.state.wy.us/news.aspx?NewsID=313]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} As of July 21, there have been 106 confirmed cases of swine flu in [[Wyoming]].{{cite web |url=http://wdh.state.wy.us/phsd/epiid/swineflu.html |title=Swine Influenza (Swine Flu) |publisher=Wyoming Department of Health |date=May 27, 2009 |accessdate=June 23, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090712134057/http://wdh.state.wy.us/phsd/epiid/swineflu.html |archivedate=July 12, 2009 }} ==See also== *[[2009 flu pandemic in the United States]] {{clear right}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== ===State governments=== *[http://www.adph.org/H1N1Flu/index.asp?ID=3571 Alabama Department of Public Health] homepage on Novel A/09(H1N1) *[http://www.azdhs.gov/flu/h1n1/index.htm Arizona Department of Health Services] daily updates *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090626005321/http://www.cdph.ca.gov/Pages/default.aspx California Department of Public Health] provides updates on Swine Flu *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090624211041/http://health.state.ga.us/h1n1flu/ Georgia Department of Human Services – Division of Public Health] *[http://healthalerts.ky.gov/Pages/default.aspx Kentucky Cabinet for Health and Family Services] *[http://www.dhh.louisiana.gov/offices/default-145.asp?ID=145 Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals] – A/H1N1 (2009 Swine Flu) updates and links *[http://www.michigan.gov/mdch/0,1607,7-132-2940_2955_22779_53388-213600--,00.html Michigan Dept of Community Health] updates with county breakdowns posted daily at 4:30 pm EDT *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090923202228/http://www.msdh.state.ms.us/msdhsite/_static/14%2C0%2C334.html Mississippi State Department of Health] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090624210955/http://www.dhss.mo.gov/BT_Response/_SwineFlu09.html Missouri Department of Health and Senior Services] Swine Flu Updates *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090526224748/http://www.hhs.state.ne.us/H1N1flu/cases.htm Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services] *[http://www.health.state.ny.us/ New York State Department of Public Health] provides updates on Swine Flu *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090515183938/http://www.ncdhhs.gov/pressrel/2009/2009-4-30-swineflucases.htm North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090624210954/http://www.odh.ohio.gov/landing/phs_emergency/swineflu.aspx Ohio Department of Health] *[http://www.scdhec.gov/flu/swine-flu.htm South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090514221330/http://doh.sd.gov/SwineFlu.aspx South Dakota Department of Health] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090621172232/http://health.state.tn.us/swineflu.htm Tennessee Department of Health] *[http://www.dshs.state.tx.us/swineflu/default.shtm Texas Department of State Health Services] provides updates on Swine Flu and a county breakdown of confirmed cases *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090502155537/http://health.utah.gov/epi/SwineFlu/ Utah Bureau of Epidemology] Swine Flu *[http://healthvermont.gov/panflu/SwineFlu.aspx Vermont Department of Health] Swine Flu Outbreak *[http://www.vdh.state.va.us/epidemiology/DiseasePrevention/H1N1/index.htm Virginia Dept of Health] – Provides updates on influenza A (H1N1) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090624213204/http://doh.dc.gov/doh/site/default.asp Washington, DC Department of Health] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090624211026/http://www.doh.wa.gov/swineflu/Default.htm Washington State Department of Health] Swine Flu Information *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090504021447/http://www.wvidep.org/Home/HotTopicSwineInfluenza/tabid/1856/default.aspx West Virginia Bureau for Public Health] Swine Influenza *[http://pandemic.wisconsin.gov/ Wisconsin Pandemic Flu Resource] {{2009 flu pandemic}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2009 Flu Pandemic In The United States By State}} [[Category:2009 disasters in the United States|Flu Pandemic In The United States By State, 2009]] [[Category:2009 flu pandemic by country|United States]] [[Category:2009 in the United States by state|Flu pandemic]] [[Category:Health in the United States by state]] [[es:Pandemia de gripe A (H1N1) de 2009-2010 en Estados Unidos#Estados infectados]]

revision.text:
'''Amir Hannan''' is an English [[physician|doctor]] who works as a [[General Practitioner]] in [[Tameside]] and has pioneered patients having access to their [[Electronic health record]]s in the English National Health Service.<ref>{{cite news|title=Paperless NHS supplement: Technology – instant access|url=http://www.hsj.co.uk/resource-centre/supplements/paperless-nhs-supplement-technology-instant-access/5083142.article#.VTzCWIq4_eM |first=Matthew |last=Shelley |accessdate=26 April 2015|work=[[Health Service Journal]] |date=13 March 2015}}</ref>
He grew up in a family of doctors – his mother was a gynaecologist who later became a GP.<ref>{{cite news|title=Q&A: patient access pioneer Dr Amir Hannan|url=http://www.hsj.co.uk/home/innovation-and-efficiency/innovation-network/qa-patient-access-pioneer-dr-amir-hannan/5065505.article#.VTzNdIq4_eM|accessdate=26 April 2015|publisher=Health Service Journal|date=28 November 2013}}</ref>
Hannan is a board member of the Tameside and Glossop [[Clinical Commissioning Group]].
==General practice== He took over Haughton Thornley Medical Centres in [[Hyde, Greater Manchester|Hyde]] which was formerly run by Dr [[Harold Shipman]] when he started his career. The practice has a large Bengali population. It is a very deprived neighbourhood. He saw opening records to patients as a way of rebuilding trust in a difficult situation.<ref>{{cite news|title=Increasing access to patient records|url=http://www.nursingtimes.net/increasing-access-to-patient-records/5062710.article|accessdate=26 April 2015|work=[[Nursing Times]]|date=30 August 2013}}</ref> He told the BBC: "The week before I started there was a sit-down protest in the waiting room, because the patients were not happy about this doctor that was being foisted on them. That gives you some idea of the battlefield I was walking into." 150 patients at the practice were given access to their medical records and test results over the internet in 2007.<ref>{{cite news|title=Web records prove hit with patients|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/6323587.stm|accessdate=26 April 2015|work=[[BBC News]]|date=5 February 2007}}</ref> Prof [[Steve Field (medical doctor)|Steve Field]] of the [[Care Quality Commission]] recounted: “It was very difficult to recruit to Shipman’s practice because of [the lack of] trust locally. But Amir said, ‘Right from the start I will share everything with my patients, and gave them access to all their own records. He’s got examples of patients being admitted to hospital where they have had to show the consultants their record which may have saved their lives. It’s policy to try and make it happen. But it’s not moving quickly enough.”<ref>{{cite news|title=Failure to join up medical records is a 'health risk’, says GP chief inspector|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-families/health-news/failure-to-join-up-medical-records-is-a-health-risk-says-gp-chief-inspector-9707356.html|accessdate=30 November 2014|work=[[The Independent]]|date=2 September 2014}}</ref> {{As of|2015|May}}, 34% of the patient population were accessing to their GP record. There was no difference between the proportion of Bengali patients doing so and the rest of the practice population.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rising Stars: Inspiring campaign promises self care|url=http://www.hsj.co.uk/resource-centre/supplements/rising-stars-inspiring-campaign-promises-self-care/5084979.article#.VX1bxba_UYA|accessdate=14 June 2015|publisher=Health Service Journal|date=13 May 2015}}</ref>
==Record access==
He was one of the first GPs pioneering [[Patient record access]] using [[Egton Medical Information Systems|EMIS]] software. He says "there are some doctors and nurses who have genuine concerns about patients suddenly being let loose to access their records without any controls in place or without clinicians having to do anything and a feeling of irresponsibility that that raises."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hannan|first1=Amir|title=BACK TO SCHOOL FOR DOCTORS, NURSES AND PATIENTS|url=http://www.htmc.co.uk/displayarticle.asp?a=5&c=3|website=Amir Hannan's Blog|accessdate=12 December 2014}}</ref> Jacqui Gladwin, a nursing lecturer who is one of his patients, was worried about online access. She asked:"What happens if patients see information that is incorrect? How safe is the system? What happens if they see something distressing when the surgery is closed?" She was surprised to find that other patients in the practice did not share her worries. At a meeting at the practice to discuss the development of records access, several patients had found errors in their records. They were positive about being able to identify errors and the response they had received when they reported them. They felt trusted to own the information, and secure when travelling abroad that they could allow other health professionals to access their medical information.<ref>{{cite news|title=Increasing access to patient records|url=http://www.nursingtimes.net/increasing-access-to-patient-records/5062710.article |first=Jacqui |last=Gladwin|accessdate=26 April 2015|work=Nursing Times|date=30 August 2013}}</ref>
He speaks regularly about the benefits of giving patients access to their full GP electronic health records, and about how this works at his practice.<ref>{{cite news|title=Realising the potential of primary care|url=http://www.kingsfund.org.uk/events/realising-potential-primary-care|accessdate=26 April 2015|publisher=Kings Fund|date=25 September 2014}}</ref> And in 2008 he authored the Patient Access to Medical Records pattern<ref>{{cite web|title=Patient Access to Medical Records|url=http://www.publicsphereproject.org/content/patient-access-medical-records|website=Public Sphere Project|accessdate=1 November 2015|date=2008}}</ref> of the Liberating Voices [[pattern language]].
Research in which Hannan participated showed that practices who give at least a third of their patients full online access to their records could experience a decrease in appointment demand of up to 12%. Dr Brian Fisher, one of the other participants in the study conceded that as the practices concerned were leaders in their field with regard to offering online access to medical records, it could be difficult to extrapolate the results.<ref>{{cite news|title=Giving patients online records access 'cuts appointment demand by 12%'|url=http://www.pulsetoday.co.uk/your-practice/practice-topics/it/giving-patients-online-records-access-cuts-appointment-demand-by-12/20002460.article#.VTzF94q4_eM|accessdate=26 April 2015|work=[[Pulse (magazine)|Pulse]] |date=3 April 2013}}</ref>
He has defended the government's [[Summary Care Record]] project, which has been criticised by other GPs on the grounds of cost. Each time an SCR was accessed for a patient in 2012 it cost £1,200. He says "The SCR isn’t a panacea, it’s just one solution".<ref>{{cite news|title='Pull the plug' on Summary Care Records, says GPC IT lead|url=http://www.pulsetoday.co.uk/pull-the-plug-on-summary-care-records-says-gpc-it-lead/20001851.article#.VTzHDIq4_eM|accessdate=26 April 2015|publisher=Pulse|date=14 February 2013}}</ref> He was, however, critical of the [[Health and Social Care Information Centre|care.data]] fiasco, saying "If patients felt that their data was leaking out, and I had not warned them about it, then that would destroy my relationship with them."<ref>{{cite news|title=Dr Amir Hannan: 'This goes to the very heart of the doctor-patient relationship'|url=http://www.pulsetoday.co.uk/your-practice/practice-topics/it/dr-amir-hannan-this-goes-to-the-very-heart-of-the-doctor-patient-relationship/20005677.article#.VTzMXoq4_eM|accessdate=26 April 2015|publisher=Pulse|date=28 January 2014}}</ref>
He was ranked in the [[Health Service Journal]]'s list of Clinical Leaders in 2015.<ref>{{cite news|title=HSJ Clinical Leaders 2015|url=http://www.hsj.co.uk/leadership/top-leaders/clinical-leaders/hsj-clinical-leaders-2015/5087348.article#.Vd9s_JZIgYA|accessdate=27 August 2015|publisher=Health Service Journal|date=6 July 2015}}</ref>
==References==
{{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.htmc.co.uk/displayarticle.asp?a=5&c=3 Amir Hannan's Blog]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hannan, Amir}} [[Category:21st-century English medical doctors]] [[Category:British general practitioners]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Health informaticians]]

{{Infobox hospital
| Name = Belize Medical Associates | Org/Group = <!-- Org or group that owns/manages the hospital --> | Image = <!-- Preferably a pic of the main building or entrance --> | image alt = | Caption = <!-- optional --> | map_type = | latitude = <!-- used only for adding a map, with map_type --> | longitude = <!-- used only for adding a map, with map_type --> | map_caption = <!-- Optional. Gives a small caption under the map such as "Shown in region, country" --> | Logo = <!-- Please conform to copyright --> | Logo Size = <!-- Use to limit the logo size --> | Location = 5791 St. Thomas Street | Region = Kings' Park, Belize City | State = <!-- optional UK: England, Wales, Scotland, Northern Ireland. US: The US State - NB autolinked --> | Country = Belize | Coordinates = {{coord|17.508|-88.194|display=inline,title}} | HealthCare = <!-- UK:NHS. AU/CA: Medicare. ELSE freetext, e.g. Private --> | Funding = <!-- Non-profit, For-profit, Government, Public - will generate linka --> | Type = <!-- Community, District, General, District General, Teaching, Specialist --> | Speciality = <!-- if devoted to a speciality (ie not a broad spectrum of specialities) and Type=Specialist/Teaching --> | Standards = <!-- optional if no national standards --> | Emergency = <!-- UK/IR/HK/SG: Yes/No, CA/IL/US: I/II/III/IV/V for Trauma certification level --> | Helipad = <!-- Yes, No, or use "Template:Airport codes" with p=n. Only list if verifiable, leave blank if unknown. --> | Affiliation = <!-- 'None' or Medical School and University affiliations (medical or paramedical) --> | Patron = <!-- 'None' or the individual who acts as the hospital patron --> | Network = <!-- Hospital network, non-owner --> | Beds = 25 | Founded = 1988 | Closed = <!-- Use if defunct, please also add to Category:Defunct hospitals --> | Website = <!-- 'None' or http URL --> | Wiki-Links = <!-- Creates ""See also" field --> }} ''' Belize Medical Associates''' is a private hospital in [[Belize City]], [[Belize]]. It was developed in 1988, as a single clinic.<ref name="Silver Anniversary">{{cite news|title=Private Medical Facility Celebrates Silver Anniversary|url=http://www.lovetv.com.bz/private-medical-facility-celebrates-silver-anniversary/|accessdate=12 October 2015|publisher=Love Television|date=23 August 2013|location=Belize City, Belize}}</ref> A decade after they opened, in 1998, they changed from a private clinic into a small hospital featuring two surgical theaters and 18 beds.<ref name="converts to hospital">{{cite news|title=Medical Associates expands into hospital|url=http://edition.channel5belize.com/archives/24059|accessdate=12 October 2015|publisher=Channel 5 Belize|date=6 November 1998|location=Belize City, Belize}}</ref> Belize's first female architect, [[Esther Ayuso]] worked on the hospital expansion.<ref name="Guardian profile">{{cite news|title=Trailblazer Tuesday's brings you Belize's first female architect Ms. Esther Ayuso!|url=http://guardian.bz/archives/8111-trailblazer-belizes-first-female-architect-|accessdate=11 October 2015|publisher=The El Guardian|date=17 July 2014|location=Belize City, Belize}}</ref> By 2010, a subsequent expansion had created space for 25 beds.<ref name="2nd expansion">{{cite book|last1=Sluder|first1=Lan|title=Easy Belize : how to live, retire, work and buy property in Belize, the English speaking, frost free paradise on the Caribbean coast|date=2010|publisher=Equator Publishing|location=Asheville, NC|isbn=978-1-451-50101-8|page=122|edition=Rev. and fully updated.|url=https://books.google.com.mx/books?id=Zxmuu7MrJT8C&lpg=PA122&ots=_yzSmWoUk8&dq=belize%20medical%20associates%2C%20expansion&pg=PA122#v=onepage&q=belize%20medical%20associates,%20expansion&f=false|accessdate=12 October 2015}}</ref>
==Facilities== The hospital is located at 5791 St. Thomas Street, Kings Park in Belize City.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://belize-guide.info/travel.basics/health.and.medical/ |title=Belize Guide listing}}</ref>
It currently provides: *24-hour emergency service *Modern 25-bed Hospital *Well Stocked Pharmacy *Advanced Laboratory *Modern [[radiology]] services *Fully equipped [[operating theater]] *Multi-specialist & Primary Care Clinics *Cardiac Care Unit *Neurological Unit
Its stated mission is :"To provide the Highest Quality Health Care Service in Belize that is Complete, Affordable and done in an Ethical Manner."
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Belize-hospital-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''Boston School of Occupational Therapy''' is an American [[college]] offering [[Academic degree|degree]] programs in [[occupational therapy]]. It is part of the [[Tufts University School of Arts and Sciences]]. It was founded in 1918 at the request of the surgeon general of the United States Army, and became affiliated to Tufts University in 1945.<ref name="BSOT History">{{cite web|title=History of the Occupational Therapy Department at Tufts|url=http://ase.tufts.edu/bsot/aboutHistory.htm|work=Tufts University|accessdate=2011-12-30}}</ref>
==Rankings== The Boston School of Occupational Therapy (BSOT) was ranked #6 in 2016, according to the ''[[US News & World Report]]''{{'s}} Best Occupational Therapy Programs.<ref name="US News OT Rankings">{{cite web|title=Best Occupational Therapy Programs|url=http://grad-schools.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-graduate-schools/top-health-schools/occupational-therapy-rankings|work=Best Occupational Therapy Programs Rankings|publisher=US News & World Report|accessdate=2016-11-15}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Occupational therapy organisations]] [[Category:Tufts University]]

{{Infobox hospital | name = Bryce Hospital | org/group = <!-- optional --> | logo = <!-- optional --> | logo_size = | image = Bryce Hospital by Highsmith 01.jpg | image_size = 260 | caption = Front of Administration Building, the first and oldest building on campus, completed in 1859. | map_type = | map_caption = | coordinates = {{coord|33.21626|-87.53831|region:US-AL|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | location = | region = [[Tuscaloosa, Alabama|Tuscaloosa]] | state = [[Alabama]] | country = US <!--needed for infobox--> | healthcare = Public | type = Specialist | speciality = [[Psychiatric hospital]] | standards = <!-- optional if no national standards --> | emergency = <!-- UK/IR/HK/SG: Yes/No, CA/US: I/II/III for Trauma certification level --> | affiliation = <!-- Medical School and University affiliations (medical or paramedical) --> | beds = 268 | founded = 1861 | closed = <!-- optional --> | website = <!-- {{URL|www.example.org}} --> | other_links = <!-- optional --> | nrhp = {{Infobox NRHP | embed = yes | name = Alabama Insane Hospital | nrhp_type = | image = | caption = | location = University Blvd., [[Tuscaloosa, Alabama]] | locmapin = Alabama#USA | area = {{convert|17|acre|0}} | built = 1853–59 | architect = Sloan, Samuel, et al.; Stewart | architecture = Mixed (more than 2 styles from different periods), Italianate, Roman Revival | governing_body = State | refnum = 77000216<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|version=2010a}}</ref> | added = April 18, 1977 }} }}
'''Bryce Hospital''', opened in 1861 in [[Tuscaloosa, Alabama]], [[United States]], is Alabama's oldest and largest inpatient psychiatric facility. First known as the '''Alabama State Hospital for the Insane'''<ref name="bridging">{{Cite book | last = Lupold | first = John S. | authorlink = |author2=Thomas L. French | title = Bridging deep south rivers: the life and legend of Horace King | publisher = U of Georgia P | year = 2004 | location = | page = 137 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=QfNYX7ImtVUC&pg=PA137 | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-8203-2626-9}}</ref> and later as the '''Alabama Insane Hospital''', the building is considered an architectural model.<ref>Carla Yanni, ''The Architecture of Madness: Insane Asylums in the United States'', Minneapolis: Minnesota University Press, 2007, 59-64</ref> The hospital currently houses 268 beds for acute care, treatment and rehabilitation of full-time (committed) patients. The Mary Starke Harper Geriatric Psychiatry Hospital, a separate facility on the same campus, provides an additional 100 beds for inpatient geriatric care. The main facility was added to the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1977.<ref name="nris"/>
==History== The plans for a state hospital for the mentally ill in Alabama began in 1852. The new facility was planned from the start to utilize the "moral architecture" concepts of 1830s activists [[Thomas Story Kirkbride]] and [[Dorothea Dix]]. Dix's reformist ideas, in particular, are credited as the driving force behind the construction of the hospital. Architect [[Samuel Sloan (architect)|Samuel Sloan]] designed the Italianate building using the [[Kirkbride Plan]]. Construction of the building began in 1853 but was not completed until 1859. The hospital was the first building in Tuscaloosa with gas lighting and central heat,<ref name="EOA">{{cite web | title=Bryce Hospital (Alabama Insane Hospital) | url=http://encyclopediaofalabama.org/face/Article.jsp?id=h-1564 | last=Weaver |first=Bill | publisher=The Encyclopedia of Alabama | date=June 5, 2008 | accessdate=March 26, 2009}}</ref> "all clad in a fashionable Italianate exterior."<ref name="bridging"/>
The Alabama Insane Hospital opened in 1861. It was later renamed for its first superintendent, Peter Bryce, who had first begun as a 27-year-old [[Psychiatry|psychiatric]] pioneer from [[South Carolina]]. Bryce had been brought to the attention of the hospital trustees by Dix. He had studied mental-health care in Europe and worked in psychiatric hospitals in [[New Jersey]], as well as his native state of South Carolina.<ref name="EOA"/> His tenure was marked by absolute discipline among the staff of the hospital. He demanded that patients be given courtesy, kindness and respect at all times. The use of shackles, [[straitjacket]]s and other restraints was discouraged, and finally abandoned altogether in 1882. Various work programs and other activities were encouraged, including farming, sewing, maintenance and crafts. Between 1872 and the early 1880s, some of the patients wrote and edited their own newspaper, called ''[[The Meteor]]''. These writings provide a rare inside look at life in a progressive mental institution in the late 19th century. At that time, Bryce's management and commitment to "scientific treatments" was recognized around the country as being in a class of its own.
==Decline== During the 20th century, the patient population expanded while standards of care fell to abysmal levels. Alabama Governor [[Lurleen Wallace]] viewed the facility in February 1967, and was moved to tears after an overweight, mentally challenged nine-year-old attempted to hug her, crying, "Mama! Mama!" She lobbied her husband, [[George Wallace]] (who held the actual power of her governorship) for more funds for the institution.<ref name="Carter">{{Cite book | last = Carter | first = Dan T. | authorlink = | title = The politics of rage: George Wallace, the origins of the new conservatism, and the transformation of American politics | publisher = Louisiana State UP | year = 2000 | location = Baton Rouge | page = 336 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=XJWtbRNdoqgC&pg=PA336 | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-8071-2597-7}}</ref>
In 1970, Alabama ranked last among [[U.S. state]]s in funding for mental health. Bryce Hospital at that time had 5,200 patients living in conditions that a ''[[Montgomery Advertiser]]'' editor likened to a [[concentration camp]]. That same year, a [[cigarette]] tax earmarked for mental-health treatment was cut. One hundred Bryce employees were laid off, including twenty professional staff. Members of the Department of Psychology at the [[University of Alabama]] attempted to file suit on behalf of the laid-off workers, but Federal Judge [[Frank Minis Johnson|Frank M. Johnson]] ruled that the courts had no standing to intervene on behalf of fired employees. He left open, however, the possibility of a suit filed on behalf of patients, whose quality of care was affected.
==''Wyatt v. Stickney''==
In October 1970, Ricky Wyatt, a fifteen-year-old who had always been labeled a "juvenile delinquent" and housed at Bryce despite not being indicated with a mental illness, became the named plaintiff in a [[class-action]] lawsuit.<ref name="Wyatt">{{citation | url=http://www.encyclopediaofalabama.org/article/h-2375 | title=Encyclopedia of Alabama | year=2009}}</ref> His aunt, W. C. Rawlins, was one of the employees who had been laid off. Together they testified about intolerable conditions and improper treatments designed only to make the patients more manageable. In 1971 the plaintiff class was expanded to include patients at Alabama's two other inpatient mental health facilities, [[Searcy Hospital]] ([[Mount Vernon, Alabama|Mt. Vernon]]) and Camp Partlow ([[Coker, Alabama|Coker]]). The resulting court-ordered agreements formed the basis for federal minimum standards for the care of people with mental illness or mental retardations who reside in institutional settings. In 1999 a new [[settlement agreement]] was made, recognizing a great deal of progress. The case was finally dismissed on December 5, 2003, with the finding by Judge [[Myron Thompson]] that Alabama was in compliance with the agreement.
The standards elaborated in that agreement have served as a model nationwide. Known as the "Wyatt Standards," they are founded on four criteria for evaluation of care: * Humane psychological and physical environment * Qualified and sufficient staff for administration of treatment * Individualized treatment plans * Minimum restriction of patient freedom.
The case of ''Wyatt v. Stickney'' came to a conclusion after 33 years, through the tenure of nine Alabama governors and fourteen state mental health commissioners, the longest mental health case in national history. The State of Alabama estimates its litigation expenses at over $15 million.<ref name="Wyatt"/>
==Future of Bryce Hospital==
Gov. [[Bob Riley]] announced on December 30, 2009 that Bryce Hospital was to relocate into a newly constructed facility across McFarland Boulevard in Tuscaloosa, and the [[University of Alabama]] would take over the current Bryce campus. For several years the university had sought the {{convert|180|acre|sing=on}} parcel of land, which is adjacent to its landlocked campus.<ref name="tuscnews1">Bryce Hospital to remain in [[Tuscaloosa, Alabama|Tuscaloosa]], [http://www.tuscaloosanews.com/article/20091230/NEWS/912309997/1007?p=1&tc=pg]</ref>
Riley said that a hospital for about 268 patients had been envisioned but the final size was yet to be determined. The deal, approved by Gov. Bob Riley and the [[Alabama Department of Mental Health]] on December 30, 2009 was worth $72 million in cash for Mental Health to build a replacement hospital. The university will pay $50 million in cash and Mental Health will get another $22 million in state bond money. The university pledged another $10 million to clean up environmental problems on the Bryce grounds and restore the main hospital building, construction of which started in 1853.<ref name="tuscnews1"/>
The sale of Bryce Hospital and Harper Center to UA was finalized on May 27, 2010 at a price of $87.75 million. $77 million would go to installments plus the aforementioned $10 million for ground improvements.<ref>http://blog.al.com/spotnews/2010/05/88_million_sale_of_bryce_hospi.html November 5, 2017</ref> In 2014, the remaining patients were moved to a new facility and UA began a restoration project estimated at $40 million. Dan Wolfe, University of Alabama planner, revealed the two buildings will house a welcome center, two museums focusing on mental health and the history of the university, event space and classrooms for performing arts students. The project is expected to be complete by 2020.<ref>http://www.al.com/living/index.ssf/2016/06/inside_the_spooky_skeleton_of.html November 5, 2017</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery> File:Bryce Hospital by Highsmith 06.jpg|Entrance gate to the campus File:Bryce State Hospital Tuscaloosa Alabama USA.jpg|Detail of front portico on the Administration Building Image:Brycehospital.jpg|A postcard depicting Bryce Hospital around the turn of the 20th century Image:Bryceh1.jpg|Abandoned building on the campus Image:Bryceh4.jpg|Admission building, where most patients are located </gallery>
==See also== *{{Commons category-inline|Bryce State Mental Hospital (Kirkbride Plan building)|Bryce Hospital}} * [[Alabama Department of Mental Health]] * [[Bazelon Center for Mental Health Law]] * ''[[The Meteor]]'', an internal paper published by the residents of Bryce Hospital between 1872 and 1881.
==Further reading== *Robert O. Mellown. (Spring 1994). "Mental Health and Moral Architecture." ''Alabama Heritage.'' Issue #32. *Rev. Joseph Camp. (1882) ''An Insight into an Insane Asylum.'', self-published "exposé" of conditions at Bryce. *John S. Hughes, editor (1993). ''The Letters of a Victorian Madwoman.'' Columbia, SC: University of South Carolina Press. {{ISBN|0-87249-840-9}}, the letters of Andrew Sheffield giving details of a woman's life at Bryce at the end of the 19th century. *Bill L. Weaver (January 1996) "Survival at the Alabama Insane Hospital, 1861-1892," ''Journal of the History of Medicine and Allied Sciences.'' 51, pages 5–28.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * Burt Rieff. (April 1999) "Meteor: The "remarkable enterprise" at the Alabama Insane Hospital, 1872-1881", ''The Alabama Review,'' [http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3880/is_199904/ai_n8846619] - accessed August 23, 2005. * Clarence J. Sundram. (2003) "Wyatt v. Stickney - A Long Odyssey Reaches an End." American Association on Mental Retardation. [https://web.archive.org/web/20070313115939/http://www.cqc.state.ny.us/pressreleases/wyattclarence.htm] - accessed August 23, 2005. * History of Mental Health in Alabama on the [https://web.archive.org/web/20110721033019/http://www.mh.alabama.gov/BryceHospitalProject/ ''ADMH Web site''] - accessed January 4, 2011. * [http://opacity.us/site246_bryce_hospital.htm Photos of the abandoned Kirkbride and treatment buildings] * {{HABS |survey=AL-941 |id=al1023 |title=Robert Jemison Plantation, Byler Road, Northport, Tuscaloosa County, AL |photos=1 |color= |dwgs= |data=4 |cap=1}}
{{National Register of Historic Places}} {{Kirkbride Plan}}

revision.comment: I appreciate the effort of the last user to expand on the article but I really don't feel like the sentence was relevant or in within the scope of the article.
revision.text:
{{Redirect|Salto del Agua|the Metro station|Metro Salto del Agua|the municipality|Salto de Agua}} [[File:Acueducto_de_Chapultepec,_parte_posterior.jpg|thumb|250x250px|View of remaining arches of the Spanish built Chapultepec Aqueduct]] The '''Chapultepec aqueduct''' (in Spanish: acueducto de Chapultepec) was built to provide potable water to [[Tenochtitlan]], now known as [[Mexico City]]. This fresh water was transported from the Chapultepec springs.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The remarkable hydrological works of the Aztec civilization|last=Villasenor|first=Raynal|publisher=Water for the Future:Hydrology in Perspective Proceedings of Rome Symposium IAHS|year=April 1987|isbn=|location=|pages=164}}</ref> Two aqueducts following the same route from the springs were built by the [[Aztec]]s during the 15th century, the first destroyed by flooding and the second by the Spanish. After the [[Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire|Spanish conquest]] a colonial aqueduct was built, the remains of which are located near [[Metro Sevilla]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Moon Mexico City|last=Humphrey|first=Chris|publisher=Avalon Travel|year=2008|isbn=978-1-59880-083-8|location=|pages=Page 52}}</ref>
==Original Chapultepec aqueduct== The water level under Tenochtitlan was only 4–5 feet below the city, however, it was not a viable source of freshwater as the water retrieved was brackish.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Aztecs Under Spanish Rule: A History of the Indians of the Valley of Mexico, 1519-1810|last=Gibbons|first=Charles|publisher=Standford University Press|year=1964|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> Shallow wells were constructed, and the water retrieved was used for household work. Construction of an aqueduct that brought fresh water, suitable for cooking and drinking, from Chapultepec springs to Tenochtitlan began in 1418.<ref name=":23">{{Cite book|title=Aztec Archaeology and Ethnohistory|last=Berdan|first=Frances|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2014|isbn=|location=|pages=78–79}}</ref> Building relied on mud and plant material to create the foundation, which rested on artificial islands that were spread 3 to 4 meters apart.<ref name=":23" /> Mounds consisting of mud were constructed on these islands and driven through with a wooden stake for support. The top of each mound had a hollowed out trough lined with compacted clay, and hollowed out logs were placed in the bottom of the flow path to bridge gaps between the islands. A wooden plank walkway flanked the aqueduct, making it easily accessible and a method of transportation from the city to the outlying areas.<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|title=Landscapes, Identities, and Development|last=Roca|first=Zoran|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|year=2011|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> Once the water reached the city, it was delivered to small reservoirs and select households through a network of canals that extended in the four cardinal directions and branched off to individual streets.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Handbook to Life in the Aztec World|last=Aguilar-Moreno|first=Manuel|publisher=Oxford University Press|date=October 3, 2007|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref>
Despite its relative longevity, the composition of the aqueduct could not withstand the forces of nature.<ref name=":23" /> Erosion weathered away the compacted clay, and in 1449, heavy rains triggered a flood that destroyed the aqueduct and effectively shut down Tenochtitlan for weeks.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Mexico To-day and To-morrow|last=Trowbridge|first=Edward D.|publisher=Macmillan|year=1919|isbn=|location=|pages=23}}</ref>
==Second Chapultepec aqueduct== After the destruction of the original aqueduct, the engineer, [[Nezahualcoyotl (tlatoani)|Nezahualcoyotl]], lead the construction of another water system using sturdier materials following the same route as the original.<ref name=":7">{{Cite book|title=Return to the Center: Culture, Public Space, and City Building in a Global Era|last=Herzog|first=Lawrence Arthur|publisher=University of Texas Press|year=2006|isbn=978-0-292-71262-1|location=|pages=119}}</ref> This aqueduct consisted of two mortar lined troughs made of stone masonry. The addition of the second trough allowed for water to be diverted to the second pipe when maintenance had to be performed on the other. This allowed for a continuous supply of fresh water to be delivered to the city.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Becerril, Jiménez|first=|date=March 2007|title=Potable water and sanitation in Tenochtitlan: Aztec culture|url=http://ws.iwaponline.com/content/7/1/147|journal=Water Science and Technology|volume=7|pages=|via=}}</ref> Like the original aqueduct, the second rested on a chain of artificial islands. The pipes were secured to the islands by wood pilings attached to a foundation of sand, lime, and rock.<ref name=":23" /> The aqueduct was constructed using wood, carved stone, and compacted soil, with portions made of hollowed logs, allowing canoes to travel underneath.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://highscalability.com/blog/2011/3/28/aztec-empire-strategy-use-dual-pipes-in-your-aqueduct-for-hi.html|title=Aztec Empire Strategy: Use Dual Pipes in Your Aqueduct for High Availability - High Scalability -|website=highscalability.com|language=en|access-date=2017-10-13}}</ref>
==Colonial aqueduct== [[File:FUENTE DE SALTO DEL AGUA.jpg|thumb|Replica of the Salto del Agua Fountain.]]After his arrival in the Aztec empire, [[Hernán Cortés|Hernan Cortes]] discovered the economic and political importance of the Chapultepec aqueduct. He took advantage of the city's dependence on the aqueduct and blocked the fresh water supply, eventually destroying it. Shortly after the Spanish conquest, he set about dividing the land among the conquistadors. He wanted to take the forest of Chapultepec for himself, but [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles V, King of Spain]], denied his request and decreed that the springs were needed to provide the people with potable water and were thereby the property of the city of Tenochtitlan.<ref name=":23" /> Construction of a new aqueduct started under the reigning Viceroy [[Fernando de Alencastre, 1st Duke of Linares|Fernando de Alencastre]], 1st Duke of Linares (1711-1716). The structure became known under another name as the Aqueduct of Belen, named after an old Belen convent it passed by.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Here and There in Mexico: The Travel Writings of Mary Ashley Townsend|last=Townsend|first=Mary Ashley|publisher=The University of Alabama Press|year=2001|isbn=9780817358266|location=|pages=275}}</ref> Built along the same path as the Aztec engineered aqueducts, it was constructed using Roman architecture, reflected in its 904 arches. In completion, it reached a total length of 4663 [[Spanish customary units#Vara .28unit of length.29|varas]], roughly 4 kilometers. In conquest times, the aqueduct supplied the city with the majority of its freshwater, however, waterborne illness was a concern. In an effort to reduce the possibility of external contamination, iron and lead pipes were installed to replace the open troughs during the 19th Century.<ref name=":1" /> These shielded the water from air and outside contaminants but did not decrease the number of pathogen related illnesses and death.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Contributions to the Bacteriological Study of the Drinking Waters of the City of Mexico: Springs Bacteriological Analysis of the Waters of Chapultepec|last=Bell|first=Agrippa|publisher=The Sanitarian|year=|isbn=|location=Volume 31|pages=}}</ref>
Located on Chapultepec Avenue near Metro Sevilla, a small section, about twenty-two arches long, still survives today.<ref name=":1" /> Also standing today are two fountains associated with the aqueduct. The first is found wedged between [[Chapultepec|Chapultepec Park]] and [[Metro Chapultepec]]. Constructed by the viceroy [[Agustín de Ahumada]], this fountain was designed to divert a water to this section of the city. It also served a decorative and historical purpose. However, it is no longer in its original location: it was restored, enlarged and moved to its current location by Roberto Alvarez Espinoza in 1921.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Catalogo de Monumentos Escultoricos y Conmemorativos del Distrito Federal|last=Prado Nuñez|first=Ricardo|publisher=|year=1965|isbn=|location=|pages=20–23}}</ref> The second fountain, Salto del Agua, was built at the intersection of [[Eje Central]] and Arcos de Belen Street, where the historic center meets [[Colonia Doctores]] and [[Colonia Obrera]]. While it is at the original location, it is not the original fountain. It had deteriorated badly, and a reproduction was made by Guillermo Ruiz. The remains of the original are on display at the [[Museo Nacional del Virreinato]] in [[Tepotzotlán]].

{{Expand Spanish|Claudio Mamerto Cuenca|date=December 2011}} [[File:Cuenca retrato.0.jpg|thumb|right|Claudio Mamerto Cuenca]] '''Claudio Mamerto Cuenca''' (1812–1852) was an [[Argentina|Argentine]] poet and physician.
He was born in [[Buenos Aires]].
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cuenca, Claudio Mamerto}} [[Category:1812 births]] [[Category:1852 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century Argentine poets]] [[Category:Argentine male poets]] [[Category:Argentine physicians]] [[Category:Writers from Buenos Aires]] [[Category:19th-century male writers]]
{{Argentina-med-bio-stub}} {{Argentina-poet-stub}}

The '''Conference of Postgraduate Medical Deans''' (COPMeD) provides a forum for [[postgraduate]] [[Dean (education)|deans]] of the [[National Health Service]] of the [[United Kingdom]] to discuss current issues, share best practice and agree a consistent and equitable approach to medical training in all [[Deanery (NHS)|deaneries]].
It also acts as a focal point for contact between the postgraduate medical deans and other organisations, for example:
*[[Medical royal colleges]] *[[General Medical Council]] *[[British Medical Association]] *[[Academy of Medical Royal Colleges]] *[[Council of Heads of Medical Schools]] *[[Postgraduate Medical Education and Training Board]] *Health departments for postgraduate medical and dental education matters
It has an office in Red Lion Square in the same building as the [[Royal College of Anaesthetists]] and the [[Academy of Medical Royal Colleges]] which provides administrative support. ==External links==
*[http://www.copmed.org.uk Official website]
