revision.text:
The '''Health Datapalooza''' is an annual conference which exists to promote access to [[open data in the United States]] for the purpose of improving [[public health]]. Since its inception in 2010, Health Datapalooza has become the gathering place for people and organizations creating knowledge from data and pioneering innovations that drive health policy and practice.
==History== The first Health Datapalooza was a meeting organized in 2010 in response to the newly established website and database HealthData.gov.<ref name="2014 Lohr">{{cite web |url= http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/11/19/chasing-the-entrepreneurial-opportunity-in-obamacare/?_r=0 |title=Chasing Entrepreneurial Opportunity in the Affordable Care Act |first=Steve |last=Lohr |work=bits.blogs.nytimes.com |date=19 November 2014 |accessdate=27 January 2015}}</ref> The Obama administration invited 45 people to gather to consider 30 data sets and develop some prototype application using them within 30 days.<ref name="2014 Lohr"/>
;Datapalooza 2012 At Datapalooza 2012 a call was made for innovators to use data related to health and nutrition.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.forbes.com/sites/daniellegould/2012/03/20/todd-park-invites-food-tech-innovators-to-the-health-datapalooza/ |title=Todd Park Invites Food & Tech Innovators to the Health Datapalooza |first=Danielle |last=Gould |work=forbes.com |date=20 March 2012 |accessdate=27 January 2015}}</ref>
;Datapalooza 2013 In giving the keynote address at the fourth Datapalooza, [[Jonathan S. Bush]] of [[athenahealth]] said "Data scientist may be the sexiest career in the 21st-century!"<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.npr.org/blogs/health/2013/06/07/189565146/datapalooza-a-concept-a-conference-and-a-movement |title=Datapalooza: A Concept, A Conference And A Movement : Shots - Health News : NPR |first=Eric |last=Whitney|work=npr.org |date=7 June 2013 |accessdate=27 January 2015}}</ref> 1900 attendees and 80 companies joined the event.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2013/06/07/health-datapalooza-iv-tops-huge-year-health-data-liberation-innovation |title=Health Datapalooza IV Tops Off a Huge Year in Health Data Liberation & Innovation |first=Todd |last=Park |first2=Bryan |last2=Sivak |work=whitehouse.gov |date=7 June 2013 |accessdate=27 January 2015}}</ref>
;Datapalooza 2014 A topic of discussion was the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]]'s criticism of the [[Office of the National Coordinator for Health Information Technology]]'s authority to create a health IT safety center.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.politico.com/morningehealth/0614/morningehealth14164.html |title=GOP attack on ONC surprises industry as Health Datapalooza concludes — Health IT groups praise realignment — Sebelius' last speech |first=Ashley |last=Gold |work=politico.com |date=4 June 2014 |quote=data |accessdate=27 January 2015}}</ref>
;Datapalooza 2016 Current Vice President of the United States, Joe Biden gave a keynote address and discussed his family's struggles with cancer.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{official website|http://healthdatapalooza.org/}}
[[Category:Medical conferences]] [[Category:Data storage conferences]]

[[File:Hospital de Santa Maria.jpg|thumb|350px|The Hospital of Santa Maria, [[Lisbon]]]] '''Health in Portugal''' is characterized by the existence of a high quality healthcare system (ranked as the 9th best in Europe and 12th in the World), allowing the country to achieve good rankings in several health indices.
==Statistics== According to the latest [[Human Development Report]], the average [[life expectancy]] in 2014 was 80.0 years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apps.who.int/gho/data/node.main.688?lang=en|title=Global Health Observatory Data Repository|work=who.int}}</ref> The Portuguese healthcare system was ranked number 12 in overall performance by the World Health Organization in a 2000 report ranking the healthcare systems of each of the 190 United Nations member nations. Nonetheless it ranked number 27 as the most expensive per capita healthcare system.<ref>[[World Health Organization ranking of health systems]]</ref>
Similar to the other Eur-A countries, most Portuguese die from [[noncommunicable diseases]]. Mortality from [[cardiovascular diseases]] (CVD) is higher than in the [[Eurozone]], but its two main components, ischaemic heart disease and cerebrovascular disease, display inverse trends compared with the Eur-A, with [[cerebrovascular disease]] being the single biggest killer in Portugal (17%). Portuguese people die 12% less often from cancer than in the Eur-A, but mortality is not declining as rapidly as in the Eur-A. Cancer is more frequent among children as well as among women younger than 44 years. Although lung [[cancer]] (slowly increasing among women) and breast cancer (decreasing rapidly) are scarcer, cancer of the cervix and the prostate are more frequent. Portugal has the highest mortality rate for diabetes in the Eur-A, with a sharp increase since the late 1980s.
Portugal’s [[infant mortality rate]] has dropped sharply since the 1980s, when 24 of 1000 newborns died in the first year of life. It is now around 3 deaths per a 1000 newborns. This improvement was mainly due to the decrease in neonatal mortality, from 15.5 to 3.4 per 1000 live births.
People are usually well informed about their health status, the positive and negative effects of their behaviour on their health and their use of health care services. Yet their perceptions of their health can differ from what administrative and examination-based data show about levels of illness within populations. Thus, survey results based on self-reporting at the household level complement other data on health status and the use of services. Only one third of adults rated their health as good or very good in Portugal (Kasmel et al., 2004). This is the lowest of the Eur-A countries reporting and reflects the relatively adverse situation of the country in terms of mortality and selected morbidity.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090225002655/http://www.euro.who.int/document/chh/por_highlights.pdf ]</ref>
In 2015 it was estimated that 13.09% of the population has diabetes, costing about $2,011 per person per year.<ref>{{cite news|title=Top 10: Which country has the highest rates of diabetes in Europe? The UK’s position might surprise you…|url=http://www.diabetes.co.uk/blog/2015/08/which-country-highest-diabetes-europe/|accessdate=20 December 2015|publisher=Diabetes UK|date=27 August 2015}}</ref>
[[Madeira]] had the third highest death rate from respiratory diseases of any region in Europe in 2015 at 151 per 100,000 population.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ballas|first1=Dimitris|last2=Dorling|first2=Danny|last3=Hennig|first3=Benjamin|title=The Human Atlas of Europe|date=2017|publisher=Policy Press|location=Bristol|isbn=9781447313540|page=72}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Healthcare in Portugal]]
==References== {{commons category}} {{Reflist}}
{{Portugal topics}} {{Health care in Europe}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Health In Portugal}} [[Category:Health in Portugal| ]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = High-grade serous carcinoma | synonym = | image = Androgen receptors on a HGSC tumour.jpg | width = | alt = | caption = Immunohistochemistry micrograph of androgen receptors on a HGSC tumour sample | pronounce = | field = <!-- from Wikidata, can be overwritten --> | symptoms = | onset = | duration = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | frequency = | deaths = }}
'''High-grade serous carcinoma''' ('''HGSC''') is a type of tumour that arises from the [[Serous membrane|serous]] epithelial layer in the [[abdominopelvic cavity]] and is mainly found in the [[ovary]]. HGSCs make up the majority of [[ovarian cancer]] cases<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Shih|first=Ie-Ming|last2=Kurman|first2=Robert J.|date=2004-05-01|title=Ovarian Tumorigenesis: A Proposed Model Based on Morphological and Molecular Genetic Analysis|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S000294401063708X|journal=The American Journal of Pathology|volume=164|issue=5|pages=1511–1518|doi=10.1016/S0002-9440(10)63708-X}}</ref> and have the lowest survival rates.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Olivier|first=R. I.|last2=van Beurden|first2=M.|last3=Lubsen|first3=M. a. C.|last4=Rookus|first4=M. A.|last5=Mooij|first5=T. M.|last6=van de Vijver|first6=M. J.|last7=van't Veer|first7=L. J.|date=2004-03-16|title=Clinical outcome of prophylactic oophorectomy in BRCA1/BRCA2 mutation carriers and events during follow-up|url=http://www.nature.com/bjc/journal/v90/n8/full/6601692a.html|journal=British Journal of Cancer|language=en|volume=90|issue=8|pages=1492–1497|doi=10.1038/sj.bjc.6601692|issn=0007-0920|pmc=2409718|pmid=15083174}}</ref> HGSC is distinct from low-grade serous carcinoma (LGSC) which arises from ovarian tissue, is less aggressive and is present in stage I ovarian cancer where tumours are localised to the ovary.
Although originally thought to arise from the [[squamous]] epithelial cell layer covering the ovary, HGSC is now thought to originate in the Fallopian tube epithelium. HGSC is much more invasive than LGSC with a higher fatality rate - although it is more sensitive to [[Platinum-based antineoplastic|platinum-based chemotherapy]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Santillan|first=A.|last2=Kim|first2=Y.w.|last3=Zahurak|first3=M.l.|last4=Gardner|first4=G.j.|last5=Giuntoli|first5=R.l.|last6=Shih|first6=I.m.|last7=Bristow|first7=R.e.|date=2007-05-01|title=Differences of chemoresistance assay between invasive micropapillary/low-grade serous ovarian carcinoma and high-grade serous ovarian carcinoma|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1525-1438.2007.00820.x/abstract|journal=International Journal of Gynecological Cancer|language=en|volume=17|issue=3|pages=601–606|doi=10.1111/j.1525-1438.2007.00820.x|issn=1525-1438}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schmeler|first=Kathleen M.|last2=Sun|first2=Charlotte C.|last3=Bodurka|first3=Diane C.|last4=Deavers|first4=Michael T.|last5=Malpica|first5=Anais|last6=Coleman|first6=Robert L.|last7=Ramirez|first7=Pedro T.|last8=Gershenson|first8=David M.|date=2008-03-01|title=Neoadjuvant chemotherapy for low-grade serous carcinoma of the ovary or peritoneum|journal=Gynecologic Oncology|volume=108|issue=3|pages=510–514|doi=10.1016/j.ygyno.2007.11.013|issn=1095-6859|pmid=18155273}}</ref> possibly due to its rapid growth rate. In rare cases, HGSCs can develop from LGSCs,<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Dehari|first=Reiko|last2=Kurman|first2=Robert J.|last3=Logani|first3=Sanjay|last4=Shih|first4=Ie-Ming|date=2007-07-01|title=The development of high-grade serous carcinoma from atypical proliferative (borderline) serous tumors and low-grade micropapillary serous carcinoma: a morphologic and molecular genetic analysis|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=The+Development+of+High-grade+Serous+Carcinoma+From+Atypical+Proliferative+(Borderline)+Serous+Tumors+and+Low-grade+Micropapillary+Serous+Carcinoma%253A+A+Morphologic+and+Molecular+Genetic+Analysis|journal=The American Journal of Surgical Pathology|volume=31|issue=7|pages=1007–1012|doi=10.1097/PAS.0b013e31802cbbe9|issn=0147-5185|pmid=17592266}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Dehari|first=Reiko|last2=Kurman|first2=Robert J.|last3=Logani|first3=Sanjay|last4=Shih|first4=Ie-Ming|date=2007-07-01|title=The development of high-grade serous carcinoma from atypical proliferative (borderline) serous tumors and low-grade micropapillary serous carcinoma: a morphologic and molecular genetic analysis|journal=The American Journal of Surgical Pathology|volume=31|issue=7|pages=1007–1012|doi=10.1097/PAS.0b013e31802cbbe9|issn=0147-5185|pmid=17592266}}</ref> but generally the two types arise independently of each other.
== Risk factors ==
=== Environmental risk factors === The ‘incessant [[ovulation]]’ theory is suggested by the strong [[Correlation and dependence|correlation]] between the number of ovulatory cycles of an individual and their risk of ovarian cancer.<ref name="SwanSong">{{Cite journal |last=Fathalla |first=M. F. |date=2013-01-01 |title=Incessant ovulation and ovarian cancer - a hypothesis re-visited |journal=Facts, Views & Vision in ObGyn |volume=5 |issue=4 |pages=292–297 |issn=2032-0418 |pmc=3987381 |pmid=24753957}}</ref>
This trend is reflected in the protective effects of pregnancy, parity and breastfeeding against ovarian cancer,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Risch|first=H. A.|last2=Marrett|first2=L. D.|last3=Howe|first3=G. R.|date=1994-10-01|title=Parity, contraception, infertility, and the risk of epithelial ovarian cancer|journal=American Journal of Epidemiology|volume=140|issue=7|pages=585–597|issn=0002-9262|pmid=7942759}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gwinn|first=M. L.|last2=Lee|first2=N. C.|last3=Rhodes|first3=P. H.|last4=Layde|first4=P. M.|last5=Rubin|first5=G. L.|date=1990-01-01|title=Pregnancy, breast feeding, and oral contraceptives and the risk of epithelial ovarian cancer|journal=Journal of Clinical Epidemiology|volume=43|issue=6|pages=559–568|issn=0895-4356|pmid=2348208|doi=10.1016/0895-4356(90)90160-q}}</ref> and similar findings in epidemiological studies that have indicated a reduction of risk associated with use of oral contraceptive pills.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Kurman|first=R. J.|date=2013-12-01|title=Origin and molecular pathogenesis of ovarian high-grade serous carcinoma|journal=Annals of Oncology|volume=24 Suppl 10|pages=x16–21|doi=10.1093/annonc/mdt463|issn=1569-8041|pmid=24265397}}</ref><ref name="SwanSong" />
Ovulation is accepted as the cause of ovarian cortical inclusion cysts, the precursor [[lesion]]s of serous carcinomas, and lower numbers of these cortical inclusion cysts are thought to be the mechanism by which reducing lifetime ovulations can lower the risk of developing HGSC.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=DastranjTabrizi|first=Ali|last2=MostafaGharabaghi|first2=Parvin|last3=SheikhzadehHesari|first3=Farzam|last4=Sadeghi|first4=Liela|last5=Zamanvandi|first5=Sharareh|last6=Sarbakhsh|first6=Parvin|last7=Ghojazadeh|first7=Morteza|date=2016-01-01|title=Impact and mechanistic role of oral contraceptive pills on the number and epithelial type of ovarian cortical inclusion cysts; a clinicopathology and immunohistochemical study|journal=Diagnostic Pathology|volume=11|pages=30|doi=10.1186/s13000-016-0482-6|issn=1746-1596|pmc=4802821|pmid=27000861}}</ref>
Conversely, a temporal association with [[Hormone replacement therapy (menopause)|menopausal hormone therapy]] and incidence of HGSC was found,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Yang|first=Hannah P.|last2=Anderson|first2=William F.|last3=Rosenberg|first3=Philip S.|last4=Trabert|first4=Britton|last5=Gierach|first5=Gretchen L.|last6=Wentzensen|first6=Nicolas|last7=Cronin|first7=Kathleen A.|last8=Sherman|first8=Mark E.|date=2013-06-10|title=Ovarian cancer incidence trends in relation to changing patterns of menopausal hormone therapy use in the United States|journal=Journal of Clinical Oncology|volume=31|issue=17|pages=2146–2151|doi=10.1200/JCO.2012.45.5758|issn=1527-7755|pmc=3731982|pmid=23650423}}</ref> and [[Polycystic ovary syndrome|polycystic ovarian syndrome]] (PCOS) was shown to contribute to a doubling of the risk of ovarian cancer.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schildkraut|first=J. M.|last2=Schwingl|first2=P. J.|last3=Bastos|first3=E.|last4=Evanoff|first4=A.|last5=Hughes|first5=C.|date=1996-10-01|title=Epithelial ovarian cancer risk among women with polycystic ovary syndrome|journal=Obstetrics and Gynecology|volume=88|issue=4 Pt 1|pages=554–559|issn=0029-7844|pmid=8841217}}</ref>
[[Endometriosis]] can increase risk for other ovarian cancer subtypes, but is not associated with HGSC.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pearce|first=Celeste Leigh|last2=Templeman|first2=Claire|last3=Rossing|first3=Mary Anne|last4=Lee|first4=Alice|last5=Near|first5=Aimee M.|last6=Webb|first6=Penelope M.|last7=Nagle|first7=Christina M.|last8=Doherty|first8=Jennifer A.|last9=Cushing-Haugen|first9=Kara L.|date=2012-04-01|title=Association between endometriosis and risk of histological subtypes of ovarian cancer: a pooled analysis of case-control studies|journal=The Lancet. Oncology|volume=13|issue=4|pages=385–394|doi=10.1016/S1470-2045(11)70404-1|issn=1474-5488|pmc=3664011|pmid=22361336}}</ref>
=== Genetic risk factors === More than 20% of ovarian cancer tumours have [[Heredity|hereditary]] origin. The majority of these feature mutations in the tumour suppressor [[BRCA mutation|BRCA]] genes, which tend to give rise to HGSC.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Toss|first=Angela|last2=Tomasello|first2=Chiara|last3=Razzaboni|first3=Elisabetta|last4=Contu|first4=Giannina|last5=Grandi|first5=Giovanni|last6=Cagnacci|first6=Angelo|last7=Schilder|first7=Russell J.|last8=Cortesi|first8=Laura|date=2015-01-01|title=Hereditary ovarian cancer: not only BRCA 1 and 2 genes|journal=BioMed Research International|volume=2015|pages=341723|doi=10.1155/2015/341723|issn=2314-6141|pmc=4449870|pmid=26075229}}</ref> A mutation in [[BRCA1]] or [[BRCA2]] can confer a lifetime ovarian cancer risk of 40-50% and 10-20% respectively,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Liu|first=Guoyan|last2=Yang|first2=Da|last3=Sun|first3=Yan|last4=Shmulevich|first4=Ilya|last5=Xue|first5=Fengxia|last6=Sood|first6=Anil K.|last7=Zhang|first7=Wei|date=2012-10-01|title=Differing clinical impact of BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations in serous ovarian cancer|journal=Pharmacogenomics|volume=13|issue=13|pages=1523–1535|doi=10.2217/pgs.12.137|issn=1744-8042|pmc=3603383|pmid=23057551}}</ref> with BRCA2 mutations strongly associated with better clinical outcomes.
A specific tumour protein 53 (''[[P53|TP53]])'' expression pattern in the Fallopian tube epithelium – the ‘p53 signature’ - is thought to be a precursor marker of HGSC. TP53-/- mice (in which the TP53 gene has been deleted) do not develop ovarian carcinomas.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Liu|first=Ying|last2=Yen|first2=Hai-Yun|last3=Austria|first3=Theresa|last4=Pettersson|first4=Jonas|last5=Peti-Peterdi|first5=Janos|last6=Maxson|first6=Robert|last7=Widschwendter|first7=Martin|last8=Dubeau|first8=Louis|date=2015-10-01|title=A Mouse Model That Reproduces the Developmental Pathways and Site Specificity of the Cancers Associated With the Human BRCA1 Mutation Carrier State|journal=EBioMedicine|volume=2|issue=10|pages=1318–1330|doi=10.1016/j.ebiom.2015.08.034|issn=2352-3964|pmc=4634618|pmid=26629527}}</ref> However, TP53 mutations were found in 96% of HGSC cases.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cancer Genome Atlas Research Network|date=2011-06-30|title=Integrated genomic analyses of ovarian carcinoma|journal=Nature|volume=474|issue=7353|pages=609–615|doi=10.1038/nature10166|issn=1476-4687|pmc=3163504|pmid=21720365}}</ref> A local abnormal TP53 expression may thus be indicative of HGSC.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ahmed|first=Ahmed Ashour|last2=Etemadmoghadam|first2=Dariush|last3=Temple|first3=Jillian|last4=Lynch|first4=Andy G.|last5=Riad|first5=Mohamed|last6=Sharma|first6=Raghwa|last7=Stewart|first7=Colin|last8=Fereday|first8=Sian|last9=Caldas|first9=Carlos|date=2010-05-01|title=Driver mutations in TP53 are ubiquitous in high grade serous carcinoma of the ovary|journal=The Journal of Pathology|volume=221|issue=1|pages=49–56|doi=10.1002/path.2696|issn=1096-9896|pmc=3262968|pmid=20229506}}</ref> In women, pelvic HGSC show either a complete absence of P53 expression, or overexpression, suggesting that any aberration of P53 leads to tumour development.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Köbel|first=Martin|last2=Reuss|first2=Alexander|last3=du Bois|first3=Andreas|last4=Kommoss|first4=Stefan|last5=Kommoss|first5=Friedrich|last6=Gao|first6=Dongxia|last7=Kalloger|first7=Steve E.|last8=Huntsman|first8=David G.|last9=Gilks|first9=C. Blake|date=2010-10-01|title=The biological and clinical value of p53 expression in pelvic high-grade serous carcinomas|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=The+biological+and+clinical+value+of+p53+expression+in+pelvic+high-grade+serous+carcinomas|journal=The Journal of Pathology|volume=222|issue=2|pages=191–198|doi=10.1002/path.2744|issn=1096-9896|pmid=20629008}}</ref> Additionally, overexpression of TP53 is associated with better clinical outcome whereas an absence of the p53 protein is linked to an increased risk of HGSC tumour recurrence.<ref name=":1" />
A recent mouse model suggest that a p53 mutation may induce HGSC arising from the ovary rather than the Fallopian tube.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Kim|first=Jaeyeon|last2=Coffey|first2=Donna M.|last3=Ma|first3=Lang|last4=Matzuk|first4=Martin M.|date=2015-06-01|title=The ovary is an alternative site of origin for high-grade serous ovarian cancer in mice|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=The+Ovary+Is+an+Alternative+Site+of+Origin+for+High-Grade+Serous+Ovarian+Cancer+in+Mice|journal=Endocrinology|volume=156|issue=6|pages=1975–1981|doi=10.1210/en.2014-1977|issn=1945-7170|pmid=25815421}}</ref>
== Pathophysiology ==
=== Cell origin === HGSC are further distinguished from LGSC by ‘type I/II’ ovarian tumour nomenclature;<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Koshiyama|first=Masafumi|last2=Matsumura|first2=Noriomi|last3=Konishi|first3=Ikuo|date=2014-01-01|title=Recent concepts of ovarian carcinogenesis: type I and type II|journal=BioMed Research International|volume=2014|pages=934261|doi=10.1155/2014/934261|issn=2314-6141|pmc=4017729|pmid=24868556}}</ref> type I referring to tumour types (e.g. LGSCs) where precursor lesions within the ovary have been characterised, and type II referring to tumour types (e.g. HGSCs) without association of such lesions, tumours understood to develop ''de novo'' from the tubal and/or ovarian surface epithelium. This classification has more relevance to research rather than to clinical practice.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Cobb|first=Lauren Patterson|last2=Gaillard|first2=Stephanie|last3=Wang|first3=Yihong|last4=Shih|first4=Ie-Ming|last5=Secord|first5=Angeles Alvarez|date=2015-01-01|title=Adenocarcinoma of Mullerian origin: review of pathogenesis, molecular biology, and emerging treatment paradigms|journal=Gynecologic Oncology Research and Practice|volume=2|pages=1|doi=10.1186/s40661-015-0008-z|issn=2053-6844|pmc=4880836|pmid=27231561}}</ref>
The [[Serous membrane|serous]] membrane is a particular type of secretory epithelium which covers organs in body cavities and secretes serous fluid to reduce friction from muscle movement. Serous membrane lining the abdominopelvic cavity is called the [[peritoneum]]; that lining heart and mediastinum is the [[pericardium]], and that lining the thoracic cavity and lungs is the [[Pulmonary pleurae|pleura]]. Technically a ‘serous carcinoma’ can occur anywhere on these membranes, but high-grade serous carcinoma is generally limited to the peritoneal area.
While until recently HGSC was thought to arise from simple differentiation of cortical inclusion cysts (CICs) of [[Germinal epithelium (female)|ovarian surface epithelium]] (OSE), the cell origin of HGSC is now understood to be much more complex, with evidence for other sites of origin, both intra- and extra-ovarian, having come to light. {| class="wikitable" !Tissue !Evidence for role as HGSC cell of origin |- |Ovary |''Supporting:'' # [[Metastasis|Metastatic]] HGSC arose in the ovaries of mouse triple [[Gene knockout|knockouts]] of [[p53]], [[PTEN (gene)|PTEN]] and ''[[Dicer]]'' in which the Fallopian tubes had been removed, as well as in double [[Murinae|murine]] knockouts of PTEN and p53 with intact Fallopian tubes.<ref name=":6"/> # The stem-cell-rich hilum region of the ovarian surface epithelium is a cancer-prone area.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Flesken-Nikitin|first=Andrea|last2=Hwang|first2=Chang-Il|last3=Cheng|first3=Chieh-Yang|last4=Michurina|first4=Tatyana V.|last5=Enikolopov|first5=Grigori|last6=Nikitin|first6=Alexander Yu|date=2013-03-14|title=Ovarian surface epithelium at the junction area contains a cancer-prone stem cell niche|journal=Nature|volume=495|issue=7440|pages=241–245|doi=10.1038/nature11979|issn=1476-4687|pmc=3982379|pmid=23467088}}</ref>
''Opposing:'' # A convincing precursor of HGSC in the ovary has not yet been identified.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Dubeau|first=L.|last2=Drapkin|first2=R.|date=2013-11-01|title=Coming into focus: the nonovarian origins of ovarian cancer|journal=Annals of Oncology|volume=24 Suppl 8|pages=viii28–viii35|doi=10.1093/annonc/mdt308|issn=1569-8041|pmc=3805308|pmid=24131966}}</ref> |- |Coelomic epithelium |''Supporting:'' 'Coelomic hypothesis' <ref name=":2" /> # Due to the embryological relationship between the [[coelomic epithelium]] and the [[Paramesonephric duct|Müllerian ducts]], the coelomic epithelium is predisposed to differentiation via Müllerian metaplasia into the different epithelial tumour tissue types (e.g. serous, [[Endometrioid tumor|endometrioid]], [[Clear-cell ovarian carcinoma|clear cell]] and [[Mucinous carcinoma|mucinous]]). Cortical inclusion cysts of the OSE can thus undergo differentiation into neoplasms. # This hypothesis can account for primary peritoneal carcinomas by implying that extra-ovarian coelomic epithelium can similarly undergo Müllerian metaplasia. ''Opposing:'' # There has so far been an absence of precursor lesions of ovarian carcinomas on the OSE despite extensive [[histopathology]].<ref name=":5" /> |- |Fallopian tube |''Supporting:'' # Precursor lesions (serous tubal intraepithelial carcinomas or ‘STICs’) found on the fimbrial ends of the Fallopian tube of BRCA 1/2 women.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Folkins|first=Ann K.|last2=Jarboe|first2=Elke A.|last3=Saleemuddin|first3=Aasia|last4=Lee|first4=Yonghee|last5=Callahan|first5=Michael J.|last6=Drapkin|first6=Ronny|last7=Garber|first7=Judy E.|last8=Muto|first8=Michael G.|last9=Tworoger|first9=Shelley|date=2008-05-01|title=A candidate precursor to pelvic serous cancer (p53 signature) and its prevalence in ovaries and fallopian tubes from women with BRCA mutations|journal=Gynecologic Oncology|volume=109|issue=2|pages=168–173|doi=10.1016/j.ygyno.2008.01.012|issn=1095-6859|pmc=2746001|pmid=18342932}}</ref> # There is physical contact between the [[Fimbriae of uterine tube|fimbriae]] and the ovary during ovulation (supports ‘incessant ovulation’ hypothesis). # The fringes of the fimbriae come into contact with the pro-inflammatory follicular fluid.<ref name="Ng 625–638">{{Cite journal|last=Ng|first=Annie|last2=Barker|first2=Nick|date=2015-10-01|title=Ovary and fimbrial stem cells: biology, niche and cancer origins|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=Ovary+and+fimbrial+stem+cells%253A+biology%252C+niche+and+cancer+origins|journal=Nature Reviews Molecular Cell Biology|volume=16|issue=10|pages=625–638|doi=10.1038/nrm4056|issn=1471-0080|pmid=26350076}}</ref> # Identical TP53 mutations in STIC and concurrent HGSC were reported, suggesting a clonal relationship.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kuhn|first=Elisabetta|last2=Kurman|first2=Robert J.|last3=Vang|first3=Russell|last4=Sehdev|first4=Ann Smith|last5=Han|first5=Guangming|last6=Soslow|first6=Robert|last7=Wang|first7=Tian-Li|last8=Shih|first8=Ie-Ming|date=2012-02-01|title=TP53 mutations in serous tubal intraepithelial carcinoma and concurrent pelvic high-grade serous carcinoma--evidence supporting the clonal relationship of the two lesions|journal=The Journal of Pathology|volume=226|issue=3|pages=421–426|doi=10.1002/path.3023|issn=1096-9896|pmc=4782784|pmid=21990067}}</ref> # In the triple ''p53''-PTEN-''Dicer'' knockout mice earlier mentioned, where the Fallopian tubes were intact, HGSC arose from the tubes 100% of the time, eclipsing the tumourgenicity of the ovary.<ref name=":6" /> Identical findings were found from PTEN-''Dicer'' knockouts. # A 2012 clinical trial of a screening technique found that 7 out of 9 identified HGSC cases arose from the Fallopian tube fimbriae<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Gilbert|first=Lucy|last2=Basso|first2=Olga|last3=Sampalis|first3=John|last4=Karp|first4=Igor|last5=Martins|first5=Claudia|last6=Feng|first6=Jing|last7=Piedimonte|first7=Sabrina|last8=Quintal|first8=Louise|last9=Ramanakumar|first9=Agnihotram V.|date=2012-03-01|title=Assessment of symptomatic women for early diagnosis of ovarian cancer: results from the prospective DOvE pilot project|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=Assessment+of+symptomatic+women+for+early+diagnosis+of+ovarian+cancer%253A+results+from+the+prospective+DOvE+pilot+project|journal=The Lancet. Oncology|volume=13|issue=3|pages=285–291|doi=10.1016/S1470-2045(11)70333-3|issn=1474-5488|pmid=22257524}}</ref> # Transfer of transformed serous Fallopian tube secretory epithelium into the peritoneum of [[Severe combined immunodeficiency (non-human)|severe combined immunodeficiency]] (SCID) mice induced tumours which resemble human HGSC.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Jazaeri|first=Amir A.|last2=Bryant|first2=Jennifer L.|last3=Park|first3=Hong|last4=Li|first4=Hui|last5=Dahiya|first5=Neetu|last6=Stoler|first6=Mark H.|last7=Ferriss|first7=James Stuart|last8=Dutta|first8=Anindya|date=2011-10-01|title=Molecular requirements for transformation of fallopian tube epithelial cells into serous carcinoma|journal=Neoplasia (New York, N.Y.)|volume=13|issue=10|pages=899–911|issn=1476-5586|pmc=3201567|pmid=22028616|doi=10.1593/neo.11138}}</ref> # Reliable HGSC precursors were found on the Fallopian tubes in the form of abnormal TP53 expression patterns.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Saleemuddin|first=Aasia|last2=Folkins|first2=Ann K.|last3=Garrett|first3=Leslie|last4=Garber|first4=Judy|last5=Muto|first5=Michael G.|last6=Crum|first6=Christopher P.|last7=Tworoger|first7=Shelley|date=2008-11-01|title=Risk factors for a serous cancer precursor ("p53 signature") in women with inherited BRCA mutations|journal=Gynecologic Oncology|volume=111|issue=2|pages=226–232|doi=10.1016/j.ygyno.2008.07.018|issn=1095-6859|pmc=2613977|pmid=18718648}}</ref> # Serous fimbrial cells are less able to correct DNA damage and reverse mutations than their ciliated counterparts, indicating how they might be particularly vulnerable to the mutagenicity of the follicular fluid at ovulation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Levanon|first=K.|last2=Ng|first2=V.|last3=Piao|first3=H. Y.|last4=Zhang|first4=Yi|last5=Chang|first5=M. C.|last6=Roh|first6=M. H.|last7=Kindelberger|first7=D. W.|last8=Hirsch|first8=M. S.|last9=Crum|first9=C. P.|date=2010-02-25|title=Primary ex vivo cultures of human fallopian tube epithelium as a model for serous ovarian carcinogenesis|journal=Oncogene|volume=29|issue=8|pages=1103–1113|doi=10.1038/onc.2009.402|issn=1476-5594|pmc=2829112|pmid=19935705}}</ref>
''Opposing:'' # A 2013 study shows that STICs only advance to form HGSC in the presence of a BRCA mutation, remaining uninvasive in models without such mutations – suggesting that HGSCs may arise from Fallopian tube tissue in individuals with BRCA mutations, but not generally.<ref name="Perets 751–765">{{Cite journal|last=Perets|first=Ruth|last2=Wyant|first2=Gregory A.|last3=Muto|first3=Katherine W.|last4=Bijron|first4=Jonathan G.|last5=Poole|first5=Barish B.|last6=Chin|first6=Kenneth T.|last7=Chen|first7=Jin Yun H.|last8=Ohman|first8=Anders W.|last9=Stepule|first9=Corey D.|date=2013-12-09|title=Transformation of the fallopian tube secretory epithelium leads to high-grade serous ovarian cancer in Brca;Tp53;Pten models|journal=Cancer Cell|volume=24|issue=6|pages=751–765|doi=10.1016/j.ccr.2013.10.013|issn=1878-3686|pmc=3917315|pmid=24332043}}</ref> |- |Extra-uterine Müllerian epithelium (EUME) |''All epithelia of the female genital tract – Fallopian tubes, [[endometrium]], [[Cervical canal|endocervix]], [[Cervix|ectocervix]], upper vagina - are derived from the embryonal Müllerian ducts. Extra-uterine Müllerian epithelium includes the distal end of the Fallopian tubes (the fimbriae), and instances of [[endosalpingiosis]], [[endometriosis]] and endocervicosis.''
''Supporting:'' # High-grade serous extra-uterine carcinomas have been reported.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dubeau|first=Louis|date=2015-02-01|title=Pathogenesis of serous, extra-uterine Müllerian epithelial cancer and therapeutic implications|journal=Translational Cancer Research|volume=4|issue=1|pages=3–13|doi=10.3978/j.issn.2218-676X.2015.01.06|issn=2218-676X|pmc=4643277|pmid=26568913}}</ref> # Intraovarian Müllerian cysts can be explained as examples of endosalpingiosis within the ovary, rather than as results of Müllerian metaplasia in pre-existing cortical inclusion cysts as per the coelomic hypothesis. # This hypothesis can also account for primary peritoneal carcinomas, as EUME can be found far away enough from the ovary and fimbriae to give rise to tumors without input from those organs. # The extensiveness of EUME can also explain the presence of paratubal and [[Paraovarian cyst|paraovarian]] tumours. # Endosalpingiosis - a condition where Fallopian tube epithelium is found outside the Fallopian tube - supports the likelihood of HGSC arising in the wider peritoneum. # Endosalpingiosis is associated with high incidence of borderline serous carcinoma (38%) and HGSC (18%).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Esselen|first=Katharine|last2=Terry|first2=Kathryn|date=2016|title=Endosalpingiosis: More than just an incidental finding at the time of gynecologic surgery?|url=http://www.gynecologiconcology-online.net/article/S0090-8258(16)30765-X/pdf|journal=Gynecologic Oncology|volume=142|issue=|doi=10.1016/j.ygyno.2016.05.036|pmid=|access-date=10/8/2016|via=|pages=255–260}}</ref> # A central role of EUME in HGS carcinogenesis would account for cases of HGSC that do not involve precursor STICs.
''Opposing:'' # This is a relatively new hypothesis and requires further research using appropriate models before conclusions can be drawn. |- |Border between ovary and Fallopian tube (transition zone) |''Supporting:'' # Transition zones in other epithelia are frequent sites of stem cells. # Such an epithelial transition zone may have more ambiguous stem cell fate signalling, and thus may be vulnerable to carcinogenesis.<ref name="Ng 625–638"/> # A number of epithelial transition zones, e.g. ectocervix junction, gastro-duodenal junction, are implicated in the development of different epithelial cancers.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mcnairn|first=AJ|last2=Guasch|first2=G|date=2011|title=Epithelial transition zones: merging microenvironments, niches, and cellular transformation|url=http://www.jle.com/fr/revues/ejd/e-docs/epithelial_transition_zones_merging_microenvironments_niches_and_cellular_transformation_288607/article.phtml|journal=European Journal of Dermatology|volume=|issue=|doi=10.1684/ejd.2011.1267|pmid=|access-date=|via=}}</ref>
''Opposing:'' # This is a relatively new hypothesis and requires further research using appropriate models before conclusions can be drawn. |} The common Müllerian origin of the Fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix, and upper vagina has resulted in the proposal that peritoneal high-grade serous carcinoma is a spectrum of a single disease.<ref name=":7" />
Relevant animal models of HGSC can only be developed when the cell origin is properly understood. However, as HGSC tends to have the same clinical behaviour, regardless of its primary cell origin, determining cell origin is less important for clinical treatment, but may be of relevance when looking for biomarkers.
The specific process by which a HGSC arises may be related to the BRCA mutation status of the individual,<ref name="Perets 751–765"/><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Howitt|first=Brooke E.|last2=Hanamornroongruang|first2=Suchanan|last3=Lin|first3=Douglas I.|last4=Conner|first4=James E.|last5=Schulte|first5=Stephanie|last6=Horowitz|first6=Neil|last7=Crum|first7=Christopher P.|last8=Meserve|first8=Emily E.|date=2015-03-01|title=Evidence for a dualistic model of high-grade serous carcinoma: BRCA mutation status, histology, and tubal intraepithelial carcinoma|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=Evidence+for+a+dualistic+model+of+high-grade+serous+carcinoma%253A+BRCA+mutation+status,+histology,+and+tubal+intraepithelial+carcinoma|journal=The American Journal of Surgical Pathology|volume=39|issue=3|pages=287–293|doi=10.1097/PAS.0000000000000369|issn=1532-0979|pmid=25581732}}</ref> as well as the p53 mutation status.<ref name=":6" />
A 2007 paper describes the process of determining cell of origin as “Tumour origin is typically assigned to the organ presenting with the dominant tumour mass. The one exception is the peritoneum, which is classified as a primary site only if a candidate origin is not found in the endometrium, tube or ovary”.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Crum|first=Christopher P.|last2=Drapkin|first2=Ronny|last3=Miron|first3=Alexander|last4=Ince|first4=Tan A.|last5=Muto|first5=Michael|last6=Kindelberger|first6=David W.|last7=Lee|first7=Yonghee|date=2007-02-01|title=The distal fallopian tube: a new model for pelvic serous carcinogenesis|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=The+distal+fallopian+tube%253A+a+new+model+for+pelvic+serous+carcinogenesis|journal=Current Opinion in Obstetrics and Gynecology|volume=19|issue=1|pages=3–9|doi=10.1097/GCO.0b013e328011a21f|issn=1040-872X|pmid=17218844}}</ref>
It is recognised that HGSC can have variable and complex primary origins, but understanding and determining this will give insight into its pathogenesis. [[File:High grade serous carcinoma theories of origin diagram.png|alt=Diagram visualising theory that HGSC arises from inclusion of a stem cell from the ovarian surface epithelium, or possibly from a fallopian tube stem cell|thumb|Diagram of HGSC theories of origin]]
=== Pathogenesis === Assuming a fimbrial origin, as observed in the majority of HGSC cases,<ref name=":8" /> the current understanding of HGSC genesis suggests a process by which STIC fimbrial cells implant into the ovary as cortical inclusion cysts through the ovulation rupture site.
To account for instances where there is no STIC involvement, endosalpingiosis or ''de novo'' metaplasia of ovarian surface epithelium inclusions are also possible. A much rarer occurrence is the differentiation of HGSC from LGSC.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" />
== Diagnosis == Symptoms include persistent [[bloating]], postmenopausal bleeding, and/or appetite loss.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bankhead|first=C. R.|last2=Collins|first2=C.|last3=Stokes-Lampard|first3=H.|last4=Rose|first4=P.|last5=Wilson|first5=S.|last6=Clements|first6=A.|last7=Mant|first7=D.|last8=Kehoe|first8=S. T.|last9=Austoker|first9=J.|date=2008-07-01|title=Identifying symptoms of ovarian cancer: a qualitative and quantitative study|journal=BJOG: an international journal of obstetrics and gynaecology|volume=115|issue=8|pages=1008–1014|doi=10.1111/j.1471-0528.2008.01772.x|issn=1471-0528|pmc=2607526|pmid=18651882}}</ref>
[[Vaginal ultrasonography|Transvaginal ultrasonography]] as well as cancer marker [[CA-125|CA125]] level analysis is often used to determine potential malignancy of suspect pelvic masses.<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Colombo|first=N.|last2=Peiretti|first2=M.|last3=Parma|first3=G.|last4=Lapresa|first4=M.|last5=Mancari|first5=R.|last6=Carinelli|first6=S.|last7=Sessa|first7=C.|last8=Castiglione|first8=M.|last9=ESMO Guidelines Working Group|date=2010-05-01|title=Newly diagnosed and relapsed epithelial ovarian carcinoma: ESMO Clinical Practice Guidelines for diagnosis, treatment and follow-up|journal=Annals of Oncology|volume=21 Suppl 5|pages=v23–30|doi=10.1093/annonc/mdq244|issn=1569-8041|pmid=20555088}}</ref>
Surgical [[Cancer staging|staging]] is the procedure by which the abdominal cavity and lymph nodes are examined for malignant tissue, usually via [[laparoscopy]]. Tissue [[Biopsy|biopsies]] may be taken for further analysis. It is not until this histological analysis stage that actual diagnosis of HGSC can be made.<ref name=":9" />
If glands are seen to fuse with intricate, extensive papillae featuring epithelial tufting with solid nests surrounded by a space alongside irregular slit-like spaces, then serous carcinoma is suspected.
Distinguishing between LGSC and HGSC:<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Vang|first=Russell|last2=Shih|first2=Ie-Ming|last3=Kurman|first3=Robert J.|date=2009-09-01|title=Ovarian low-grade and high-grade serous carcinoma: pathogenesis, clinicopathologic and molecular biologic features, and diagnostic problems|journal=Advances in Anatomic Pathology|volume=16|issue=5|pages=267–282|doi=10.1097/PAP.0b013e3181b4fffa|issn=1533-4031|pmc=2745605|pmid=19700937}}</ref> # [[Necrosis]] is common in HGSC and absent in LGSC, as are giant (multi- or mononucleated) tumour cells. # [[Psammoma body|Psammoma bodies]] are more frequent in low-grade serous carcinoma. # Tp53 expression is assessed for mutations, overexpression or absence – common features of high-grade serous carcinomas. # LGSCs are generally limited to micropapillary growth patterns, whereas HGSCs can exhibit admixed patterns. Distinction of HGSC from high-grade endometrioid carcinoma is not always possible.<ref name=":10" />
The progression of HGSC may also be determined from examining the [[cadherin]] expression profile.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Quattrocchi|first=Livia|last2=Green|first2=Andrew R.|last3=Martin|first3=Stewart|last4=Durrant|first4=Lindy|last5=Deen|first5=Suha|date=2011-07-01|title=The cadherin switch in ovarian high-grade serous carcinoma is associated with disease progression|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=The+cadherin+switch+in+ovarian+high-grade+serous+carcinoma+is+associated+with+disease+progression|journal=Virchows Archiv: An International Journal of Pathology|volume=459|issue=1|pages=21–29|doi=10.1007/s00428-011-1082-1|issn=1432-2307|pmid=21509572}}</ref>
=== Screening === As ovarian cancer is rarely symptomatic until an advanced stage,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nagle|first=Christina M.|last2=Francis|first2=Jane E.|last3=Nelson|first3=Anne E.|last4=Zorbas|first4=Helen|last5=Luxford|first5=Karen|last6=de Fazio|first6=Anna|last7=Fereday|first7=Sian|last8=Bowtell|first8=David D.|last9=Green|first9=Adèle C.|date=2011-06-01|title=Reducing time to diagnosis does not improve outcomes for women with symptomatic ovarian cancer: a report from the Australian Ovarian Cancer Study Group|journal=Journal of Clinical Oncology|volume=29|issue=16|pages=2253–2258|doi=10.1200/JCO.2010.32.2164|issn=1527-7755|pmid=21537035}}</ref> regular pre-emptive screening is a particularly important tool for avoiding the late stage at which most patients present. However, A 2011 US study found that transvaginal ultrasound and cancer marker CA125 screening did not reduce ovarian cancer mortality.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Buys|first=Saundra S.|last2=Partridge|first2=Edward|last3=Black|first3=Amanda|last4=Johnson|first4=Christine C.|last5=Lamerato|first5=Lois|last6=Isaacs|first6=Claudine|last7=Reding|first7=Douglas J.|last8=Greenlee|first8=Robert T.|last9=Yokochi|first9=Lance A.|date=2011-06-08|title=Effect of screening on ovarian cancer mortality: the Prostate, Lung, Colorectal and Ovarian (PLCO) Cancer Screening Randomized Controlled Trial|journal=JAMA|volume=305|issue=22|pages=2295–2303|doi=10.1001/jama.2011.766|issn=1538-3598|pmid=21642681}}</ref> In contrast, a more recent UK study found that up to 20% of ovarian cancer deaths could be prevented through annual performance of these procedures.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Jacobs|first=Ian J.|last2=Menon|first2=Usha|last3=Ryan|first3=Andy|last4=Gentry-Maharaj|first4=Aleksandra|last5=Burnell|first5=Matthew|last6=Kalsi|first6=Jatinderpal K.|last7=Amso|first7=Nazar N.|last8=Apostolidou|first8=Sophia|last9=Benjamin|first9=Elizabeth|date=2016-03-05|title=Ovarian cancer screening and mortality in the UK Collaborative Trial of Ovarian Cancer Screening (UKCTOCS): a randomised controlled trial|journal=Lancet|volume=387|issue=10022|pages=945–956|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(15)01224-6|issn=1474-547X|pmc=4779792|pmid=26707054}}</ref>
==Prevention== Prevention for an individual deemed at risk of HGSC has, up until recently, been (bilateral or unilateral) removal of both the ovary and the Fallopian tube (salpingo-[[oophorectomy]]).
With hormonal and even morbidity issues resulting from ovary removal, and the increased evidence for the role of the Fallopian tubes HGSC pathogenesis, optimisation of this procedure has been to remove just the Fallopian tube(s) (salpingectomy) with the ovaries remaining until age of menopause <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Oliver Perez|first=M. Reyes|last2=Magriñá|first2=Javier|last3=García|first3=Alvaro Tejerizo|last4=Jiménez Lopez|first4=Jesus Salvador|date=2015-12-01|title=Prophylactic salpingectomy and prophylactic salpingoophorectomy for adnexal high-grade serous epithelial carcinoma: A reappraisal|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=Prophylactic+salpingectomy+and+prophylactic+salpingoophorectomy+for+adnexal+high-grade+serous+epithelial+carcinoma%253A+A+reappraisal|journal=Surgical Oncology|volume=24|issue=4|pages=335–344|doi=10.1016/j.suronc.2015.09.008|issn=1879-3320|pmid=26690823}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Daly|first=Mary B.|last2=Dresher|first2=Charles W.|last3=Yates|first3=Melinda S.|last4=Jeter|first4=Joanne M.|last5=Karlan|first5=Beth Y.|last6=Alberts|first6=David S.|last7=Lu|first7=Karen H.|date=2015-05-01|title=Salpingectomy as a means to reduce ovarian cancer risk|journal=Cancer Prevention Research (Philadelphia, Pa.)|volume=8|issue=5|pages=342–348|doi=10.1158/1940-6207.CAPR-14-0293|issn=1940-6215|pmc=4417454|pmid=25586903}}</ref> - although critics of this argue that a reduced blood supply to the ovaries may induce premature menopause regardless.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pölcher|first=Martin|last2=Hauptmann|first2=Steffen|last3=Fotopoulou|first3=Christina|last4=Schmalfeldt|first4=Barbara|last5=[[Ivo Meinhold-Heerlein|Meinhold-Heerlein]]|first5=Ivo|last6=Mustea|first6=Alexander|last7=Runnebaum|first7=Ingo|last8=Sehouli|first8=Jalid|date=2015-07-01|title=Opportunistic salpingectomies for the prevention of a high-grade serous carcinoma: a statement by the Kommission Ovar of the AGO|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=Opportunistic+salpingectomies+for+the+prevention+of+a+high-grade+serous+carcinoma%253A+a+statement+by+the+Kommission+Ovar+of+the+AGO|journal=Archives of Gynecology and Obstetrics|volume=292|issue=1|pages=231–234|doi=10.1007/s00404-015-3697-y|issn=1432-0711|pmid=25914073}}</ref>
Prophylactic salpingo-oophorectomy is frequently performed in carriers of BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kauff|first=Noah D.|last2=Satagopan|first2=Jaya M.|last3=Robson|first3=Mark E.|last4=Scheuer|first4=Lauren|last5=Hensley|first5=Martee|last6=Hudis|first6=Clifford A.|last7=Ellis|first7=Nathan A.|last8=Boyd|first8=Jeff|last9=Borgen|first9=Patrick I.|date=2002-05-23|title=Risk-reducing salpingo-oophorectomy in women with a BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|volume=346|issue=21|pages=1609–1615|doi=10.1056/NEJMoa020119|issn=1533-4406|pmid=12023992}}</ref> although the benefits conferred by this procedure may vary dependent on the specific mutation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kauff|first=Noah D.|last2=Domchek|first2=Susan M.|last3=Friebel|first3=Tara M.|last4=Robson|first4=Mark E.|last5=Lee|first5=Johanna|last6=Garber|first6=Judy E.|last7=Isaacs|first7=Claudine|last8=Evans|first8=D. Gareth|last9=Lynch|first9=Henry|date=2008-03-10|title=Risk-reducing salpingo-oophorectomy for the prevention of BRCA1- and BRCA2-associated breast and gynecologic cancer: a multicenter, prospective study|journal=Journal of Clinical Oncology|volume=26|issue=8|pages=1331–1337|doi=10.1200/JCO.2007.13.9626|issn=1527-7755|pmc=3306809|pmid=18268356}}</ref>
Tubal ligation is a less impactful prophylactic treatment shown to significantly reduce the risk of HGSC.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sieh|first=Weiva|last2=Salvador|first2=Shannon|last3=McGuire|first3=Valerie|last4=Weber|first4=Rachel Palmieri|last5=Terry|first5=Kathryn L.|last6=Rossing|first6=Mary Anne|last7=Risch|first7=Harvey|last8=Wu|first8=Anna H.|last9=Webb|first9=Penelope M.|date=2013-04-01|title=Tubal ligation and risk of ovarian cancer subtypes: a pooled analysis of case-control studies|journal=International Journal of Epidemiology|volume=42|issue=2|pages=579–589|doi=10.1093/ije/dyt042|issn=1464-3685|pmc=3619957|pmid=23569193}}</ref>
== Treatment == Cytoreductive “[[debulking]]” surgery may be performed prior to chemotherapy treatment in order to decrease the physical mass of the tumour and thus reduce the number of chemotherapy cycles needed.<ref name=":9" /> The typical advanced presentation as well as extra-ovarian spread seen in HGSC can require aggressive debulking procedures.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ferguson|first=Donna|last2=Han|first2=Lucy|date=2015|title=The role of the fallopian tube in ovarian serous carcinogenesis: biologic mechanisms and clinical impacts|url=http://www.ajceog.us/files/ajceog1311002.pdf|journal=American Journal of Clinical and Experimental Obstetrics and Gynecology|volume=2|issue=1|doi=|pmid=|access-date=|via=}}</ref> In some cases total abdominal [[hysterectomy]] will be performed, in other cases where the patient intends to bear children a salpingo-oophorectomy is performed instead.
Typical chemotherapy is six cycles of intraperitoneally-delivered platinum-base adjuvant chemotherapy with agents such as [[carboplatin]].<ref name=":9" /> Measurements of blood CA125 levels are used to determine patient response to the treatment.
Between 20% and 30% of patients relapse within six months of treatment.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Berns|first=Els M. J. J.|last2=Bowtell|first2=David D.|date=2012-06-01|title=The changing view of high-grade serous ovarian cancer|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=The+Changing+View+of+High-Grade+Serous+Ovarian+Cancer|journal=Cancer Research|volume=72|issue=11|pages=2701–2704|doi=10.1158/0008-5472.CAN-11-3911|issn=1538-7445|pmid=22593197}}</ref>
[[Poly ADP ribose polymerase]] (PARP) inhibitors are another possible treatment, with carriers of BRCA1/2 mutations being the most responsive <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ivy|first=S. Percy|last2=Liu|first2=Joyce F.|last3=Lee|first3=Jung-Min|last4=Matulonis|first4=Ursula A.|last5=Kohn|first5=Elise C.|date=2016-05-01|title=Cediranib, a pan-VEGFR inhibitor, and olaparib, a PARP inhibitor, in combination therapy for high grade serous ovarian cancer|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=Cediranib%252C+a+pan-VEGFR+inhibitor%252C+and+olaparib%252C+a+PARP+inhibitor%252C+in+combination+therapy+for+high+grade+serous+ovarian+cancer|journal=Expert Opinion on Investigational Drugs|volume=25|issue=5|pages=597–611|doi=10.1517/13543784.2016.1156857|issn=1744-7658|pmid=26899229}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Parkes|first=Eileen E.|last2=Kennedy|first2=Richard D.|date=2016-05-01|title=Clinical Application of Poly(ADP-Ribose) Polymerase Inhibitors in High-Grade Serous Ovarian Cancer|journal=The Oncologist|volume=21|issue=5|pages=586–593|doi=10.1634/theoncologist.2015-0438|issn=1549-490X|pmc=4861365|pmid=27022037}}</ref>
== Epidemiology == A study of incidence rates in the US between 1992 and 1999 found that the age-specific incidence rate for HGSC doubles every 10 years up until age 55, where it plateaus at approximately 20 cases per 100,000 women - before dropping dramatically after age 75.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Quirk|first=Jeffrey T.|last2=Natarajan|first2=Nachimuthu|last3=Mettlin|first3=Curtis J.|date=2005-10-01|title=Age-specific ovarian cancer incidence rate patterns in the United States|journal=Gynecologic Oncology|volume=99|issue=1|pages=248–250|doi=10.1016/j.ygyno.2005.06.052|issn=0090-8258|pmid=16095676}}</ref>
Ovarian cancer incidence rates are low in East Asia<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Liede|first=Alexander|last2=Narod|first2=Steven A.|date=2002-12-01|title=Hereditary breast and ovarian cancer in Asia: genetic epidemiology of BRCA1 and BRCA2|journal=Human Mutation|volume=20|issue=6|pages=413–424|doi=10.1002/humu.10154|issn=1098-1004|pmid=12442265}}</ref> and highest in Europe, the United States, and Australia/New Zealand.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ferlay|first=Jacques|last2=Shin|first2=Hai-Rim|last3=Bray|first3=Freddie|last4=Forman|first4=David|last5=Mathers|first5=Colin|last6=Parkin|first6=Donald Maxwell|date=2010-12-15|title=Estimates of worldwide burden of cancer in 2008: GLOBOCAN 2008|journal=International Journal of Cancer|volume=127|issue=12|pages=2893–2917|doi=10.1002/ijc.25516|issn=1097-0215|pmid=21351269}}</ref>
Since 1975, survival rates for ovarian cancer have steadily improved with a mean decrease of 51% by 2006 of risk of death from ovarian cancer for an advanced stage tumour.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Temkin|first=Sarah M.|last2=Terplan|first2=Mishka|date=2015-10-01|title=Trends in Relative Survival for Ovarian Cancer From 1975-2011|journal=Obstetrics and Gynecology|volume=126|issue=4|pages=898|doi=10.1097/AOG.0000000000001073|issn=1873-233X|pmid=26393445}}</ref> The increase has mainly been due to successful extended life expectancy of affected patients rather than an improvement in cure rates.
A racial disparity exists between black and white women in the US, where black women experience a higher mortality risk from ovarian cancer.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Terplan|first=Mishka|last2=Schluterman|first2=Nicholas|last3=McNamara|first3=Erica J.|last4=Tracy|first4=J. Kathleen|last5=Temkin|first5=Sarah M.|date=2012-04-01|title=Have racial disparities in ovarian cancer increased over time? An analysis of SEER data|journal=Gynecologic Oncology|volume=125|issue=1|pages=19–24|doi=10.1016/j.ygyno.2011.11.025|issn=1095-6859|pmid=22108636}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|32em}}
[[Category:Ovarian cancer]] [[Category:Gynaecology]]
